entry.title: My Tippet — only Tulle —
entry.content:
My Tippet — only Tulle —
That's a line from Emily Dickinson's poem, "Because I could not stop for death". It's a weird moment. The meter seems to slow way down. For a modern reader, who probably doesn't know the meaning of the words, it's a fun to feel the way the words play from the front of your mouth back into your throat. Courtesy of Wikipedia:
Tippet — a scarf-like narrow piece of clothing, worn over the shoulders. It may also be likened to a stole in the secular rather than ecclesiastic sense of this word. Tulle — a lightweight, very fine netting, which is often starched. It can be made of various fibres, including silk, nylon, and rayon. Tulle is most commonly used for veils, gowns (particularly wedding gowns), and ballet tutus.
The clothes the speaker of the poem is wearing aren't made for warmth. They're ceremonial—a wedding dress or, more likely, the clothes she's been buried in. The courtship theme of the poem implies that in an darkly humorous way she's become married to Death. (Jesus — how many million times has *that *been said?) Is Dickinson satirizing death or is she satirizing romance? Neither, really. I think death is given quite a bit of respect here. And she's not being cynical about romance. What she's satirizing is the way we avoid thinking about death. We can't even call a grave a grave; we call it a house with its roof in the ground. We have to imagine death as a person rather than just this formless and all-consuming *negation*. We have to wrap everything in words—even death, even the ones we love—so that our brains and tongues can hold them. Knowledge is power. Naming things gives us a grasp on life. Naming things creatively lets us enjoy our minds and our mouths and gives us access to real power, real vitality. Say it five times fast: "My Tippet — only Tulle —" Tweet

entry.title: "Because I could not stop for death" by Emily Dickinson
entry.content:
Oof, I'm thin skinned. I take the slightest discomfort or disappointment as a sign that I shouldn't be writing, have no business writing, would serve the world and God and my loved ones best by not writing. I'm only just now, at the age of thirty, learning that discomfort and disappointment are, for me, the essential preconditions of being a writer. We're told to do what we're passionate about, and we're told to do what makes us happy, but we're rarely told that those aren't necessarily going to be the same thing. Writing doesn't make me happy, or at least not very often, but I keep doing it anyway. I write until I get so unhappy that I think I'll be happier if I just stop writing, but that only makes it worse. So I can be either mildly unhappy writing, or deeply unhappy not writing. The choice makes itself. I've started memorizing poems again. It's something I did in college. Keats and Yeats, mostly. The first poem I've memorized is Emily Dickinson's "Because I Could Not Stop for Death". Here's the text.
Because I could not stop for Death – He kindly stopped for me – The Carriage held but just Ourselves – And Immortality. We slowly drove – He knew no haste And I had put away My labor and my leisure too, For His Civility – We passed the School, where Children strove At Recess – in the Ring – We passed the Fields of Gazing Grain – We passed the Setting Sun – Or rather – He passed us – The Dews drew quivering and chill – For only Gossamer, my Gown – My Tippet – only Tulle – We paused before a House that seemed A Swelling of the Ground – The Roof was scarcely visible – The Cornice – in the Ground – Since then – ‘tis Centuries – and yet Feels shorter than the Day I first surmised the Horses’ Heads Were toward Eternity –
There are a lot of boring things to say about this poem, I assume. Things that have been said by a hundred thousand undergraduates in a hundred thousand American literature classes. Why couldn't she stop for death? Is this creepy perversion of the courtship plot supposed to be a satire? If so, of what? In what sense does grain gaze? The sun, too, is like an eye. She's passing by childhood, warmth, light, food, life. What do "Tippet" and "Tulle" mean? Is that a good line or is it just weird? (Once you start memorizing the poem, this becomes one of your favorite lines.) Why isn't the speaker able to recognize the grave for what it is? Is she in denial? There's "Ground" rhyming with itself in the penultimate stanza. What's that about? OK, most of those questions actually weren't that boring. I like to run my hand over a poem, feel its texture. Tap on it, strum it, beat it like a drum. You do this best by memorizing it. The poem as memorized is an essentially different thing from the poem as read. And once its there in you, then you can do anything you want with it. It's yours. It belongs to you, almost more than it ever belonged to the poet who wrote it. The thing that interests me the most in the poem currently is the way the poem stutters in the first two lines of the last stanza.
Since then – ‘tis Centuries – and yet Feels shorter than the Day
What is the subject of "Feels"? Let's start by straightening the sentence out. "The time since then, even though it's been centuries, feels shorter than the Day[....]" "Since then" is the subject. It's a stand-in for the more logical "the time since then." "'tis Centuries" is a reduction of the phrase "the time since then has been centuries." But what about the "and yet"? Where did that come from? It indicates a hesitation or sob or wandering into thoughtlessness. The speaker is struck with the sublime power of "Centuries". The speaker leaves so much unsaid — can't even admit that it's not a house she's come to but a grave — that the horror of the empty "Centuries" gives her pause. "and yet" is a jarring attempt to get the poetry moving again. It's been such a sing-song poem so far, but here the rhythm breaks or at least trips. We feel that the speaker is upset, and we know we should feel upset as well, and we do. I won't make any promises that I'll return to the blog tomorrow, but I hope to. I wrote this piece in an hour. I'm OK with it. I don't want to destroy it, which is saying something. Good enough. Until tomorrow, then, or whenever. Tweet

entry.title: 'January' by Charles Simic
entry.content:
A couple weeks ago I picked up the new issue of *The Paris Review*, mainly because it has some interviews I wanted to read (Hilary Mantel, Lydia Davis, Elena Ferrante) and a new novella by James Lasdun. But it also features some excellent poems, including three poems by Charles Simic. Usually I'm not wild about Charles Simic. He strikes me as a rich man's poet. He's an oenophile's oenophile. I find his chumminess around the finer things distasteful. But that's my problem, not his. I'm a bit of a populist, and sometimes that clouds my judgment. So with no more hemming and hawing, here's 'January' by Charles Simic, from the Spring 2015 issue of *The Paris Review*:
Children’s fingerprints On a frozen window Of a small schoolhouse. An empire, I read somewhere, Maintains itself through The cruelty of its prisons.
The line breaks online aren't arranged the same way as they are in print, so I've adjusted them to match the what-seems-to-me more sensible option. This is the second time I've found that a big publication didn't get the line breaks right online (the first time was with Michael Robbins' 'Country Music', where *The New Yorker *website did away with the line breaks entirely.) What to say about this poem? It's a simple construction. One image and one idea, yolked together in an unlikely but clever pairing. We could interpret that image of the children's fingerprints in any number of ways, but Simic puts a great spin on it by recalling something he read once. He gives voice to something we all felt as school kids, I think: it isn't fair that we have to spend our childhoods locked up in some classroom. I went to Our Lady of Perpetual Help (OLPH) elementary school, a Catholic school run by Sisters of the Immaculate Conception; it was a good school but my we still found it hilarious to refer to OLPH as the Old Ladies' Prison Home. The structure of this poem would make a good writing exercise. Juxtapose an image and an idea so that the second one spins the first in an interesting way. You could do the same thing with two images: I'm thinking of Ezra Pound's "In a Station of the Metro". The important thing is to get in and out of the reader's imagination quickly. It's a good way to make people laugh or consider an unpleasant truth that they otherwise wouldn't make time for. That'll do it for me today. I've got a post going up on the Ploughshares blog later this morning, so please do check that out. Until tomorrow, all.

entry.title: Bloomin' Onion
entry.content: I just submitted my next post for the *Ploughshares *Blog. It took me way too long to write it. I've been slacking on my writing lately. I don't make time for it in the same way that I make time for other things—work, editing projects, video games, TV. I go to the movies maybe only two or three times a year but I bet I'd sooner go to the movies than sit down for an hour and just write. My post is about a couple of poets I've reviewed here on the blog. I like that my editor at *Ploughshares *lets me quote long passages from poems. It's important to me that I can share the poetry itself rather than just talk about it abstractly. I want people to feel the thing itself. I hate abstractions. I've avoided words like "haunting" and "passion" and "human" because they just don't goddamn *mean* anything. I hate those lazy tokens of the craft. I don't want to be lazy. I want to be bold, like Harold Bloom. I remember the first time I heard someone criticize Harold Bloom. I'd been pulling *The Western Canon *and *Genius *and *Shakespeare: The Invention of the Human *out of the college library for a whole year. My favorite high school English teacher had given us an excerpt from the Shakespeare book and I loved it. I was reading a lot of Nietzsche at the time, so I was ready for that kind of grand, generalizing voice. But then some guys I met in college told me how much they hated Bloom and I thought, "Oh, there's something here I should hate." They said they read The Western Canon and hated it so much that they burned their copies on a hibachi grill. "Oh, jeeze, I really shouldn't like this stuff." I would have told you I was a go-my-own-way type of guy back in college but the truth is I was deeply impressionable. I let people I barely knew dictate my tastes because I wanted them to like me. I have, over the years, become more boring. There's no getting around that. I'm less adventurous, less confrontational, less involved. I'm trying to fight back against the boredom, but it's definitely winning. So yeah, I stopped reading Bloom, even though I still liked the boldness of his pronouncements. Bloom slaps his hand on the table and says "This is just how things are!" The subtext being "And fuck you if you don't believe it." I like his egomania, the way he can't stop talking about himself. I like that Bloom is a Yale guy. He lives that swagger and pomposity to its honest fulfillment. I sat in on the first session of a class he did for undergrads. The room was packed and he said at the end, "I'm going to go and sit in one of the classrooms somewhere in the building. If you're serious about taking this course, write out a few hundred words about why you should be allowed in and come find me." Who goddamn *does *that? So here's what I say to those guys who burned copies of  The Western Canon on their hibachi grill: fuck you guys. Literature is a creator's game, not an analyst's. Literary criticism is weighted down with a thousand thousand milquetoasts and poetasters; what we want are bold voices who are willing to be wrong in order to get it right. You can and should argue with Harold Bloom, but that's only because he's bold enough to say things that are worth arguing about. The stakes of his arguments are high: he's trying to define the shape of humanity. Writers: can you say the stakes of your arguments are high?

entry.title: Cranking
entry.content:
I'm writing this post on my tablet. It's a relatively inexpensive Samsung Galaxy tab. It does that thing where you can just drag your finger across the keyboard and it guesses what you wanted to type. It's shockingly accurate.

I'm not so much writing a post as going to crank one out. Hence the title.

What is a post on a blog? To me there are two ways of speaking: prepared and extemporaneous. Most writing is akin to prepared speech. But blog writing is akin to extemporaneous speech. To me,  that's its chief appeal. That's the appeal of cheaply produced podcasts. That's the appeal of comic books. It's culture hot off the press. It's clunky and cliché and closer to the beating heart of everyday thought and speech than anything you'll find in novel or book of poems. 

I'm listening to Marc Ribot while I crank. I had a serious jazz phase in high school and college. It started with Chick Corea and Al di Meola but moved to Miles Davis and Medeski, Martin and Wood and then a ton of Dave Douglas and Marc Ribot and Uri Caine. After my jazz phase I got really into classical,  then talk radio and podcasts,  and now here we are.

Alright, that's all for today. More later, poetry lovers.

entry.title: Returning to "It Isn't Me" by James Lasdun
entry.content:
I discovered Richard Rohr yesterday thanks to a podcast by Pete Holmes. Rohr is a Franciscan on "the edge of the inside" of Christianity. That phrase means he's just Christian enough to call himself Christian, but (refreshingly) he recognizes the contingency of his faith. He was born to devout Christian parents in rural Kansas; as he says in the interview with Pete Holmes, he'd be a devout Hindu now if he'd been born in India. In other words, there are many paths to revelation, reintegration, resurrection. There is no one true way. There are as many paths as there are people. Jesus. He's all over this "It Isn't Me" poem by James Lasdun, isn't he? "they couldn’t, in the end, believe in him, / except as some half-legendary figure / destined, or doomed, to carry on his back // the weight of their own all-but-weightless, stray / doubts and discomforts." The dropout, the loser, the person who doesn't quite fit in: that's Jesus. It's also the artist. Or the romantic artist. The genius. Here's a great essay by Lasdun on the poet/translator Michael Hofmann, entitled "A Sherlock of Poems". Here's a great quote:
In Mexico Michael  declared with sublime intransigence that the Mason-Dixon line ran along the Canadian border, and that the flocks of obvious (if rather small) pigeons in Cuernavaca were in fact quail. These rare but striking lapses from omniscience put me in mind of Sherlock Holmes’s apparent ignorance of the fact that the earth revolves around the sun. The lacunae became, somehow, further evidence of the genius. And I suspect I am not the only friend of Michael’s who feels a little ploddingly Watson-like in his company, or, for that matter, who regards him as something like the Sherlock Holmes of British poetry: preternaturally attuned to reality, somewhat inclined to disappear, and always several leagues ahead of everyone else.
Genius and goodness lead to loneliness. They make you admirable, yes, but they separate you. Others feel like Watsons in the presence of the genius or the saint. Some people like that feeling; many more, I would think, resent it. Jesus had plenty of admirers, but in the end there were more (and more powerful) people who hated him. "Genius and goodness lead to loneliness." Do I really believe that? No, not really. That's how it appears to people in the center, but not to the person on the edge of the inside. To the individual who takes the wider perspective—the unpopular perspective—separation from the insiders isn't a problem. It's a natural part of being true to oneself. *It is a source of joy*. Not *seeming *joy. Not "I guess *technically *I'm happy" joy. *Real joy*. I forget that too often. Sometimes I just want so bad to *belong to a group. *People who love poetry. People who love comic books. Computer programmers. Literature nuts. But none of that none of that none of that will make me happy unless I'm a secure, confident, comfortable individual first. And that comes with being true to myself, being able to look at the things that I want even though I know they're bad for me (and even though they're good for other people) and say, "It isn't me."

entry.title: "It Isn't Me" by James Lasdun
entry.content:
Lately I've been reading a collection of James Lasdun's poems that will be coming out from Farrar Straus and Giroux this spring. I'd never read his poetry before. (That's a phrase I should stop using on this blog. I say it too often. One must accept one's newbishness. Mustn't one?) And I'm really enjoying it, mostly. The Poetry Foundation has made a few of his poems available online. "Blues for Samson" is one of my least favorite in the collection. I get the clever play on a modern Samson and Delilah story, but it's a little blah, a little too clever and macho for it's own good. (Side note: The best thing I've ever read about men's haircuts is the story "A Short History of Hairdressing" from Julian Barnes' collection of short stories, *The Lemon Table.*) But the other two poems they feature are ones I've really enjoyed. Here's "It Isn't Me", from the December 2009 issue of *Poetry *magazine.
*It isn’t me*, he’d say, stepping out of a landscape that offered, he’d thought, the backdrop to a plausible existence until he entered it; *it’s just not me*, he’d murmur, walking away. *It’s not quite me*, he’d explain, apologetic but firm, leaving some job they’d found him. They found him others: he’d go, smiling his smile, putting his best foot forward, till again he’d find himself reluctantly concluding that this, too, wasn’t him. He wanted to get married, make a home, unfold a life among his neighbors’ lives, branching and blossoming like a tree, but when it came to it, *it isn’t me* was all he seemed to learn from all his diligent forays outward. And why it should be so hard for someone not so different from themselves, to find what they’d found, barely even seeking; what gift he’d not been given, what forlorn charm of his they’d had the luck to lack, puzzled them—though not unduly: they lived inside their lives so fully they couldn’t, in the end, believe in him, except as some half-legendary figure destined, or doomed, to carry on his back the weight of their own all-but-weightless, stray doubts and discomforts. Only sometimes, alone in offices or living rooms, they’d hear that phrase again: *it isn’t me*, and wonder, briefly, what they were, and where, and feel the strangeness of being there.
Herman Melville's "Bartleby the Scrivener" comes to mind. Who is this character? What's his relation to "it"? What does he mean by "me"? Is he right to demand that the circumstances of his environment and his job and his social arrangements suit him? I want to say to him, "Of course *it *isn't *you*! That's life!" But maybe I'm wrong. Maybe I feel so vehemently opposed to his way (or rejection) of life because I'm suppressing my own inner mantra of "it isn't me." The repressed always returns in disguise, *often as a strong emotion*. I'll come back to this soon. I also want to look at "The Blight". Until next time.

entry.title: Gratitude
entry.content: Yesterday I received a new biography of T.S. Eliot in the mail. I didn't ask for it; the publisher just sent it to me. This morning I read (for the twentieth or thirtieth time) a book of poems that I'll be reviewing this coming month. I've been in touch with the author (whose one of my favorite poets writing today) and I've been able to get his answers to some specific questions. Would any of this have been possible if I hadn't started blogging over this last year? Absolutely not. I feel, right now, a tremendous sense of gratitude. Doing what I like, saying what I feel, expressing my confusion and my enthusiasm (is there anything more embarrassing?)—these have brought me more interesting and important experiences than I would have ever thought possible. I feel a tremendous sense of gratitude right now. Thanks for reading. :-)

entry.title: 'Orality, Literacy, and the Memorized Poem' by Mike Chasar
entry.content:
Hey all! I want to kick off this week by reading a recent non-fiction piece from Poetry Magazine. I wasn't crazy about much of the poetry in the issue, but I did enjoy this essay by Mike Chasar, entitled "Orality, Literacy, and the Memorized Poem". Here's the TL;DR: poetry in the form of text has more social clout in the U.S. than poetry in the form of spoken words. Why? Because educational systems push people out of the oral economy and into the literal/literate economy. Literacy is a stamp of approval; the author provides authority. Here are several choice quotes:
In his now classic study Orality and Literacy: The Technologizing of the Word, Walter J. Ong traces the differences in communication forms and dynamics between oral and literate cultures, distinguishing between the fixity and abstracted knowledge of print (which “sets up conditions for ‘objectivity,’ in the sense of personal disengagement or distancing”) and the “situational, operational frames of reference” of orality and its real-time, personal exchanges.... For Ong, the values of oral and print economies exist in relation to one another in the modern, Western world of widespread literacy, where most oral communication is in some way underwritten, made possible by, or in a sort of dialogue with, the technology and authority of print....
You follow what he's saying here? As I understand it, Ong is contending that the spoken word is tethered to the written word. The written word says, "You can go as far as I would go, but no further." When people *say *what cannot be *written *(and I'm extrapolating a bit here) we step into the world of class conflict. Think about it: don't you cringe a little when a professor sounds *too *much like a book? They're walking a fine line between the spoken and written word. All professionals are. Professional speakers crack jokes and make little gestures toward the casual world of speech as if to say "I know all this book stuff, and I'm going to keep talking about it in a bookish way, but really I'm just like you." It's a question of who's in and who's out. So what's that have to do with poetry?
Among its other functions, the memorized poem in the schoolroom becomes a crucial intersection of oral and print economies, as the spoken display of one’s mastery enlists values associated with orality (bodily carriage, gesture, intonation, and elocution) even as word-for-word fidelity to the original, printed text remains the  primary measure of achievement....
Having gained momentum and come to seem even more natural thanks to the privileged place of rote memorization, those values still inform, albeit in somewhat refracted ways, how we relate to certain sorts of poetry (and poetry delivery systems)  differently than to others today. Publication in the little magazine or the slim volume, for example, is a far more “credible” sign of a poet’s accomplishment — far more likely to elicit respect, scholarly consideration, and even promotion or tenure — than poetry in performance or other non-print contexts, historical or contemporary. The same poem is likely to acquire a credibility when presented in Poetry that it loses if “interpreted” on air by Garrison Keillor. This is one reason why poets with print-based, rather than performance-based, résumés “read” at presidential inaugurations. 
The difference between oral and print economies isn't just about how we interpret poetry; it impacts the type of poetry people choose to write. Certain poets — I'll say *most* poets — want to be credible. The way to be credible as a poet is to be published. If you can, you get a position at a university teaching poetry. Authorship and authority: those are the two keys to the Kingdom of Professional Poetry. And your poetry becomes bookish, highly allusive. Like T.S. Eliot you provide notes to the allusions in your own poems. Chasar's description of a poetry reading is dead-on:
The management of the relationship between oral and print value economies comes into view most clearly (at least in the context of what Charles Bernstein has called “official verse culture”) in the phenomenon of the professional poetry “reading,” which uses  a print-based term to describe what is otherwise a recitation for the purposes of saving the endeavor from its affiliation with the oral. The last thing a professional poet wants is to risk being linked to the history of recitation and its accumulated values, and so he or she goes through a set of gestures meant to anchor his or her performance in print. She reads in a more or less standardized, even impersonal, style with little intonation and few if any theatrical gestures. She disengages from the work itself by not memorizing it. She makes a show of displaying, paging through, or talking about her books or manuscripts. And she references the poem’s social ties not in regard to the immediacy of what Ong calls the “existential present” (i.e., the  moment of the poetry reading itself), but, rather, in regard to its biographical impetus, moment of inspiration, or compositional process.
(I have to say, I don't like the way Chasar makes this fictional poet female. It's harmless enough in most cases to use the feminine pronoun generically, but here he's creating too much of a contrast between this straw-woman poet and virile figures like Charles Bernstein and Robert Frost. Even if you're reading generously, it comes off as sexist.)

For Chasar, this reader's opposite would be Robert Frost, who improvised during his reading at JFK's inauguration. By improvising, Frost put aside the tradition of his own work and embraced the spirit of the moment. He put the oral before the literal at a crucial moment. What does that say about the U.S.? What does that say about who we were, and who we are becoming? Frost valued the spirit over the letter. Chasar does, too, and so do I. Should that make a difference in how we read? In how we write? Does this knowledge change us? Does it imply a critical ethics? A practical ethics? I don't know. But it's a rare article that can bring these issues up so plainly and strikingly. Chasar pushes you to take a side. Good for him. And good for *Poetry* for publishing it. Go read the whole thing. Until Wednesday, meinen Freunden.

entry.title: Resolutions
entry.content: Browsing through the Blogging subreddit, I was pleased to find a post entitled 'What are your blogging related New Year's Resolutions?' The most upvoted comment is from user CulinariaBlog, who said "Try to find more blogs I like and comment in them." I think that's a great resolution. There are plenty of 'post more regularly' resolutions, but none of that does much if we bloggers aren't reading and supporting one another. And support isn't just giving one another a pat on the back; it's asking hard questions, expecting more from each other as thinkers and writers. I'll follow these redditors lead and make a better effort to engage with my fellow bloggers. I've got a few resolutions this year, mostly related to fitness and professional development, but I've got literary goals, too. Last year I wrote over a hundred blog posts, four published articles, a half-dozen or so poems I was pretty proud of, and (God help me) a short novel. I'm not sure I really want to do much more than that; I just want to redistribute my efforts a bit. No more miserable novel writing, that's for damn sure. I want to keep my prose writing to non-fiction about poets and poetry. I want my reading to feed my non-fiction; my reading will be *research*, a term I dislike because I know that actual scholarly research is far more strenuous than anything I'll be doing. And I want to be more diligent about setting aside time to write poetry, and some time to submit my poems to journals. I've sent poems to five or six journals in the past year and received nothing but rejections. I took it poorly, let it get me down, and quit trying. This year, I'm resolved to keep pushing at it and finally get some poetry published. So much for resolutions. In tomorrow's post I'll feature a poem. Until then.

entry.title: A New Year; 'Asking the Way' by Ko Un
entry.content:
I've spent most of today writing my next post for Ploughshares. But of course, it's the first day of the new year, so I'm also thinking about the year ahead and the year that's just past. What was I happy with? What could I have done better? What lessons can I draw that will help me in the year ahead? I was unhappy with the way I slowed down on this blog over the course of the last half-year. I really enjoyed the early days of the blog when I was putting up new material daily. And honestly, even though I repeatedly allow myself the excuse that not writing a post is a time-saver, I know that that's not really true. Writing a post each morning, which usually took no more than an hour, was a tremendous energy and confidence boost. So I think I'm going to bring back the daily format. Last year I read voraciously and wrote sporadically. This year I'm going to write like a beast, and my reading will be the food that keeps the writing strong. Wow — for someone who writes about poetry, I am terrible at metaphors. Here's a fitting poem for beginning anew. It's called 'Asking the Way,' by the Korean poet Ko Un.
You fools who ask what god is should ask what life is instead. Find a port where lemon trees bloom. Ask about places to drink in the port. Ask about the drinkers. Ask about the lemon trees. Ask and ask until nothing’s left to ask. — translated by Suji Kwock Kim and Sunja Kim Kwock in the November 2014 issue of Poetry Magazine
What a taut, unassuming little poem! Someone new to the English language could read this with little trouble and come away from it refreshed and enlightened. There are questions to ask about this poem, certainly, but not because it makes obscure references or difficult vocabulary or contorted syntax. Its surface is smooth and pleasant. It fits in your hand or in your mouth. (What am I saying? I'm not completely sure, but I know it's true. This sort of discover is exactly why I need to write more often.) The poem consists of a single declarative sentence followed by five imperatives. Each of the imperatives seems to drive forward the same point. The last imperative summarizes and can replace all the other four, except that it can't because the repetition is enacting the poem's rhetorical point: you should keep asking and asking, repeating until (if it's possible) you come to the end. The speaker is rejecting inquiry into god in favor of inquiry into the world. The abstract is left behind for the particular. He tells the fools they "should ask what life is" but of course "life" is a very broad concept. He clarifies: "life" is the stories and details and truths that can be offered about people and places and things. "Life" is being in and talking about the world. "god" is not that; "god" is outside the world; there is no one to ask about "god" and no one who can tell about "god"; "god" is not the life, or the truth, or the way. Ah, I'm looking forward to another year of reading poetry. Until tomorrow, friends. Tweet

entry.title: My first article on the Ploughshares Blog
entry.content: My first post on the Ploughshares Blog is now live. I've obsessed over this article for the last month—changing words and word orders and punctuation and then changing them all back—so it's nice to have it out of my hands. entry.title: Michael Robbins on 'A Poem for President Drone'
entry.content:
Following up on yesterday's post, Michael Robbins forwarded me an article he wrote (published in the Los Angeles Review of Books) about 'A Poem for President Drone'. It's a really interesting and incendiary summary of his position on the drone program and our willful blindness to its horrible violence. Here's a highlight:
Because violent civilian deaths are all too common in Mideast war zones like Pakistan, and uncommon in suburban American communities like Newtown, Connecticut, it makes perfect sense that a person would get more exercised about the latter. This could well be true, but it misses the point. I, for one, am not bewildered by people being more upset about the Newtown victims than they are about the children their taxes help to murder in Pakistan and Yemen. I simply believe that they should be as upset about the latter. Or more so. Leaving aside the absolutely relevant fact that the United States is not currently at war with Pakistan or Yemen, is there a “moral difference” between the cases at issue? Of course there is: you and I bear no responsibility for the Newtown shootings. (I suppose one could argue that we bear a slight responsibility, insofar as we have not been active enough in the fight for sane gun legislation, but let that go.) But we are indeed complicit in the deaths of those 64 Pakistani children. It is our government that is killing them, after all. The drones and their operators are bought and paid for with our money. And there is a remarkable venality in the suggestion that, because children live in a war zone, their deaths matter less. The more trenchant question is whether our attacks on Pakistani citizens are immoral. I believe they are. And I believe that our president is a war criminal with the blood of innocent children on his hands. No doubt that makes me an infantile leftist. There are worse fates. —from the Los Angeles Review of Books
Sure, all politicians—including the President—deserve unflinching scrutiny and fearless critique. But sometimes as a writer you can go so far to the left that you end up saying things the right would just *love* to quote you on. I don't want to get into my own politics here too much, but Robbins' sharp criticism raises the point: is it the poet's place to be the thorn in the establishment's side? Is Robbins even speaking as 'the poet Michael Robbins' here, or isn't it rather that he's speaking as a citizen? Or is such a separation even possible? I'm not too sure where I fall here, though I do know that I wouldn't say what Robbins has said. I would be too afraid that I was being rash, and I would be unsure that I wasn't doing more harm than good.

entry.title: Political Poetry: Heidi Lynn Staples and Michael Robbins
entry.content:
Last week I looked at a poem by Martín Espada, which I read as a political poem. But Espada's poem was very straight-faced; I'd like to look at some political poems that use humor to satirize their objects. First, from the latest issue of *The American Poetry Review*, I want to read 'O Anti O Antiphons' by Heidi Lynn Staples.
O man-made machine who fakes man as Thing and Foresaker, the rope     shipped around our neck of the woods, Come to enslave us     to our owned hours, O body become Bot. O Smart Phone, who flames from the mouth if a screen, waiting in the     pockets, lights in the mall’s smallest darkness, Come, recognize     our vices. O keyboard O Facebook, and Social Media and WWW, whose ever-     widening “Buyer!” has been let loose and pawned the words:     Come, and bring forth “Friend”, let us bow together before your     Cyclops. O keyboard and clicker of the Digital Age, who can recognize my face     from among the masses and hunt me down and destroy me from     any remote location: Come, come and watch over us. O biotech implant, over become lover, O biotech Virus of Neural     Plaquing, how skull no longer offers isolation. O Predator Drone, O Hummingbird Drone, O Bee Drone Swarm how     hovers: Come, and, let us watch a man-made machine unmake a     man unto forsaken thing, Come into the classrooms of our youth     and hear how we laugh. O robotic nurse, who can sing, who can dance, who stands ready with     outstretched metal rubber- encased arms and movement-tracking     tearless eyes before our bodily suffering she shall not waver:     Come and deliver into their beds our soft bodies, pliable babies, into your arms,     into your arms, into your arms, forever more     and more… —text from *The American Poetry Review* website
There are several rhetorical devices/structures clearly at work. The three big ones are:
"Apostrophe (Greek ἀποστροφή, apostrophé, "turning away"; the final e being sounded) is an exclamatory figure of speech. It occurs when a speaker breaks off from addressing the audience (e.g. in a play) and directs speech to a third party such as an opposing litigant or some other individual, sometimes absent from the scene." —source "In rhetoric, an anaphora (Greek: ἀναφορά, "carrying back") is a rhetorical device that consists of repeating a sequence of words at the beginnings of neighboring clauses, thereby lending them emphasis." —source "Litany, in Christian worship and some forms of Judaic worship, is a form of prayer used in services and processions, and consisting of a number of petitions. The word comes from the Latin litania from Ancient Greek: λιτανεία (litaneía), which in turn comes from Ancient Greek: λιτή (litê), meaning "supplication"." —source
The poetic speaker is turning away from us, the listeners, to address these technological gods. The implication is that we turn with the speaker and join in the worship. So it's mock-religious speech, which is not to say that it's mocking religion. In fact, the poem relies on our belief in the power and importance of religious speech to emphasize that these lauded technologies aren't worthy of worship. There's a bit of Allen Ginsberg's 'Howl' in here, I think. And inside that is quite a bit of Walt Whitman. Ginsberg and Whitman were drawing from the American oratorical tradition of the fiery sermon, which is rich in anaphora and litany. Both Ginsberg and Whitman asserted that there was holiness to be found everywhere. By turning the religious imagery onto unworthy gods, Staples makes us see that the holiness isn't exactly everywhere. She finds what Ginsberg found in the second section of 'Howl': Moloch, the child-devouring god. Satire is among the least cynical things in the world. Satire singles out the base because it believes so strongly in the noble. Satire singles out the profane because it believes so strongly in the holy. Is this poem properly political? Sure, though of a certain kind. It's political in that it rejects a dominant ideology (more technology is *always *good). But it doesn't single anybody out. It doesn't refer to any particular politician or policy. It's not invective. For something a little more like that, I'd like to turn to a poem by Michael Robbins (whom I've read here on the blog before). As Robbins tells it on his blog, he was commissioned by Yahoo! to write an inaugural poem, but they refused to publish it because it contains the word "queef." Oh well.
This is a poem for President Drone. It was written by a camel. Can I borrow your phone? This is for President Mark Hamill. Newtown sounds a red alert. Mark Hamill asks is Ernie burnt? Every camel’s a first-person shooter. The Prez’s fez is haute couture. It seems strange that he should be offended. The same orders are given by him. Paging Pakistan and Yemen. Calling all the drone-dead children. The camel can’t come to the phone. This is for the drone-in-chief. Mumbai used to be Bombay. The bomb bay opens with a queef. —text from Michael Robbins' blog
Like Staples, Robbins is setting the tone of the form (bouncy, fun) against the content (the Newtown massacre, President Obama's unprecedented use of killer drones). This intentional mismatch of form to content lets us *feel *that something is deeply out of sorts. Praising something that doesn't deserve it, having fun with something deadly serious — we react almost *physically *to the wrongness of it. But the content here is also cutting. President Obama is called 'President Drone', 'President Mark Hamill' (a reference, perhaps, to Ronald Reagan's Star Wars program), and "the drone-in-chief." Like Staples, Robbins is using apostrophe to turn directly to someone else and we're supposed to turn with him. But it's *the President*. As an Obama supporter, the poem makes me cringe. As a New Englander I cringe to hear the deaths of children in Yemen and Pakistan compared to the Newtown massacre, but there it is. That's the gauntlet Robbins has thrown down, *and he's not wrong*. Robbins isn't just challenging the President; he's challenging *us*. --- I'd like to continue looking at more political poetry in the months ahead. It's been a nice journey in the last six months that I've been blogging. I feel like I'm settling more into a niche, learning the poets and journals I like and getting a better sense of where to look to be part of the conversation. Though I've still got a lot to learn. Well, a little at a time. I'll be back on Friday looking at a poem by Philip Levine. Until then, do check out *The American Poetry Review*, Heidi Lynn Staples' *Noise Event*, and Michael Robbins' *The Second Sex*.

entry.title: 'Butter' by Elizabeth Alexander
entry.content:
Happy Thanksgiving! Not going to editorialize this time; just gonna share a poem and get back to my own style of Thanksgiving hijinks. Here's 'Butter' by Elizabeth Alexander:
My mother loves butter more than I do, more than anyone. She pulls chunks off the stick and eats it plain, explaining cream spun around into butter! Growing up we ate turkey cutlets sauteed in lemon and butter, butter and cheese on green noodles, butter melting in small pools in the hearts of Yorkshire puddings, butter better than gravy staining white rice yellow, butter glazing corn in slipping squares, butter the lava in white volcanoes of hominy grits, butter softening in a white bowl to be creamed with white sugar, butter disappearing into whipped sweet potatoes, with pineapple, butter melted and curdy to pour over pancakes, butter licked off the plate with warm Alaga syrup. When I picture the good old days I am grinning greasy with my brother, having watched the tiger chase his tail and turn to butter. We are Mumbo and Jumbo’s children despite historical revision, despite our parent’s efforts, glowing from the inside out, one hundred megawatts of butter. — from the Poetry Foundation website; full citation info here

entry.title: 'Who Burns for the Perfection of Paper' by Martín Espada
entry.content:
We're all busy trying to make life better for ourselves and the people we love, but none of us goes about it in exactly the same way. There are different types of labor and there are different types of laborers, and each owes something to the other. Paradoxically, this variety of desires all pulling in different directions doesn't result in chaos but in relative harmony. The problem is that if we act as though everyone *didn't* depend on everyone else, if we *refuse *to acknowledge this interconnection of all things, the result is discord. Here's 'Who Burns for the Perfection of Paper' by Martín Espada:
At sixteen, I worked after high school hours at a printing plant that manufactured legal pads: Yellow paper stacked seven feet high and leaning as I slipped cardboard between the pages, then brushed red glue up and down the stack. No gloves: fingertips required for the perfection of paper, smoothing the exact rectangle. Sluggish by 9 PM, the hands would slide along suddenly sharp paper, and gather slits thinner than the crevices of the skin, hidden. Then the glue would sting, hands oozing till both palms burned at the punchclock. Ten years later, in law school, I knew that every legal pad was glued with the sting of hidden cuts, that every open lawbook was a pair of hands upturned and burning. — from the Poetry Foundation website; full citation info here.
The poem moves from a personal, individual experience to a larger sense of the interconnectedness of labors. We get the gritty and sensual details, and then we're invited to imagine those details multiplied by the thousands and the millions. He makes us feel exhausted, he makes us feel like we've been cut, and then he turns that feeling into an idea. He could have chosen any kind of book or type of paper, but he chose the lawbook and the legal pad. He forces us to ask, "What is justice?"
Prisons are built with Stones of Law, Brothels with Bricks of Religion.      — William Blake, *Proverbs of Hell*
We need to be more grateful. Do you think about where your books came from? Where your computer came from? Your clothes? Your food? Look at everything around you and understand that it was made by human care and labor. At some point a teenager in another country, in exchange for wages we would consider criminal here in the United States, built some little piece of your world with their bare hands. I'm not saying, "Maybe that happened." It happened. You might make wiser, more humane political decisions if you appreciated that fact. Awareness is political. Gratitude is political. I'm interested in Espada's sort of political poetry because it trusts in language. The L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poet types call their work political, but they do it in such an arch, clever way that they restrict their audience to other poets like themselves. They subvert normal language and the rules of grammar in order to make a point about the way language is twisted and hollowed out by politicians and businessmen. It's a good idea, but what's the use of speaking about urgent matters in a language people don't understand? Espada's poetry, on the other hand, isn't so paranoid or conspiratorial as to think that the powers that be have corrupted language to its core. He uses ordinary language because he believes in the goodness of the ordinary. You have to believe in the essential goodness of the ordinary if there's to be any hope politically. The remedy for corrupted language isn't snarky parody; the remedy is *more beautiful language that restores our faith in the power and dignity of common language*. Having that faith, one is better equipped to believe in the power and dignity of common people.

entry.title: Dylan Thomas's 'Do not go gentle into that good night'
entry.content:
Continuing my train of thought from Monday's post, I want to try and read Dylan Thomas's 'Do not go gentle into that good night' as something other than a #YOLO poem. I don't want to take away anybody's enjoyment of the poem, but I think the depth of that word "rage" is under-appreciated. It's not "Rage Against the Machine" rage; it's something much harder and heavier and sadder than that. Warning: the way I read this poem is a real bummer, so don't keep going if you're looking for a morning pick-me-up. Let's take it one stanza at a time.
Do not go gentle into that good night, Old age should burn and rave at close of day; Rage, rage against the dying of the light.
This first stanza is easily quotable. The two refrains (read up on villanelle form if you need to) appear here as imperative statements. They tell you what to do. That will change soon, as will our sense of who the "you" in this poem is. When he's not giving us these imperatives, Thomas is describing different kinds of men. First there's the old men. They should (but, we imagine, they often *don't*) go unwillingly into death. Then there are the wise men:
Though wise men at their end know dark is right, Because their words had forked no lightning they Do not go gentle into that good night.
Philosophy, Socrates teaches, is preparation for a good death. Thomas would throw back that even if you know that death is good (and I challenge you not to roll your eyes when Socrates says this) you still recognize the impotence of this knowledge. Your words have "forked no lighting": words and knowledge don't stop your fate, words don't change the fundamental condition of being human which is mortality. Now for the good men:
Good men, the last wave by, crying how bright Their frail deeds might have danced in a green bay, Rage, rage against the dying of the light.
Good deeds — *all *deeds, in fact — come to an end. Being good over and over again, like waves lapping on a shore, isn't enough to make a man at peace with death. There's always more to be done or, more to Thomas's point, the good we've done is never really enough. The times could have been more receptive to us; we could have been more powerful. How bright we might have been, if only....
Wild men who caught and sang the sun in flight, And learn, too late, they grieved it on its way, Do not go gentle into that good night.
The wild men thought they were celebrating life, but really they were mourning it's decline. Is there anyone, we're starting to wonder, who is at peace with death when the end comes? Is there anything to be done?
Grave men, near death, who see with blinding sight Blind eyes could blaze like meteors and be gay, Rage, rage against the dying of the light.
Grave men, serious men, men of business and urgency, learn only at the end that they could have been happy. They "see with blinding sight" that "blind eyes" could "blaze like meteors and be gay", and for this reason they "rage against the dying of the light." The blind eyes blazing like meteors is something like poetic or artistic inspiration. You think of Homer's eyes, or Milton's. Or of Thomas's father, who was also going blind, and dying, when this poem was written (or perhaps he was already dead — I don't know). Now Thomas turns to the whole point of the poem; the address to his father.
And you, my father, there on the sad height, Curse, bless, me now with your fierce tears, I pray. Do not go gentle into that good night. Rage, rage against the dying of the light.
"There on the sad height." Why does he imagine his father on a mountain top? It puts his father in a visionary position, a saintly position, a holy position, like Moses on Sinai or Horeb, or Christ on any of several mountains. "Curse, bless, me now with your fierce tears, I pray": to me this is *the *line of the poem. Curse or blessing: Thomas doesn't care. What he wants is the connection, an end to being isolated from his father. But death itself puts his father "on the sad height." It's not Thomas's fault. Death isolates; it constrains the relationship to one of prayer, a holy and real relationship, sure, but one stripped of the sensual and the familiar and the homely. And "your fierce tears." Ugh, that feels too real. How *hard *would it be to write that about a parent? It's no wonder Thomas takes the entire body of the poem to get to this point, *the *point. Now reread those refrains and see that they are full of passion and affection and grief and, yes, rage. Homeric rage, Achilles's rage. "Do not go gentle into that good night," Thomas says to his father. Sure, he's telling him (and us) how to hold his head high, but he's also just saying "Don't go. Don't do it." How *hard *would it be to write this poem? The poem doesn't answer the question of how you should try to live. It systematically undercuts every way of life. Being good, being wild, being serious, being artistic: it doesn't matter. Nobody escapes. This is the quality of Dylan Thomas's rage. Far from a #YOLO poem, this is one of the most unflinching elegies ever written, written — it seems to me — from a place of terrible hurt. I've tried several times now to spin this poem into something positive, but I just can't. I can't read *Romeo and Juliet* as anything but a tragedy. I can't think about *La Boheme* without feeling terrifically sad. Making something positive out of it would feel fake. It would be like telling someone at a funeral to cheer up. Sometimes the poet just needs to say how sad he feels, and sometimes, readers, we just need to listen. Tweet

entry.title: Dylan Thomas, Beavers, and 'Do not go gentle into that good night'
entry.content:
If you follow the trendy bullshit closely, you'll know that this is the centenary of Dylan Thomas's birth. There have been a lot of bad articles about Thomas, and then there's this very good one by Seamus Perry. One of my favorite passages from Perry's article:
Most poetry begins, as Dryden said, with a confused mass of thoughts tumbling over one another in the dark; this was truer for Thomas than for most. He always insisted he wrote ‘out of words’ and not, like a realist novelist or a poet with an ideology to impart, ‘in the direction of them’. The words came first, and the business of writing a poem was the attempt to exercise some control on the multiple and mutually interfering ripples of possible meaning the words brought with them. It does not always come off, as even his keenest admirers would admit. I’m not sure anyone has ever cracked ‘All all and all’, a poem that grows dark with the effort of getting it ‘all’ in: ‘How now my flesh, my naked fellow,/Dug of the sea, the glanded morrow,/Worm in the scalp, the staked and fallow.’ And ‘Altarwise by Owl-Light’ must be the most sheerly difficult sonnet sequence ever written. Most of his great poems retain at least something of this formative confusion. He once said, portentously, in a response to a questionnaire, that ‘poetry must drag further into the clean nakedness of light more even of the hidden causes than Freud could realise’; but pellucid enlightenment is not the effect of most of his poems. Reading him we struggle through a dense verbal murkiness and then suddenly hear language realise itself in a line such as ‘And rivers of the dead around my neck’ or ‘When the worm builds with the gold straws of venom/My nest of mercies in the rude, red tree,’ or ‘the soft,/Unclenched, armless, silk and rough love that breaks all rocks.’ There are countless others.
Reading that makes me think about my own writing. I used to get frustrated with myself because I only half-understood my own writing. Unable to explain what the stuff meant, I felt like I must not be any good. But more and more, I'm understanding that understanding isn't so important. What matters in writing poetry is *intuition, trusting yourself*. Last night I saw an episode of *Nature* about beavers. I'm kind of fascinated by beaver dams. Beavers cut down trees and saw them up with their teeth and pile them up to build homes for their families. (On the show they give you a peek at a beaver family inside their dam, by the way, and it's just as adorable as you want it to be.) If I were being super-analytical I would ask, "Why did the beaver put this particular branch on this part of the dam? What's the full significance of this particular choice?" But it's more simple than that; the beaver is making what it can with what is has to hand. The construction of the dam is intimately tied to the beaver's immediate need and its immediate situation. Poets, likewise, live in a language. We have a need to create, and we have certain words and images and memories to hand. All art is, in a sense, bricolage. What are we trying to dam up? What are we trying to protect? Who knows. All I know is that trying to thoroughly understand your own writing will ultimately lead to nothing but the Sisyphean task of understanding *who you are*. Any literary theory that doesn't take into account *what literature is* ultimately ends up in the realm of philosophy, with literature nowhere in sight. But back to Dylan Thomas. I've never been a big Dylan Thomas fan, and entirely for lack of trying. He's always struck me as a non-poet's poet, especially because of the popularity of 'Do not go gentle into that good night'. Kids in highschool liked the phrases "rage against the dying of the light" and "do not go gentle" because they sounded kind of metal. It always seems to be interpreted as something like #YOLO, which bugs me. It's like Robert Frost's "Two roads diverged in a yellow wood," which so many people read as inspirational but, when you really read it carefully, is much too dark to be inspiring. Also, 'Do not go gentle into that good night' is a villanelle, and I also just don't like villanelles all that much. The repetitions of whole lines come too quickly for my taste. The non-repeated lines feel like throwaways. Oh hell, in case you haven't read the poem in a while, here it is:
Do not go gentle into that good night, Old age should burn and rave at close of day; Rage, rage against the dying of the light. Though wise men at their end know dark is right, Because their words had forked no lightning they Do not go gentle into that good night. Good men, the last wave by, crying how bright Their frail deeds might have danced in a green bay, Rage, rage against the dying of the light. Wild men who caught and sang the sun in flight, And learn, too late, they grieved it on its way, Do not go gentle into that good night. Grave men, near death, who see with blinding sight Blind eyes could blaze like meteors and be gay, Rage, rage against the dying of the light. And you, my father, there on the sad height, Curse, bless, me now with your fierce tears, I pray. Do not go gentle into that good night. Rage, rage against the dying of the light.
There's just no time to talk more about this poem. I'll pick up with it tomorrow.

entry.title: 'Variations on a Theme by William Carlos Williams' by Kenneth Koch
entry.content:
I read this hilarious poem by Kenneth Koch on the train today, and I had to share it. I'll get back to writing about the Misty Poets tomorrow. I found the poem in this awesome collection by Robert Pinsky called *Singing School: Learning to Write (and Read) Poetry by Studying with the Masters*. For a long time I haven't been crazy about anthologies, but this book is turning me around on the idea. OK, so the Kenneth Koch poem is a variation on the classic poem "This Is Just to Say" by William Carlos Williams. You might have read it in high school; I know that's where I first saw it. Here's the poem:
I have eaten the plums that were in the icebox and which you were probably saving for breakfast Forgive me they were delicious so sweet and so cold
Throughout *Singing School*, Robert Pinsky offers a brief comment at the front of each poem. He calls Koch's poem "one of the greatest parodies ever," and I think he's right. OK, I'm done talking it up. Here's Kenneth Koch's "Variations on a Theme by William Carlos Williams":
        1 I chopped down the house that you had been saving to live in next summer. I am sorry, but it was morning, and I had nothing to do and its wooden beams were so inviting.         2 We laughed at the hollyhocks together and then I sprayed them with lye. Forgive me. I simply do not know what I am doing.         3 I gave away the money that you had been saving to live on for the next ten years. The man who asked for it was shabby and the firm March wind on the porch was so juicy and cold.         4 Last evening we went dancing and I broke your leg. Forgive me. I was clumsy and I wanted you here in the wards, where I am the doctor!

entry.title: 'Missed Time' by Ha Jin
entry.content:
I'm going to continue my reading of the Misty Poets with a poem by Ha Jin. About a month ago I had the privilege of seeing Ha Jin, who I'm pretty sure lives here in Boston, read some selections from Dickinson and Yeats. (It was the same reading I saw Robert Pinsky read at.) I was really blown away by the intensity of Ha Jin's reading. You could really tell he was *thinking *the words as he read them. Reading them aloud, finding the right pace and inflection, was *the tangible form of his thought*. It's hard to describe, but it was a powerful difference between him and some of the other readers. And I've been really happy to find that Ha Jin's own poems are equally powerful. I should have known, from the quality of Ha Jin's reading, that he would be a great writer. You have to be a good reader, I think, to be a good writer. Here's a poem by Ha Jin from an old issue of *Poetry*. I'm fascinated by this poem's title and how it might connect to the material. See if you can figure out why. Here's 'Missed Time':
My notebook has remained blank for months thanks to the light you shower around me. I have no use for my pen, which lies languorously without grief. Nothing is better than to live a storyless life that needs no writing for meaning— when I am gone, let others say they lost a happy man, though no one can tell how happy I was. — Ha Jin, *Poetry*, July 2000
First of all, I do believe this to a certain extent. Most writing comes out of anxiety. A life lived without having felt the need to write is a life lived free from all anxiety. There is "nothing better." But is it real? Does such a life even exist? Can any human being live a "storyless life"? Doesn't this poem just reinforce, by the impossibility of the ideal life it illustrates, our knowledge that story and writing are what give life meaning, and that meaning is therefore a substitute for happiness? *Happiness itself is meaningless, and therefore unwritable. Story and writing come after happiness; they are a form of grief. All writing is epitaph*. This, I think, is the reason for the title: 'Missed Time'. This poem is writable because the bliss it describes has already passed. There was a time of joy, once, and now that it's gone all the poet can do is write. (Indeed, this isn't the first time he's fallen from happiness: he owns a notebook and pen, after all!) Writing won't help, but it's all the poet can do, so he must do it. The impulse to write comes insistent like tears. This poem should make us reconsider mourning and tears as a noble engagement with life. If life is so good, we should mourn it without shame. If we aren't mourning it with painting and music and poems, we probably aren't appreciating it enough. There are a lot of answers to the question, "Why write poems?" I think one of the best ones is implied in this poem: We write poems to commemorate the beauty and happiness that have passed from the world. Not because we hope to bring them back, not because others will experience that same happiness by hearing our poems, but because something must be done for the fallen. Maybe I've missed the mark entirely in my reading of Ha Jin. An essay, after all, is an attempt. I'd rather shoot a thousand arrows and only one hit the mark than leave all my arrows in their quiver out of shame or fear or cowardice. And besides: we never know what our words may do. Maybe I've hit some mark I didn't even know was there. That story remains to be written. Tweet

entry.title: 'To the Oak' by Shu Ting
entry.content:
This week I want to focus on the "Misty Poets." From Wikipedia:
The Misty Poets (Chinese: 朦胧诗人; pinyin: Ménglóng Shīrén) are a group of 20th century Chinese poets who reacted against the restrictions on art during the Cultural Revolution. They are so named because their work has been officially denounced as "obscure", "misty", or "hazy" poetry (menglong shi).
In other words, they wrote against the officially sanctioned social realism so they were branded "misty." I love that they wear this insult as a badge of honor. Anti-realists might be a more fitting title in English; anti-social-realists would be even more exact. But "Misty Poets" will have to do. The first poet I want to read is Shu Ting. I would have sworn I'd put one of her poems up here before, but looking through the blog now I don't see any of her work. I mentioned her in my piece on Xi Murong's "Painting Exhibition", but that's all. I love her work.
OK, enough prelude. Here's 'To the Oak', by Shu Ting:
If I love you I won't imitate the morning glory Borrowing your high branches to display myself; if I love you I won't imitate those infatuated birds Who repeat their monotonous flattery to the foliage, Nor the fountain With its solace of cool waters; I won't even be those background vistas That serve to make you more majestic. Not even sunshine, Not even spring rain, No, none of these! I would like to be a kapok tree Standing beside you as an equal, Our roots touching underground, Our leaves touching in the clouds; And with every gust of wind We would bow to one another. But no one else Understands our language; You have your branches Like daggers or swords While my big red flowers Are like heavy sighs. Though it seems we are separated forever We are eternally together. This is great love, This is fidelity. Love— Not only for your splendid trunk But also for the earth you stand on. — Shu Ting, translated by Carolyn Kizer with Y.H. Zhao, *Poetry*, February 1987
There is, of course, an allegory at work. The Oak is some beloved person. The speaker turns the beloved into an allegorical figure and then asks, "Where do I belong in this allegory?" Shu Ting takes her time: The first half of the poem she spends saying what she *won't *be in the allegory. This gives her time and space to talk about *what love is not* in a rhetorical gesture that feels completely natural. The speaker would like, in the allegory, to be a kapok tree. A tree, but not the same tree. Close to the oak, but separate from it. Having its own distinct ground, but sharing roots and canopies, a private and a public language. "Though it seems we are separated forever / We are eternally together." It's about finding the right distance. Look back through the list of rejected images in the first half of the poem. They're always too close or too far. It's not a novel poem, by any means, but it's quiet and peaceful and meaningful and, in my view, quite perfect. *The poem enriches and ennobles both nature and love by tying the two together conceptually*. Quite perfect. Tweet

entry.title: "Rain Effect" by Mary Ruefle
entry.content:
Ah yes: another amazing poem from Mary Ruefle. I love when you can dig deeper and deeper into a poet's work and you just find more and more treasures. When you have that sense of communion with a poet, the sense that they see things the same way you do, the sense that they are able to open up worlds for you because they're coming from the same direction you are, the sense that by getting to know the poet better you're getting to better know *yourself*: that's a feeling you have to chase. So, that said, here's "Rain Effect" by Mary Ruefle. Pay attention to the movement of the the progression of sensations. And be on the lookout for a big leap. We had a big leap in yesterday's poem; actually, now that I think about it, all the Ruefle poems I've looked at have had a big leap, a moment when the poem breaks into a very different B section, to borrow a term from music. Keep your eye open for another here. Here's "Rain Effect":
A bride and a groom sitting in an open buggy in the rain, holding hands but not looking at each other, waiting for the rain to stop, waiting for the marriage to begin, embarrassed by the rain, the effect of the rain on the bridal veil, the wet horse with his mane in his eyes, the rain cold as the sea, the sea deep as love, big drops of rain falling on the leather seat, the rain beaded on a rose pinned to the groom’s lapel, the rain on the bride’s bouquet, on the baby’s breath there, the sound of the rain hitting the driver’s top hat, the rain shining like satin on the black street, on the tips of patent leather shoes, Hokusai’s father who polished mirrors for a living, Hokusai’s father watching the sky for clouds, Hokusai’s father’s son drawing rain over a bridge and over the people crossing the bridge, Hokusai’s father’s son drawing the rain for hours, Hokusai’s father rubbing a mirror, the rain cold as the sea, the sea cold as love, the sea swelling to a tidal wave, at the tip of the wave white. — text from the Poetry Foundation website. They have a footnote: "Mary Ruefle, “Rain Effect” from *Cold Pluto*. Copyright © 1996 by Mary Ruefle. Reprinted by permission of Carnegie Mellon University Press."
First, the form. The whole poem is one long sentence. But no, it's not even that. There's no main verb, so it's just one long fragment that's punctuated helpfully/deceptively like a sentence. If she hadn't written anything from that first "Hokusai" to the end, Ruefle would still have written a beautiful poem. But from "Hokusai" forward we've made the big leap. We've engaged with that *principle of juxtaposition* that makes Ruefle's poems work. They feel (to me) like Joseph Cornell's boxes. Because two unlike things are yoked together, we must do what we can to make sense of them as a whole. If we don't, if we can't, we have to reevaluate our sense of what it is artists do. (This same idea is taken a step further by poets who yoke together unlike grammatical and typographical objects to make us reevaluate our sense of what it is *language* does. This seems like a fine enough idea, to me, but a poor foundation for good poetry.) So how would you relate the A section to the B section. Is the A section the content of a painting by Hokusai? It would seem so, which means that the careful attention to detail, the slow movement from detail to detail is that of Hokusai himself. And yet, these aren't really *painterly* details, are they? The sights are, sure, but the sounds and the thoughts are more of a writer's territory. What's Ruefle doing here? Is it a critique of painting's limitations? Or is she rather opening up our conception of what goes into a painting? And what about this other detail of Hokusai's father, the mirror maker? How does his polishing the mirror tie in? I would venture the guess that we're supposed to draw a connection between the polishing of the mirror (making a thing perfect for seeing oneself) and the detailed attention to the painting (making a thing perfect for seeing the world). They are one and the same activity. Like father like son. Perhaps this is why Ruefle insists on using the awkward phrasing "Hokusai's father's son." And then "the tip of the wave white." I don't even know where to start. This is probably a reference to Hokusai's most famous painting, but why reference it? What does it add to the meaning? One last Mary Ruefle poem tomorrow. Until then! Tweet

entry.title: “Perpetually Attempting to Soar” by Mary Ruefle
entry.content:
Today I'm going to read more from Mary Ruefle. As in the last two posts (here and here) I'm accessing poems through the Poetry Foundation website, so many thanks are due to them for providing such an amazing resource for poetry readers. OK, let's get to it. Here's "Perpetually Attempting to Soar" by Mary Ruefle:
A boy from Brooklyn used to cruise on summer nights. As soon as he’d hit sixty he’d hold his hand out the window, cupping it around the wind. He’d been assured this is exactly how a woman’s breast feels when you put your hand around it and apply a little pressure. Now he knew, and he loved it. Night after night, again and again, until the weather grew cold and he had to roll the window up. For many years afterwards he was perpetually attempting to soar. One winter’s night, holding his wife’s breast in his hand, he closed his eyes and wanted to weep. He loved her, but it was the wind he imagined now. As he grew older, he loved the word etcetera and refused to abbreviate it. He loved sweet white butter. He often pretended to be playing the organ. On one of his last mornings, he noticed the shape of his face molded in the pillow. He shook it out, but the next morning it reappeared. —From the Poetry Foundation website . Mary Ruefle, “Perpetually Attempting to Soar” from *Cold Pluto*. Copyright © 1996 by Mary Ruefle. Reprinted by permission of Carnegie Mellon University Press. "
Not all of Ruefle's poems are narratives, but when they are they really do it for me. Like the poem I read yesterday, this poem is about abstraction. "The boy from Brooklyn" infers a sexual experience from a mundane experience. "Now he knew, / and he loved it." He knew what? The feel of a woman's breast, he tells himself. "He's been assured" that's what it feels like. "Night after night, again and again" — it's a comical inversion of the teenage boy taking a girl out in his car. It's just him and the wind — "night after night, again and again." If I were a university professor I would tell you this poem is about masturbation. Then there's a phrase that tries to sum it all up before moving the next phase of the poem. "For many years afterwards he was perpetually attempting / to soar." He tries to move fast enough to feel the wind. That's the soaring that's going on, I think. For many years he tries to experience things through simulation. "Attempting" is a good word. It's got that sense of failure to it, that sense of *almost but not quite*, and it has the word "tempt" hidden inside.
Then we have a leap. Our hero finds (we don't know how much time has elapsed) that the real thing just isn't enough. He feels his wife's breast and wishes for the wind. The roles are reversed. After all those years of attempting to soar, he finds he prefers the representation of reality to the reality itself. There's a sharp protest in that "He loved her, but...." If he "loves" "the word etcetera" and "butter" then how much does he really "love" his wife? Some love! Then comes the phrase that sums it all up: "He often / pretended to be playing the organ." He's not a creator; he's not really *in* life. He's just pretending. He's pretending "often." Where's that young man who went out driving alone? Right here, still preferring the substitute to the reality. Boys in their cars: we often use this as a symbol of a young lust for life, but Ruefle shows that it's more complex than that. "On one of his last mornings...." The narrative draws so quickly to its close! It's heavy with mortality. "He noticed the shape of his face molded in the pillow. / He shook it out, but the next morning it reappeared." *The man who prefers abstractions to realities is disturbed by the fact that he is a reality that can be abstracted*. Looking at his own abstraction is a realization of — consummation of — his own mortality. He's fascinated — bewitched — by the image of himself. It is the myth of Narcissus. The professor is clearing his throat and giving you that *told you so* look. Maybe I'm wrong. But it's where my mind led me this morning. It's where the poem led my mind this morning. Tomorrow it may take me somewhere else. I look forward to it. Tweet
