entry.title: Review of W.S. Merwin's The Moon Before Morning
entry.content:
Here's my series of posts about W.S. Merwin's The Moon Before Morning in one great big megapost. Also, here's a short article I contributed to, which includes a brief paragraph on Merwin. In short, I loved this book. You should definitely check it out of your library or buy yourself a copy or steal your friend's copy ASAP. Much love, Tim *********************** September 22, 2014 *********************** Rather than complain that Twitter posts and many blogs are too cursory and too canonical in their coverage of poetry, I'm going to counteract the offending trendings and write a slower, more concentrated review about a new book of poetry: W.S. Merwin's *The Moon Before Morning*. Over the course of this week I want to focus on a few key aspects of Merwin's newest book, including his renunciation of punctuation, the arrangement of the poems within the book, and the poetic forms he chooses. But today I just want to gather some information about Merwin into one place. You might have noticed that many of my readings lean toward the New Critical school of thinking: I read the poem as a self-contained unit, rarely going into a poem's or poet's historical context in a way that might inform my reading of a text. But that, I'm afraid, is more out of laziness than ideology. I don't believe in the great Tradition, but at times I read like someone who does. Let's counteract that. *The Moon Before Morning *is Merwin's fourteenth book with Copper Canyon Press; he's been publishing with them for just over twenty years now, though much more prolifically in the last decade. I like Copper Canyon's two paragraph bio, so here it is:
W.S. Merwin was born in New York City in 1927 and was United States Poet Laureate in 2010. He graduated from Princeton University in 1948, where he studied with John Berryman and R.P. Blackmur. From 1949 to 1951 he worked as a tutor in France, Mallorca, and Portugal; for several years afterward he made the greater part of his living by translating from French, Spanish, Latin, and Portuguese. His first book of poetry, *A Mask for Janus* (1952) was selected by W.H. Auden for the Yale Younger Poets Prize. Since then, Merwin has authored dozens of books of poetry and prose. His work embodies a bold commitment to experimentation and transformation rooted in the moral necessity of bearing witness, and is influenced by his profoundly environmentalist, pacifist, and anti–imperialist beliefs. He has won many awards, as well as fellowships from the Rockefeller and the Guggenheim Foundations and the National Endowment for the Arts. W.S. Merwin has lived in Hawaii since 1976. — taken whole-cloth from Copper Canyon's website
That last, tiny sentence is terribly important. Merwin and his poetry are inextricably bound to Hawaii. He isn't just a poet who writes about the environment; he's a committed environmentalist who practices what he preaches on his three acre palm plantation on Maui. From the Wall Street Journal's profile:
Mr. Merwin's path to his palm forest was an indirect one. The son of a Presbyterian minister, he was born in New York, lived in France and then came to Hawaii in the 1970s to study Zen Buddhism. Not long after arriving, he heard of a small piece of land near the coast with a small cabin, the place where three native Hawaiian activists had hidden after defying the U.S. Navy and occupying the bombed island of Kaho`olawe. ... Using his small inheritance, he spent $60,000 or so for just over three acres in 1977. With little money left, he drew plans for the house, and recruited friends and local craftsmen to help him build it. ...
At first, Mr. Merwin said, he had somewhat "naively" hoped to restore a rain forest with native plants. But the soil was so leached and the conditions so dry and wind-swept that he found the only ones that thrived were Hawaiian Pritchardias, a type of palm. He estimates he now has more than 850 different species of palms on the property, including a few he's saved from extinction, such as Hyophorbe indica from Reunion Island.
In 2010, shortly before Mr. Merwin agreed to become the poet laureate, the couple created the Merwin Conservancy, preserving the home and the palm forest and receiving nonprofit status as a retreat for writers and botanists. "William has created one of the greatest palm collections in the world," said Charles R. "Chipper" Wichman, director of the National Tropical Botanical Gardens. "It is amazing." — Julia Flynn Siler, the Wall Street Journal, March 25, 2011
Merwin's piece of Hawaii and its progression over the decades is the subject of most of* The Moon Before Morning*. There is a calm and a magic to the poems that makes you understand* *why Merwin fell in love with the place. Nothing is more important than the place, including time. This loyalty to place enforces a powerful simplicity and economy. Like Ezra Pound, Merwin is a man who *knows* poetry and language, yet we see hardly any of it here. He refuses to wear his learning on his sleeve. *Merwin's withdrawal from the West and the East to an island between is perfectly emblematic of his poetry*. It is a withdrawal into Nature, into the self, into the quiet things that persist when no one else is watching or listening, into things that are always true. I'm a lifelong reader of Henry David Thoreau's *Walden*; is it any wonder this collection appeals to me? *********************** September 23, 2014 *********************** I have the craziest damn day ahead of me, so unfortunately I just don't have time to do any writing. Here's some good stuff to read to familiarize yourself with W.S. Merwin's *The Moon Before Morning*. Fiona Sampson's excellent review at *The Guardian*. If you only read one of these articles, make it this one. Arlice Davenport's paean to Merwin in the Wichita Eagle. I find terms like 'greatest living poet' unhelpful; people who use the term are leaning toward the idea of priesthood. (Last line: "May he keep blessing us with his superlative gift for many more years to come.") But, still, Davenport seems to have read the book well and gotten some of the main points. Camden Avery's excessively lyrical review on The Rumpus. Writing about poetry doesn't require writing poetic prose. Timothy Liu's snarky review on Poets At Work. I'm all for negative reviews, but this one is regrettably mean-spirited, and Liu gives away at several points that he hasn't been reading carefully. <Sigh> Happy reading, happy hunting, happy birthday, etc. etc. etc. Until tomorrow, all. *********************** September 24, 2014 *********************** *Stichic integrity*. I learned this term from Brian Turner, author of two excellent poetry collections and a new memoir. If you Google *stichic integrity *you'll find this article by Turner, in which he describes how, when writing and editing his own poetry, "each line [*needs*] to be considered in isolation for its own strengths and weaknesses." Each line needs to stand on its own two feet. (Fun fact: *stichos* — "stich" pronounced like "stick", "os" as in "cost" —,* *is Ancient Greek for "line" or "verse.") But this doesn't mean that a line  has to be a single sentence or idea. This confused me for a long time. A line's strength can come from playful ambiguity. Here's Turner from that same article:
I like to call some lines ‘wrap-around’ lines. It’s when two phrases cohabitate on the same line. For example: “on a sidewalk, a blistered hand’s gold ring.” That line, for me, has stichic integrity because the two parts play off of each other. The *blistered hand’s gold ring* can be read as existing *on the sidewalk*. In the very next line after that (*still shining, while a medic, Doc Lopez*) Doc Lopez can be read to be still *shining*. Basically, there is an interplay of meaning, an exchange of relationships, built into the positioning of phrases themselves.
By placing the tail of one phrase onto the same line as the head of another phrase, Turner allows their meanings to intermingle. This preserves the logical sense (we can follow natural English sentences rather than puzzle over fragments) while allowing room for the reader's imagination to play. It slows you down and rewards imaginative reading. W.S. Merwin accomplishes something similar throughout *The Moon Before Morning* by giving you just the lines with no guides or cues for how he wants you to read them. There's no punctuation to guide your breath; often there are no stanza breaks to show you where one section ends and another begins. It's just the lines on the page and you. I'll give you a brief example from the first poem in the collection, "Homecoming":
Once only when the summer was nearly over and my own hair had been white as the day's clouds
Let's stop right there. The first line is a little bumpy "Once only when": we might reasonably expect a small pause after "only". Then take the two first two lines together: "Once only when the summer / was nearly over and my own." This could work; that "the summer was... my own" is a little heavy-handedly poetic, but it could work. He could begin the story now. But the "my own" carries over to "hair" and we see that the thought spills over the line. We thought it was over, but it kept going. Does that mean the "summer was ... my own" reading is invalid now? *Logically, yes; Imaginatively, no*. Now it's richer, more ambiguous, more meaningful thanks to its arbitrary positioning between "summer" and "hair". Let's try again:
Once only when the summer was nearly over and my own hair had been white as the day's clouds for more years than I was counting I looked across the garden at evening
Just look at that fourth line and how well it fits with both the line-and-a-half that precede it ("my own hair had been white as the day's clouds // for more years than I was counting") and the line that follows it ("for more years than I was counting // I looked across the garden at evening"). Time flows in many directions; the arrangement of lines controls it, but only just. Notice also that a new section has begun with "I looked across the garden." There's a heavy pause after "counting," the first really heavy pause of the poem. What a perfect word to pause at, especially in the first poem of the collection when we're just learning how the poet counts his lines! The first four lines have been establishing setting and character, and with the fifth line we begin the action. Here's the rest of the poem:
Once only when the summer was nearly over and my own hair had been white as the day's clouds for more years than I was counting I looked across the garden at evening Paula was still weeding around flowers that open after dark and I looked up at the clear sky and saw the new moon and at that moment from behind me a band of dark birds and then another after it flying in silence long curving wings hardly moving the plovers just in from the sea and the flight clear from Alaska half their weight gone to get them home but home now arriving without a sound as it rose to meet them "Homecoming", W.S. Merwin, *The Moon Before Morning*, Copper Canyon Press, ©2014, p.5
You sense the pauses now? The way each line both does and doesn't flow into the one after it? Think about it in terms of stichic integrity. You become *responsible *for the poem, and this responsibility slows you down and makes you experience the peaceful scene the poetic speaker himself is witnessing. I love the heavy pause after "silence" in the twelfth line, and the powerful slowness of the line that follows: "long curving wings hardly moving". And then "moving" takes or seems to take "the plovers" as its direct object, so we know we can't stop. "Hardly moving", yes, but moving all the same. The thought settles into a shape (a line) and then — by the pressure of its desire to keep going — breaks itself. Masterful. Isn't that the word? Until tomorrow, all. *********************** September 26, 2014 *********************** We're going to end with four posts about W.S. Merwin's *The Moon Before Midnight* rather than five. Why? Really it's this: yesterday I found a little time to slow down and relax, and I took it. I've been too stressed out lately. I'm basically working my day job, a medium-sized job on the side, a smaller job on the side, and writing this blog. And now I've been asked to do another blog for a much more demanding audience. It's crazy. It's fun, and fulfilling, and makes me more hopeful for my future than I've been in quite a while, but it's crazy.  But enough about me. Let's get back to Merwin. I want to talk briefly about form. Looking at the poem 'Homecoming' on Wednesday, I stressed the poem's amorphous quality, and how we seemed to be allowed to read both backward and forward in a way that allowed us to experience the subjective aspects of time even while feeling the irresistible forward motion of decay/desire. OK, sure: amorphous-ness. But there was some form to it, wasn't there? Divide it into four-line groups. Look how they begin: "Once ... I looked ... and saw ... long curving wings hardly moving ... but home now arriving." The poem can be broken into logical units; it's important that it isn't, but it's also important that it can be. So what other forms does Merwin use in *The Moon Before Morning*, and how does he use those forms, and how does he resist other forms? The second poem is a lovely sort of haiku, though it doesn't follow the normal metrical rules of haiku. I'll go ahead and share that one since it's so — wow.
Rain through the morning and in the long pool a toad singing happiness old as water — "By the Front Door", W.S. Merwin, *The Moon Before Morning*, Copper Canyon Press, ©2014, p.6
Just really quickly: whenever you notice somebody singing or playing music in a poem, especially if it's toward the beginning of a long poem or the beginning of a collection, the poet is probably talking about her- or himself as a poet. It's a very *meta *gesture. Even the title feels meta — how can "By the Front Door" not be a sly reference to the beginning of the book, just as "Homecoming" was? It's a common gesture. Virgil did it. Dante did it. John Berryman did it. A million poets have done it. Merwin's doing it here. Merwin is the toad; the toad is Merwin. He welcomes the comparison. The littleness of the poet in the poem is matched by the unassuming littleness of the poem itself. And isn't the toad teaching us, in this little poem where we have to add such heavy pauses at the end of each line, exactly how we ought to be reading these poems, and this book as a whole? For me, the shorter poems are the best ones in this book. When Merwin uses longer forms he becomes more generic, more common. But as a whole, the book is a strong one. It's one of the rare books that I'll actually go out and buy a copy of, because I would be glad and proud to have it on my shelf. I have to start wrapping this up. Isn't this ridiculous? I've written so many words about *The Moon Before Morning* now and yet I still feel like I haven't said anything at all. I've learned from the process — some of the things I've written here so matter-of-factly I only *learned through the act of writing *them. Writing here on this blog is a very associative process for me; it's so easygoing that I feel guilty about it sometimes. But whatever. I'm not an academic. This isn't for a literary journal. This is a fun place. A relaxed place. It's good I took that day off, because I needed a little down-time to remember that. I look forward to coming back next week. Have a good weekend, all.

Tweet

entry.title: "Keeping it Simple" by Mary Ruefle
entry.content:
I want to continue reading Mary Ruefle this week. Here's a great short poem of hers, available on the Poetry Foundation website. "Keeping it Simple":
I take the bird on the woodpile, separate it from its function, feather by feather. I blow up its scale. I make a whole life out of it: everywhere I am, its sense of loitering lights on my shoulder. —From the Poetry Foundation website . They have a footnote: "Mary Ruefle, “Keeping It Simple” from *memling’s veil*, published by University of Alabama Press. Copyright © 1982 by Mary Ruefle. Reprinted by permission of the author."
Let's keep the interpretation simple. She sees a bird, she observes the bird, she emulates the bird. Good? Can we all agree on this? The bird is a model of simplicity. Easy peasy. No, sorry, I can't agree to that. There's *always *more to see. Look at some of the key words. What's a key word? A word that makes you slow down. Meanings gather there. Words like "on the" and "from its" just slide by (which is not to say that they're unimportant) but words like "woodpile" and "function" just *demand *more attention. The *most *important word is... well, what do you think it is? I'll show my cards soon. It's only six lines, so let's just take it a bit at a time.
I take the bird on the woodpile, separate it from its function, feather by feather. I blow up its scale.
So we have an observer, and we have a bird being observed. There's a woodpile, "the" woodpile, probably a woodpile outside the observer's home. Then the observer takes a psychological leap by separating the bird "from its function." It's violent. The bird is being torn apart "feather by feather" until all that remains is the idea of a bird, the mythic shape of bird-ness. The phrase "I blow up" is taken from photography, of course, but there's also a latent meaning of violent explosion. The bird's natural size is unnaturally increased, and so the natural is blown up, eradicated. What does "function" mean here? I'm going to guess it means *the bird's symbolic place in the observer's life, the way the image of the bird fits into the observer's imagination*. Every observer — all of us — contains an imaginarium, a set of images we've been collecting all our lives. We do the same thing with words, too: we collect them in long strings. Every new instance of "bird" that we encounter — whether a bird we see in the real world, drawn in the pages of a book, or written in English or Chinese or whatever — adds to and transforms and is transformed by all our previous experiences of "bird". The speaker/observer here is taking an individual instance of bird and *by careful observation *("feather by feather") abstracting it until all she has is the idea, the image from her imaginarium. She's venturing inside herself *through the portal of the world, through the world as portal*.
I make a whole life out of it: everywhere I am, its sense of loitering lights on my shoulder.
She abstracts an ethics from that idea, a way of life. It's not a bird that "lights" on her shoulder, but the idea of the bird, the ethics implied by the bird. And what ethical stance does the bird exemplify? Well, it's the most important word in the poem, of course: "loitering." Loiter is such an amazing word. Whenever I hear "loiter" I think of Walt Whitman. Here's 'Beginning my Studies':
BEGINNING my studies, the first step pleas’d me so much, The mere fact, consciousness—these forms—the power of motion, The least insect or animal—the senses—eyesight—love; The first step, I say, aw’d me and pleas’d me so much, I have hardly gone, and hardly wish’d to go, any farther, But stop and loiter all the time, to sing it in extatic songs.
And I think of this story from Henry David Thoreau's *Walden*:
I once had a sparrow alight upon my shoulder for a moment, while I was hoeing in a village garden, and I felt that I was more distinguished by that circumstance that I should have been by any epaulet I could have worn.
And of course I think of these words from the Gospel of Matthew:
Look at the birds of the air; they do not sow or reap or store away in barns, and yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not much more valuable than they? Can any one of you by worrying add a single hour to your life? "And why do you worry about clothes? See how the flowers of the field grow. They do not labor or spin. Yet I tell you that not even Solomon in all his splendor was dressed like one of these.
The poetic life, the "whole life" that the observer made out of this abstracting process, is one of ease and loitering. Not that there aren't trials and troubles; but the whole life comes through being at ease *within oneself*. The bird alighting on your shoulder is a sign that you are at peace. It's a sign of *grace*, take that word however you will. And a bird may not alight on your shoulder every day, but "its sense of loitering" can. There's so much I'm not saying. There's no time. Maybe tomorrow's poem will bring out more. Until tomorrow, all. Tweet

entry.title: 'Blood Soup' by Mary Ruefle
entry.content:
I want to pick up again with reading Mary Ruefle this week. I read the poem 'Bavaria' a couple weeks ago, which I found on  the Poetry Foundation website, so let's keep moving through those poems and look at 'Blood Soup'.
The last time I saw father alive he was using a black umbrella, closed, to beat off some pigeons hanging outside the marble portals of a museum. We were visitors, walking very slowly, so father could stoop and examine everything. We had not been in the museum, but were resting on its steps. We saw it all—the fountains, the statues, the parks and the post office. Cities are made of such things. Once we encountered a wedding coming out of the cathedral and were caught in a shower of rice; as the bride flicked her veiled head father licked his little finger and in this way saved a grain. On the next block he announced he was going to heaven. But first let’s go back to the hotel and rest, he said: I want my mint. Those were practically his last words. And what did I want more than anything in the world? Probably the ancient Polish recipe for blood soup, which was finally told to me in an empty deli in a deserted mill town in western Massachusetts by the owner’s mother, who was alone one day when I burst in and demanded a bowl. But, she said, lacing her fingers around a jar of morello cherries, it requires one cup of new blood drawn from the goose whose neck you’ve just wrung to put in the pot, and where in these days can I find anything as fresh as that? I had lost track of my life before, but nothing prepared me for the onslaught of wayfarer’s bliss when she continued to list, one by one, the impossible ingredients I needed to live. We sat at the greasy table far into the night, while snow fell on the locked doors of the church next door, dedicated to St. Stanislas, which was rumored to be beautiful inside, and contain the remains of his beloved head. —From the Poetry Foundation website. They have a footnote: "Mary Ruefle, 'Blood Soup' from *Among the Musk Ox People: Poems*. Copyright © 2002 by Mary Ruefle. Reprinted by permission of Carnegie Mellon University Press."
I love the narrative quality of the poem. It reminds me of that poem by Noelle Kocot that I read a couple months ago. There are two stories, and their connection isn't forced. I love that style; plain language, nothing baroque, working on a principle of juxtaposition. Take two separate things, put them in the same container, and let the imagination play: it's like a Joseph Cornell box. Images echo eachother. There are two churches: there's the "wedding coming out of the cathedral" in the middle and "the church next door / dedicated to St. Stanislaus" toward the end. There's the shower of rice outside the cathedral, and there's the snow falling outside the church. Then notice this one: in the middle we have "as the bride / flicked her veiled head father licked his little finger" and at the end we have "the remains of his beloved head." All of these tie back to the museum that the speaker hadn't been inside, she and her father on the steps. They're always outside of things, always just getting caught up in somebody else's celebration, always hearing rumors of the thing without seeing the thing itself, always playing the role of the "visitor" or the "wayfarer". It's almost like we're hearing the same story several times over. There's such a fairy tale quality to the second half of the poem. The speaker "burst / in and demanded a bowl" of blood soup. That's such a strangely *active *way of putting it. It's heroic. But the ingredients are impossible. "[W]here *in these days* can I find / anything as fresh as that?" (emphasis my own). That gesture of tiredness, exhaustion, displacement from a more magical time, tells us so much about the speaker. It's such an amazing passage. "I had lost track of my life / before, but nothing prepared me for the onslaught of / wayfarer's bliss when she continued to list, one / by one, the impossible ingredients I needed to live." The old polish woman, the deli owner's mother, might as well be a witch at her cauldron. She demands blood. Is the speaker, by recalling the last moments of her father's life, giving the witch the demanded blood? Is she wringing the neck of the goose, just as St. Stanislas has had his head removed, just as she is making her father die all over again? I might be over-reaching. But that's all part of it, right? I'll be back with more Mary Ruefle tomorrow. Until then!

entry.title: Emily Dickinson, #70: "So bashful when I spied her"
entry.content:
Let's cap off the week with one last Emily Dickinson poem. Here's #70: "So bashful when I spied her" —
SO bashful when I spied her,
So pretty, so ashamed!
So hidden in her leaflets,
Lest anybody find;

So breathless till I passed her,
So helpless when I turned
And bore her, struggling, blushing,
Her simple haunts beyond!

For whom I robbed the dingle,
For whom betrayed the dell,
Many will doubtless ask me,
But I shall never tell!
In the last Dickinson poem I looked at, there speaker struggled toward freedom. Here, the speaker is carrying someone off — unwillingly, it seems. Rapture is a very safe way of putting it.

The first two stanzas strike me as fairly straightforward narrative. A man spies a bookish girl (bookish because she's "hidden in her leaflets") or possibly an animal or a girl hiding in the woods (the leaflets, after all, might just be small leaves). The riddle begins in the third stanza. What does the speaker mean "for whom"? I can understand that by taking the girl/animal the speaker has "robbed the dingle" and "betrayed the dell", but why would I ask "for whom" he did it? He did it for himself, didn't he? What other hand could have been at work?

I want to allegorize this poem to make some sense of it, but I don't know how. I mentioned in reading #26 that I found it interesting that there was no loss. I wanted to read sacrifice into the poetry, but really there was just presentation. The living world was preserved by poetry, allowed to live as it wanted to. That's definitely not the case in this poem. The speaker comes in and take, disrupts, causes fear and panic and — blushing. Rapture is a very, very safe way of putting it. Is this poem about poetry? Is it about sex? Is it about religion? Is it about mortality? I'll need time to think about it.

Have a great weekend, all.

entry.title: 'Bavaria' by Mary Ruefle
entry.content:
I want to take a short break from reading Emily Dickinson (here and here) to look at a short poem by Mary Ruefle. Among many other things, I've been reading this really great special feature on Ruefle's poetry in issue 4 of Music & Literature. It features eight of her poems, which I've loved, alongside essays about her and a really interesting interview with her (you can read a little of that interview here). I don't want to get overexcited. In a piece I wrote about April Bernard I gushed that she was one of the great discoveries I would look back on for a lifetime. Well... I pulled a few of her books from the library and I just wasn't into them. I still love that poem, 'Blossom', but the rest of her stuff just doesn't do it for me. For me to be a fan of a poet, I've got to enjoy at least half of their work. I definitely wasn't hitting that number in my reading of April Bernard. Not because she's bad, not because she does anything wrong: I just don't enjoy it. So I'll wait and see about Mary Ruefle, but right now I'm getting good signs from the little I've read. Anyway, here's 'Bavaria', a poem freely available through the Poetry Foundation's page for Mary Ruefle (the image above is from their site, as well).
The mountain skies were clear
except for the umlaut of a cloud
over the village.
The little girl wore yellow gloves.
She looked in the peephole and saw
a stack of unused marionettes.
Yet, she wondered.
This poem reminds me so much of 'An Impression' by Gu Cheng, both in its form and its content. Both poems use children as a sort of emblem of innocence and possibility. Both poems are small, painting an enchanting picture in just a few strokes. And there's a similar sense of motion as our eye descends from the sky to the cloud to the little girl to her gloves, and from there we see through her eyes to the marionettes, and then we enter her thoughts for that last little puzzle of a line. I love coherence. There are some people who see the world as terribly ordered and exact, and they make poetry into a wild place where things can break loose. I see the world as wild and disordered, and I want poetry that allows things to make sense. Order, progression, meaning, rhythm, music: these resonate with me. OK, I must be going. Until tomorrow, friends.

entry.title: Emily Dickinson, #144: "I never hear the word 'escape'"
entry.content:
Today I want to look at another Dickinson poem, but first I need to do a little shameless self-promotion.  I've been serving for the last couple months as an Assistant Managing Editor at *Asymptote*. The first issue I've helped produce is now live. Please do check it out; there's a great feature of new poetry in English by authors like Mary Jo Bang, Michael Farrell, and Genya Turovskaya. Go ahead and check it out! So back to Emily Dickinson. I'm reading these poems in the order they appear in a little Dover Thrift Edition of Dickinson's poems. If you're on a budget and looking to start a good collection of English and American poetry, check out Dover Thrift Editions. OK, without further ado, here's #144. Like yesterday's poem, it's a ballad stanza, though this time the rhymes are more interesting.
I never hear the word “Escape” Without a quicker blood, A sudden expectation – A flying attitude! I never hear of prisons broad By soldiers battered down, But I tug childish at my bars Only to fail again!
I don't want to over-read based on what little I know of Dickinson's life. There's a popular image of Dickinson as a shut-in. I don't know anything about Dickinson, really. I understand from Wikipedia (our paper of record) that her mother became ill in the 1850s, and it fell on the twenty-something Emily to stay home and take care of her. She wrote the bulk of her poems — the eight hundred poems that would not be published until after her death — from 1858 to 1863. It wasn't until 1867 that she really drew into real seclusion. (And really, don't trust these dates; there are contradictory dates even in the same Wiki article. <Sigh>) And I don't want to throw in too much historical speculation, either. Slavery is of course a hot issue at the time she is writing. And she's writing post-1848, so the spirit of revolution is in the air and in the newspapers. And she admired the writing of Ralph Waldo Emerson, for whom liberation and non-conformity were a major themes. These facts are relevant, even though I can't use them definitively, but for now let's just look at the poetry. The thing that most stands out to me, especially after yesterday's poem, is that the rhyme is much more slanted. First, "blood" is force to rhyme with "attitude", which is a bit of a stretch but not asking too much. In the second stanza, though, the expected rhyme actually breaks with "down" - "again". Here's the interesting part: Dickinson *does *break the form that holds her (by breaking the rhyme scheme) even as she asserts that she has *failed* to break her childish bars. Poetry, then, is not the same as her childish bars. She can break the poetry, but that won't free her. I couldn't say for sure, but I think *poetry is her way out* (out of herself? out of her home/family? out of her town? out of her culture?). She is exploring the space between her domestic/poetic world and the larger/apoetic world, as she does in one of her most famous poems:
I never saw a moor; I never saw the sea, Yet know I how the heather looks And what a billow be. I never spoke with God, Nor visited in heaven. Yet certain am I of the spot As if the checks were given.
The wider world comes to her *as language*. Language and poetry are her means of breaking free. *Words themselves — individual utterances and markings like "Escape" — are the liberating soldiers*. The freedom she acquires is, I think, more existential than political or social. I'll have to investigate that more tomorrow. I've sat on this post too long. Until tomorrow, all.

entry.title: Emily Dickinson, #26: 'It’s all I have to bring today"
entry.content:
For at least the next few days I just want to read some Emily Dickinson. There's something about reading Emily Dickinson and Walt Whitman and Wallace Stevens and William Carlos Williams and Robert Frost that feels like *coming home*. We had this book at home while I was growing up; the only poet in the collection that I never connected with was Langston Hughes. We also had this beast and I *really* never understood what it was about. So, Emily Dickinson. This is poem #26. It's two ballad stanzas — alternating lines of eight and six syllables with a rhyme ending the 2nd and 4th lines of each stanza.
It’s all I have to bring today— This, and my heart beside— This, and my heart, and all the fields— And all the meadows wide— Be sure you count—should I forget Some one the sum could tell— This, and my heart, and all the Bees Which in the Clover dwell. *(text copied from Poets.org)*
There's a lot to be said here. First of all there's that great start; it hits the ground running. "It's" has no referent. *What *is all she has to bring today? It has to be (doesn't it?) this very poem. Who is she bringing the poem to? And why? And does she bring something *every day*? The gift keeps growing, as though it were being coyly given, or as if it the giver were only becoming aware of the gift's full extent *in the act of giving*. The word Clover is interesting. Take out the L and you have 'Cover'; take out the C and you have 'lover'. Anything to that? Possibly, but I'm interested in just the plain sense. The Bees dwell in the clover, and they are being brought. The poet isn't taking them out of the Clover to bring them. She brings the Bees and their dwelling place. If that's how we read it, then we don't necessarily have to assume there's an act of violence in bringing her heart. The heart remains and dwells within the breast and yet is brought and given. But am I going too far in my reading? Why do I think these things are being given? They are merely being brought and presented. And why? *To be counted*. I got caught up in a scene from the New Testament.
Jesus sat down opposite the place where the offerings were put and watched the crowd putting their money into the temple treasury. Many rich people threw in large amounts. But a poor widow came and put in two very small copper coins, worth only a few cents. Calling his disciples to him, Jesus said, “Truly I tell you, this poor widow has put more into the treasury than all the others. They all gave out of their wealth; but she, out of her poverty, put in everything—all she had to live on.” — Mark 12: 41-44
Everything *counts*.* *If you have a talent, you have to give it, and God will remember. When Dickinson writes "Be sure you count" -- who is the "you"? The simplest answer is, of course, *you*. You, dear reader, are put into the position of God. The poet asks for your love; the poem is an offering. The field and the meadow and the bees in the clover are poetic things, the content of poetry, and with them come the poet's heart, the source of poetry, and the poem itself, the form. Using words like "sacrifice" presumes the wrong model of the poet/worshiper's interaction with the reader/God. This isn't about sacrifice; it's about *presentation*. Things are shown, whole and alive. From Christopher Smart's 'Jubilate Agno':
Let the Levites of the Lord take the Beavers of the brook alive into the Ark of the Testimony. 
The poet brings without giving away; the poet lets things live as they are, not in some new way inimical to the nature of the things presented. So the self and the world are put on display and remain intact; this is the beauty of 'this', the poem as such. There is vulnerability, but not *too much *vulnerability. It puts you, as the reader, in an interesting position. It demands a certain maturity from you, a certain gravity. As a thing to say to God -- well, it also puts some interesting demands on God. "Respect my individuality," it says. "Remember what I've done, because I'm busy living and am liable to forget." That forgetting is really *the most *interesting thing, isn't it? How strange it is. Why should the poet forget? But again I think of the New Testament.
“Then the King will say to those on his right, ‘Come, you who are blessed by my Father; take your inheritance, the kingdom prepared for you since the creation of the world. For I was hungry and you gave me something to eat, I was thirsty and you gave me something to drink, I was a stranger and you invited me in, I needed clothes and you clothed me, I was sick and you looked after me, I was in prison and you came to visit me.’ “Then the righteous will answer him, ‘Lord, when did we see you hungry and feed you, or thirsty and give you something to drink? When did we see you a stranger and invite you in, or needing clothes and clothe you? When did we see you sick or in prison and go to visit you?’ “The King will reply, ‘Truly I tell you, whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me.’" Matthew 25:34-40
The righteous forget the good they've done. Dickinson may have been wondering, as many do, how many poems should I write? Can a writer write too much? Should I write five hundred good poems and maybe five will be great, or should I spend my life crafting fifty perfect poems and maybe six will be great? She decides on *daily presentation*. She will say again and again, through poetry, to the world and for the world, *'Here I am'*. Too much to say, too much to say. I'll write on another Dickinson poem tomorrow. Much love, amigos. Tweet

entry.title: 'The X Man' by Kathryn Maris
entry.content:
Today and tomorrow I'd like to share a couple poems from the new issue of *Poetry*. Honestly, there wasn't much I was crazy about in this issue, but it's all about taking time to find the little things that stand out. Here's 'The X Man' by Kathryn Maris:
His superpower was that his testicles manufactured sperm with exclusively X chromosomes & that was ironic because not only was he a beast to women but his 40 baby girls grew up seeking men like the father they barely saw unless they went to his studio to be painted which wasn’t OK with their mothers who were not only jealous but guilty of giving birth to girls who were products of an X-chromosome-making monster & would soon suffer at the hands of other monsters with X- type sperm thereby assuring the continuation of suffering & meanwhile all the girls became writers who slouched from sitting at desks & being daughters & lovers of beasts.
Just take that first line and a half: "His superpower was that his testicles manufactured sperm / with exclusively X chromosomes". Quite an intro! There's a danger with a poem that opens with a bang that the whole thing will diffuse afterward, but Maris lets it build and unfold in stages, repeating the key phrases and adding new details a little at a time. What to do with those 40 baby girls who all became writers. Perhaps Maris is talking about one person's suffering but diluting it by treating it as a larger phenomenon. (Like in one of Thomas Mann's novels there's a main character who is dying of typhoid, and rather than go into great detail about his sickness Mann talks about the sickness generally, like he was writing a textbook: it's a way of indicating that the subject was too painful even for the narrator, a way of talking *around *what happened because that's all one can handle.) Perhaps it's a way of talking about writers in general, about their self-destructive tendencies. It's like an etiological myth: here's the story of why the daughters of shitty artist guys tragically tend to become artists who love shitty artist guys, "thereby assuring the continuation of suffering." Oy; that's all I've got for today. Gotta get some work done because, you know, that's what I do. Until tomorrow, y'all. Tweet

entry.title: 'Anecdote for Fathers' by William Wordsworth
entry.content:
Last night I wrote a long, cynical tirade against National Poetry Day, but then decided not to post it. I was about to start summing it up for you just now; my fingers hovered over the keyboard, ready to rehash all that savagery. But who needs that, right? Writing about poetry just isn't making me happy like it should. I've demanded too much of myself lately and I haven't given myself anything in return, or I haven't allowed myself to take any of the things that are being offered in return. I just read this checklist of signs you're burning out from overwork and it was like "Check... check... check...." I put a lot of pressure on myself and refuse to be satisfied with anything I do. I feel, sometimes, that the only satisfaction I get as a writer (as you're about to see in the poem below) is the partial relief that comes from just having said *anything*. I put myself into high pressure situations so that I can *force myself *to say *something*. Is that bad, or is that how it's supposed to work? I really don't know. Here's a poem about pressure and the imagination. Like everything Wordsworth wrote, it's more complex than it looks at first. Anyway, here's 'Anecdote for Fathers':
I have a boy of five years old; His face is fair and fresh to see; His limbs are cast in beauty's mould, And dearly he loves me. One morn we strolled on our dry walk, Our quiet home all full in view, And held such intermitted talk As we are wont to do. My thoughts on former pleasures ran; I thought of Kilve's delightful shore, Our pleasant home when spring began, A long, long year before. A day it was when I could bear Some fond regrets to entertain; With so much happiness to spare, I could not feel a pain. The green earth echoed to the feet Of lambs that bounded through the glade, From shade to sunshine, and as fleet From sunshine back to shade. Birds warbled round me -- and each trace of inward sadness had its charm; Kilve, thought I, was a favored place, And so is Liswyn farm. My boy beside me tripped, so slim And graceful in his rustic dress! And, as we talked, I questioned him, In very idleness. "Now tell me, had you rather be," I said, and took him by the arm, "On Kilve's smooth shore, by the green sea, Or here at Liswyn farm?" In careless mood he looked at me, While still I held him by the arm, And said, "At Kilve I'd rather be Than here at Liswyn farm." "Now, little Edward, say why so: My little Edward, tell me why." -- "I cannot tell, I do not know." -- "Why, this is strange," said I; "For, here are woods, hills smooth and warm: There surely must some reason be Why you would change sweet Liswyn farm For Kilve by the green sea." At this, my boy hung down his head, He blushed with shame, nor made reply; And three times to the child I said, "Why, Edward, tell me why?" His head he raised -- there was in sight, It caught his eye, he saw it plain -- Upon the house-top, glittering bright, A broad and gilded vane. Then did the boy his tongue unlock, And eased his mind with this reply: "At Kilve there was no weather-cock; And that's the reason why." O dearest, dearest boy! my heart For better lore would seldom yearn, Could I but teach the hundredth part Of what from thee I learn.
We're all the little boy, Edward. We try to patch together a sense of the world using what little we can remember or perceive, because someone (in this case, our father) is calling us to account. "Why, Edward, tell me why?" His father is forcing him to put everything in terms of words, so Edward looks around and scrapes together an explanation from the first thing he sees. That explanation "eased his mind." We are terribly contingent creatures. And yet — the substance of art is the memory and perception of just such contingencies. Giving ourselves up to these contingencies, participating fully in them, *actually does make us happy*. This afternoon I went out for a walk through Boston Common and the Public Garden during my lunch break. One of the trees in the park had a placard nailed into it; I had never noticed that some of  the trees were labelled. The placard told me that it was a Belgian elm. I noticed the color and texture of the bark, the shape of its leaves. I looked up Belgian elms on my phone to see what I could learn about them, and while I was at it I looked up a couple other trees I saw nearby. Then, as I continued to walk, I noticed details as I could not have noticed before. This path was shaded by a canopy of Belgian elms. On that next turn there was a yellow oak leaf fallen on the path, the first of many. *I noticed more of the world through language, and it made me glad*. So perhaps Wordsworth's poem isn't nearly as sneering as I've always interpreted it to be. Perhaps this learning how to turn things into words is a joy we have to be trained to experience, like the joy of playing a musical instrument or speaking a second language. By expanding our vocabulary, by strengthening our connection to the world through words, we become more in control of ourselves and our situation. That's the worst part of being overworked: everything feels out of control. When I'm really stressed out, all I can think of is *freedom from*. Freedom from work, freedom from responsibilities, freedom from certain people and places. But what I really need to focus on is *the freedom to*.  The freedom to read and write and appreciate nature and the city and the people I love, and not just passively but actively putting my full self into those acts. Maybe *in that *there is satisfaction. Until next week, all.

entry.title: Robert Pinsky's Voice
entry.content:
This past Thursday I attended a poetry reading to commemorate the anniversary of Robert Pinsky's *Singing School. *Pinsky was there, of course, along with Dan Chiasson, Karl Kirchwey, Luisa Caycedo-Kimura, and Ha Jin. Each poet read a poem or two out of *Singing School*, an anthology that includes the poems Pinsky has considered essential to his education as a writer and reader of poetry. There's a lot of 16th century and 17th century English lyric, which I love, especially Wyatt and Raleigh and Herrick and Lovelace. And there's a lot of 20th century poetry, too, including Frank O'Hara, Elizabeth Bishop, and May Swenson. And there's a lot of everything in between. It's a great little book — *Singing School*, check it out. * *Reading through the book over the last couple days I've been amazed by how similar my own taste is to Pinsky's. I kept saying to myself, "I wish this book had poem X," and then I'd turn the page and there it would be. We have a taste for musicality. Poems that aren't musical in some way just can't hold my attention. Not that they have to be bouncing up and down with ABAB rhymes, but I like there to be some push forward, a rhythm that pulls you into a groove, a distinct mood that tells you whether you should be yelling or whispering or reading in an English or an American accent. If a poem isn't going to have that, I want it to be very short, like Ezra Pound's "In a Station of the Metro" . With that taste for music comes a sort of theatricality. Robert Pinsky, if you haven't seen him before, is a very theatrical reader. He has a powerful voice that he clearly enjoys, like a musician enjoys his instrument. I've probably shared this before, but here's Pinsky on the Colbert Report.
The Colbert Report Get More: Daily Show Full Episodes,Indecision Political Humor,The Colbert Report on Facebook
You might think that's a bit hammy; I think I would have thought so only a few years ago. But now I think that's in keeping with things I've already said here on the blog. Reading poetry is about *you*. You're getting to know poetry better, yes, and yes it makes you more sensitive to other people and points of view, but the main point of reading poetry (or contemplating *anything*, really) is that it helps you come to terms with yourself. Part of coming to terms with yourself is learning to enjoy yourself: your mind, your body, your voice. So reading poems — slowly, aloud, with full commitment to the thought and the feeling — means you get to be a bit of a philosopher, a dancer, an actor. You get to do more and be more. Pick up *Singing School *— it's a good place to start. A quick note of gratitude: Ha Jin read one of my favorite poems by Yeats — "Adam's Curse" — and really made me see it in a new way. I especially love that he pointed out this little fact: the protagonist is talking about how difficult it is to write a poem and then remarks:
Yet if it does not seem a moment’s thought,   
Our stitching and unstitching has been naught.   
Now "stitching and unstitching" is of course a reference to sewing, which is an interesting analogy to writing poetry, but it also subtly alludes to the Ancient Greek word *stichos,* meaning a line of verse. (I talked a little about the *stichos *in this post.) But yeah — multilingual puns! I do eat that stuff up. Until tomorrow, all. Tweet

entry.title: W.S. Merwin's The Moon Before Morning (Book Review Week, 4/4)
entry.content:
We're going to end with four posts about W.S. Merwin's *The Moon Before Midnight* rather than five. Why? Really it's this: yesterday I found a little time to slow down and relax, and I took it. I've been too stressed out lately. I'm basically working my day job, a medium-sized job on the side, a smaller job on the side, and writing this blog. And now I've been asked to do another blog for a much more demanding audience. It's crazy. It's fun, and fulfilling, and makes me more hopeful for my future than I've been in quite a while, but it's crazy.  But enough about me. Let's get back to Merwin. I want to talk briefly about form. Looking at the poem 'Homecoming' on Wednesday, I stressed the poem's amorphous quality, and how we seemed to be allowed to read both backward and forward in a way that allowed us to experience the subjective aspects of time even while feeling the irresistible forward motion of decay/desire. OK, sure: amorphous-ness. But there was some form to it, wasn't there? Divide it into four-line groups. Look how they begin: "Once ... I looked ... and saw ... long curving wings hardly moving ... but home now arriving." The poem can be broken into logical units; it's important that it isn't, but it's also important that it can be. So what other forms does Merwin use in *The Moon Before Morning*, and how does he use those forms, and how does he resist other forms? The second poem is a lovely sort of haiku, though it doesn't follow the normal metrical rules of haiku. I'll go ahead and share that one since it's so — wow.
Rain through the morning and in the long pool a toad singing happiness old as water — "By the Front Door", W.S. Merwin, *The Moon Before Morning*, Copper Canyon Press, ©2014, p.6
Just really quickly: whenever you notice somebody singing or playing music in a poem, especially if it's toward the beginning of a long poem or the beginning of a collection, the poet is probably talking about her- or himself as a poet. It's a very *meta *gesture. Even the title feels meta — how can "By the Front Door" not be a sly reference to the beginning of the book, just as "Homecoming" was? It's a common gesture. Virgil did it. Dante did it. John Berryman did it. A million poets have done it. Merwin's doing it here. Merwin is the toad; the toad is Merwin. He welcomes the comparison. The littleness of the poet in the poem is matched by the unassuming littleness of the poem itself. And isn't the toad teaching us, in this little poem where we have to add such heavy pauses at the end of each line, exactly how we ought to be reading these poems, and this book as a whole? For me, the shorter poems are the best ones in this book. When Merwin uses longer forms he becomes more generic, more common. But as a whole, the book is a strong one. It's one of the rare books that I'll actually go out and buy a copy of, because I would be glad and proud to have it on my shelf. I have to start wrapping this up. Isn't this ridiculous? I've written so many words about *The Moon Before Morning* now and yet I still feel like I haven't said anything at all. I've learned from the process — some of the things I've written here so matter-of-factly I only *learned through the act of writing *them. Writing here on this blog is a very associative process for me; it's so easygoing that I feel guilty about it sometimes. But whatever. I'm not an academic. This isn't for a literary journal. This is a fun place. A relaxed place. It's good I took that day off, because I needed a little down-time to remember that. I look forward to coming back next week.
Have a good weekend, all.

entry.title: W.S. Merwin's The Moon Before Morning (Book Review Week, 3/4)
entry.content:
*Stichic integrity*. I learned this term from Brian Turner, author of two excellent poetry collections and a new memoir. If you Google *stichic integrity *you'll find this article by Turner, in which he describes how, when writing and editing his own poetry, "each line [*needs*] to be considered in isolation for its own strengths and weaknesses." Each line needs to stand on its own two feet. (Fun fact: *stichos* — "stich" pronounced like "stick", "os" as in "cost" —,* *is Ancient Greek for "line" or "verse.") But this doesn't mean that a line  has to be a single sentence or idea. This confused me for a long time. A line's strength can come from playful ambiguity. Here's Turner from that same article:
I like to call some lines ‘wrap-around’ lines. It’s when two phrases cohabitate on the same line. For example: “on a sidewalk, a blistered hand’s gold ring.” That line, for me, has stichic integrity because the two parts play off of each other. The *blistered hand’s gold ring* can be read as existing *on the sidewalk*. In the very next line after that (*still shining, while a medic, Doc Lopez*) Doc Lopez can be read to be still *shining*. Basically, there is an interplay of meaning, an exchange of relationships, built into the positioning of phrases themselves.
By placing the tail of one phrase onto the same line as the head of another phrase, Turner allows their meanings to intermingle. This preserves the logical sense (we can follow natural English sentences rather than puzzle over fragments) while allowing room for the reader's imagination to play. It slows you down and rewards imaginative reading. W.S. Merwin accomplishes something similar throughout *The Moon Before Morning* by giving you just the lines with no guides or cues for how he wants you to read them. There's no punctuation to guide your breath; often there are no stanza breaks to show you where one section ends and another begins. It's just the lines on the page and you. I'll give you a brief example from the first poem in the collection, "Homecoming":
Once only when the summer was nearly over and my own hair had been white as the day's clouds
Let's stop right there. The first line is a little bumpy "Once only when": we might reasonably expect a small pause after "only". Then take the two first two lines together: "Once only when the summer / was nearly over and my own." This could work; that "the summer was... my own" is a little heavy-handedly poetic, but it could work. He could begin the story now. But the "my own" carries over to "hair" and we see that the thought spills over the line. We thought it was over, but it kept going. Does that mean the "summer was ... my own" reading is invalid now? *Logically, yes; Imaginatively, no*. Now it's richer, more ambiguous, more meaningful thanks to its arbitrary positioning between "summer" and "hair". Let's try again:
Once only when the summer was nearly over and my own hair had been white as the day's clouds for more years than I was counting I looked across the garden at evening
Just look at that fourth line and how well it fits with both the line-and-a-half that precede it ("my own hair had been white as the day's clouds // for more years than I was counting") and the line that follows it ("for more years than I was counting // I looked across the garden at evening"). Time flows in many directions; the arrangement of lines controls it, but only just. Notice also that a new section has begun with "I looked across the garden." There's a heavy pause after "counting," the first really heavy pause of the poem. What a perfect word to pause at, especially in the first poem of the collection when we're just learning how the poet counts his lines! The first four lines have been establishing setting and character, and with the fifth line we begin the action. Here's the rest of the poem:
Once only when the summer was nearly over and my own hair had been white as the day's clouds for more years than I was counting I looked across the garden at evening Paula was still weeding around flowers that open after dark and I looked up at the clear sky and saw the new moon and at that moment from behind me a band of dark birds and then another after it flying in silence long curving wings hardly moving the plovers just in from the sea and the flight clear from Alaska half their weight gone to get them home but home now arriving without a sound as it rose to meet them "Homecoming", W.S. Merwin, *The Moon Before Morning*, Copper Canyon Press, ©2014, p.5
You sense the pauses now? The way each line both does and doesn't flow into the one after it? Think about it in terms of stichic integrity. You become *responsible *for the poem, and this responsibility slows you down and makes you experience the peaceful scene the poetic speaker himself is witnessing. I love the heavy pause after "silence" in the twelfth line, and the powerful slowness of the line that follows: "long curving wings hardly moving". And then "moving" takes or seems to take "the plovers" as its direct object, so we know we can't stop. "Hardly moving", yes, but moving all the same. The thought settles into a shape (a line) and then — by the pressure of its desire to keep going — breaks itself. Masterful. Isn't that the word? Until tomorrow, all.

entry.title: W.S. Merwin's The Moon Before Morning (Book Review Week, 1/4)
entry.content:
Rather than complain that Twitter posts and many blogs are too cursory and too canonical in their coverage of poetry, I'm going to counteract the offending trendings and write a slower, more concentrated review about a new book of poetry: W.S. Merwin's *The Moon Before Morning*. Over the course of this week I want to focus on a few key aspects of Merwin's newest book, including his renunciation of punctuation, the arrangement of the poems within the book, and the poetic forms he chooses. (Edit: here are links to parts two, three, and four.) But today I just want to gather some information about Merwin into one place. You might have noticed that many of my readings lean toward the New Critical school of thinking: I read the poem as a self-contained unit, rarely going into a poem's or poet's historical context in a way that might inform my reading of a text. But that, I'm afraid, is more out of laziness than ideology. I don't believe in the great Tradition, but at times I read like someone who does. Let's counteract that. *The Moon Before Morning *is Merwin's fourteenth book with Copper Canyon Press; he's been publishing with them for just over twenty years now, though much more prolifically in the last decade. I like Copper Canyon's two paragraph bio, so here it is:
W.S. Merwin was born in New York City in 1927 and was United States Poet Laureate in 2010. He graduated from Princeton University in 1948, where he studied with John Berryman and R.P. Blackmur. From 1949 to 1951 he worked as a tutor in France, Mallorca, and Portugal; for several years afterward he made the greater part of his living by translating from French, Spanish, Latin, and Portuguese. His first book of poetry, *A Mask for Janus* (1952) was selected by W.H. Auden for the Yale Younger Poets Prize. Since then, Merwin has authored dozens of books of poetry and prose. His work embodies a bold commitment to experimentation and transformation rooted in the moral necessity of bearing witness, and is influenced by his profoundly environmentalist, pacifist, and anti–imperialist beliefs. He has won many awards, as well as fellowships from the Rockefeller and the Guggenheim Foundations and the National Endowment for the Arts. W.S. Merwin has lived in Hawaii since 1976. — taken whole-cloth from Copper Canyon's website
That last, tiny sentence is terribly important. Merwin and his poetry are inextricably bound to Hawaii. He isn't just a poet who writes about the environment; he's a committed environmentalist who practices what he preaches on his three acre palm plantation on Maui. From the Wall Street Journal's profile:
Mr. Merwin's path to his palm forest was an indirect one. The son of a Presbyterian minister, he was born in New York, lived in France and then came to Hawaii in the 1970s to study Zen Buddhism. Not long after arriving, he heard of a small piece of land near the coast with a small cabin, the place where three native Hawaiian activists had hidden after defying the U.S. Navy and occupying the bombed island of Kaho`olawe. ... Using his small inheritance, he spent $60,000 or so for just over three acres in 1977. With little money left, he drew plans for the house, and recruited friends and local craftsmen to help him build it. ...
At first, Mr. Merwin said, he had somewhat "naively" hoped to restore a rain forest with native plants. But the soil was so leached and the conditions so dry and wind-swept that he found the only ones that thrived were Hawaiian Pritchardias, a type of palm. He estimates he now has more than 850 different species of palms on the property, including a few he's saved from extinction, such as Hyophorbe indica from Reunion Island.
In 2010, shortly before Mr. Merwin agreed to become the poet laureate, the couple created the Merwin Conservancy, preserving the home and the palm forest and receiving nonprofit status as a retreat for writers and botanists. "William has created one of the greatest palm collections in the world," said Charles R. "Chipper" Wichman, director of the National Tropical Botanical Gardens. "It is amazing." — Julia Flynn Siler, the Wall Street Journal, March 25, 2011
Merwin's piece of Hawaii and its progression over the decades is the subject of most of* The Moon Before Morning*. There is a calm and a magic to the poems that makes you understand* *why Merwin fell in love with the place. Nothing is more important than the place, including time. This loyalty to place enforces a powerful simplicity and economy. Like Ezra Pound, Merwin is a man who *knows* poetry and language, yet we see hardly any of it here. He refuses to wear his learning on his sleeve. *Merwin's withdrawal from the West and the East to an island between is perfectly emblematic of his poetry*. It is a withdrawal into Nature, into the self, into the quiet things that persist when no one else is watching or listening, into things that are always true. I'm a lifelong reader of Henry David Thoreau's *Walden*; is it any wonder this collection appeals to me? More tomorrow.  Tweet

entry.title: Writing vs. Writing Well
entry.content:
Between the beautiful sunlit hours wasted staring at thousands of pages of HTML and the rare opportunities for rest each night that I've traded in for Google chat meetings with colleagues across the globe, I got some good news.
Unfortunately I can't share the full details yet. There's a contract to be signed, and I want it to be good and binding before I say word one. I respect contracts with an intensity normally reserved for cartoon devils.
What I can tell you is that this coming change will give my writing a significantly larger reach. It's not like writing for one of the major newspapers, but it's big. It's the first big step for me after some hard falls from high places, falls that I thought had knocked the wind completely out of me.
To be honest, the prospect of writing more regularly and for a larger audience makes me nervous. On this blog I do minimal editing, and I take comfort in my freedom to not make a secret of this stream-of-consciousness approach. But ultimately I'm unhappy with most of my pieces here. Many of them I wouldn't dare put into my professional portfolio. (Note to self: start putting together a professional portfolio.)
But even when I do put some polish on my writing, I'm often dissatisfied with those pieces a few days after publication. Everything comes out too grand, too oratorical, too much like a sermon. In most of my writing there's a touch of the nineteenth century writers who first inspired me — Emerson, Thoreau, Whitman — which is fine on occasion but not in a regular column potentially read by hundreds, maybe thousands.
In this new phase of my career, I need to write more deliberately, carefully weighing each sentence for tone and rhythm and register. I want to more consciously imitate writers with mature critical voices. James Wood comes to mind. John Jeremiah Sullivan, too. Helen Vendler. John Updike. Michael Chabon. Jonathan Franzen. If I don't assure myself that I've done everything I possibly could to make the writing just how I wanted it to be, I will lose my nerve. If I'm ever going to become the writer I've always wanted to be — the person I've always wanted to be — I have to do it now.
Now I can't tell if I'm nervous or excited. Until next week, all.

entry.title: 'The Fall of Rome' by W.H. Auden
entry.content:
Yesterday, after burritos, my wife and I went to the library. She hunted for history books while I scoured the American poetry section. I checked out several collections of John Ashbery, John Berryman, and Robert Lowell, and critical works on all three. We carted everything back to our apartment and I started to read, which led to an important re-revelation. I just don't *get *a lot of American poetry. I think that, with rare and important exceptions, Dickinson and Whitman are the last American poets I feel any kind of significant connection with. Eliot was very important to me when I was younger, but I think now that that had a lot to do with his adopted Britishness. From January to May of this year, my wife and I lived in England. I took time to read British poetry, and confirmed for myself that I really do love their style — musical, rhetorical, occasional. But I felt conflicted, as an American abroad. Everywhere I went my speaking voice felt conspicuous, embarrassing even. I had to second guess my words at every turn. It made me want to be back home, and it made me want to learn how to speak and write more like an American. But here, too, I feel conflicted, because I don't particularly *like *the method or subject matter of many American poets. Or I might even say, *most *American poets.So finding my place as a reader and a writer is a complex negotiation of native and foreign voices. It's a struggle to be myself and to be my ideal, to be American and to be British (understanding that 'British' may be a much more complicated term *very *soon). So here's a poem I love by one of my key British influences, W.H. Auden. Auden is one of those poets that I can go back and read again and again. Not all of the poems are beloved poems, of course, but the ones that are just *are *poetry for me. I won't go on. Here's 'The Fall of Rome':
The piers are pummelled by the waves; In a lonely field the rain Lashes an abandoned train; Outlaws fill the mountain caves. Fantastic grow the evening gowns; Agents of the Fisc pursue Absconding tax-defaulters through The sewers of provincial towns. Private rites of magic send The temple prostitutes to sleep; All the literati keep An imaginary friend. Cerebrotonic Cato may Extol the Ancient Disciplines, But the muscle-bound Marines Mutiny for food and pay. Caesar’s double-bed is warm As an unimportant clerk Writes *I DO NOT LIKE MY WORK* On a pink official form. Unendowed with wealth or pity, Little birds with scarlet legs, Sitting on their speckled eggs, Eye each flu-infected city. Altogether elsewhere, vast Herds of reindeer move across Miles and miles of golden moss, Silently and very fast.
I love this poem's combination of tones and registers. There's a sense that the past and present and future are blended. Ancient Rome exists alongside contemporary England and the U.S. Humor is juxtaposed with a bleak realism. In just twenty-eight rhymed lines, Auden captures so much of contemporary life and addresses so many important concepts: government, bureaucracy, militarism, conservatism, philistinism, etc. Those last eight lines are so interesting. You could lift them and I think the poem would work as well as a 'fall of Rome' poem. They add something, though: a sense of menace. The reindeer, to me, communicate the coming of the barbarians. They stand in for the vast sea of humanity, the mob as herd, pure flesh. On the right scale, man is just one microbe like any of the others. But they are also the earth, Nature with a capital N, the parts of the world that won't relent to civilization, no matter how tirelessly and disastrously man (Rome) tries. This, from the right point of view, is a good thing. Though from the Roman's point of view, I'm afraid it's quite bad. That will do it for me today. Until tomorrow, friends. Tweet

entry.title: Recalculating: further thoughts on a poem by Gary Fincke
entry.content:
I've been thinking more about my post yesterday regarding Gary Fincke's 'Calculations: A Love Poem'. I hate that uneasy feeling after posting something. It's like having a pebble in your shoe, only it's an idea pebble in some kind of mental shoe, whatever that might mean. There are two follow-up points I want to make, and then I'll call it a day. 1) I was pretty positive about the poem yesterday. I mean, I was fairly glowing about the qualities of the poem that I enjoyed. That was misleading. Even though I think the poem *accomplished *something interesting, that doesn't mean I'm 100% on board with the poem as a whole. I don't think it's aesthetically as-good-as-it-gets. Normally I don't engage in negative criticism, but in this case I think it's fair as long as I point out that I'm not trying to change Fincke's poem or Fincke as a poet or come down on his work in any kind of universalizing "This is Bad!" kind of way. I'm not trying to convince you that you shouldn't read Fincke. *I'm just trying to understand my own preferences and prejudices as a reader and a writer*. With that caveat in mind I think it's fair to approach the poem *as my own *and ask, *What do I want to change? What would I have done differently?* It's quite prosy, which I'm not wild about. I feel like the structure is arbitrary; the form doesn't comment on the content and vice versa. I'm a bit of an Aristotelian. I always end up thinking in terms of hylomorphism — in other words, I see *essence *as a marriage of *form *and *matter*. As Wordsworth might put it, poetry "takes its origin from emotion *[i.e. matter]* recollected in tranquility *[i.e. form]*." So I'm kind of a formalist, not because I'm conservative but because I think shapes and patterns and sing-song qualities are just plain fun. It's all about pleasure. I'm a formal hedonist. It also feels — I don't know how to say this — *minor*. Like, I understand that it's a love poem because he says so, but it doesn't feel like there's an occasion for the poem. Why did it come to be? It feels invented, contrived, divorced from life. Or rather, divorced from the life of anybody who isn't already themselves a poet. You know what I mean? If poetry's going to be more than cryptic signs that poets read to one another, poems have to have a broader appeal. They have to come from and go toward *life*. Note: I hate the word *life*. Especially if it's capitalized: *Life*. But like most dreadful, big words, it always seems to come up. 2) OK, now the second point. I talked about God and divine love and the Biblical interpretation of numbers, and it came off as, well, *very *Christian.
God's love is a form of counting. He knows the number of hairs on your head. He keeps careful track of the generations. We tend to see numbers as scientific, cold, abstract, but in the language of the Bible numbers often hold an organic, human significance. They are a sign of connectedness rather than difference and distance.
You could have found those sentences on a Christian blog, for sure. That's not quite what I'm up to here on this blog. Don't get me wrong, even though my relationship status with the divine has been set to "It's Complicated" for a quite while, I consider myself a spiritual person. I went to a pretty liberal Catholic school where they taught us to respect all belief systems, even atheism. Don't you kind of have to be spiritual, in a sense, in order to be a maker and appreciator of art? Don't you have to believe in some sort of transcendence and magic to want to make this stuff? To believe in the value of this stuff? I suppose I took the Christian / Biblical route because it felt relevant to the poem. He talks about several parables, clearly with Christ's parables in mind. So I went there. But not quite obliquely or considerately enough for my own tastes. I'll have to be more careful about that next time. So it goes, friends. Another day of writing. I'm hungry as hell. My wife and I are going to enjoy some delicious burritos and there's nothing you can do about it. Go read a poem. If you find a good one, tell me about it. I'll read a new poem and tell you all about it tomorrow. Until tomorrow, then.

entry.title: 'Calculations: A Love Poem' by Gary Fincke
entry.content:
Today has been marked by some very good news. I don't think I can reveal it until I've signed a contract (!), but it's going to be another big, positive change in a year that's already been full of big, positive changes. But when it rains it pours, so here's some fun news I *can* share. Today I received in the mail a print copy of the first issue of *Strangelet*, a journal of science fiction and fantasy that I helped edit. It's a beautiful journal, really well produced. And (height of excitement here) I'm listed on the masthead. This is the first time I've been listed on a print masthead, and I couldn't be happier about it. I'm also now on the masthead of *Asymptote*, as well, which is pretty marvelous. I continue to be amazed by how wildly accomplished and hard-working everyone at *Asymptote *is. It's really inspiring. I didn't post anything yesterday. Oy. I sat down in the evening to write and literally started falling asleep as I wrote. It was sad. These things happen, though. I know that when I was younger I would freak out if I missed something I had committed to. I would doubt my motives, doubt my ability, doubt myself. I would commit to studying Latin every day for an hour, for example, and then one day I wouldn't do it for whatever reason, and that was the beginning of the end. I would just fall apart. But now I know that *you have to assume you will fail*, and you have to prepare yourself for the day when you need to pick yourself up off the ground and dust yourself off. It's really easy to stay down; once you're down there, failure is strangely attractive. You resent failure and half-love it at the same time. Keats: "I have been half in love with easeful Death." But it's all about the "have been." You've got to put it behind you. You've got to put your old self behind you. You don't have to remain faithful to a you that wasn't fully formed. Blake: "The cut worm forgives the plow." So now it's time to get back into the swing of things. I want to look today at 'Calculations: A Love Poem' by Gary Fincke. This one comes from the *New England Review*, Vol. 34, the same place I got the two Russian poems that we read on Translation Thursdays (here and here). So here's 'Calculations: A Love Poem':
The billionth digit of pi is 9, The last month without a full moon, February, 1865— This morning I am making a list Of the last lines of parables About the work of numbers, about Calculations, marking the speed With which blood travels, as if three feet Per second were like the blessings On the late workers in a vineyard Or a son just home from living with swine. Someone continues the division That computes the decimals of pi— He is telling a story, numerals Spilling out toward infinity, The counting a language, a life Beyond this one, as difficult To believe as the number of hours We've slept together, darkness returning And vanishing, the moments, nightly, Between your breaths, the hesitations In your deep sleep; my own held breath, Listening, and then, temporarily Believed, turning toward the window, Reciting the autonomic lesson Of your lungs that swell and shrink At last, in rhythm, their vital Capacity, in liters, 3.1. — Gary Fincke, *New England Review*, Vol. 34, Number 3-4, ©2014,  p.333
Pi is an irrational number. It unfolds in a strange but orderly fashion forever. To try to compute pi is to try to make sense of the irrational that — who knows how or why — simply *is*. Of course language does the same thing. Counting is a language just as language is sort of counting or, as Walt Whitman would put it, a "tally." To give something a word, to acknowledge something by its name, is a way of counting it. So what does that have to do with love? God's love is a form of counting. He knows the number of hairs on your head. He keeps careful track of the generations. We tend to see numbers as scientific, cold, abstract, but in the language of the Bible numbers often hold an organic, human significance. They are a sign of connectedness rather than difference and distance. Human love is likewise a form of counting. We say that the person we're meant to be with is "the one." The people we love are the people who "count." Fincke takes this a step further: he counts his beloved in scientific terms, playing with that troubling space between knowing someone and *knowing *someone. The degree that it inevitably makes us uncomfortable — the precise speed of blood through the veins, the volume of air that the lungs can contain — lets us *feel our understanding of what poetry is*. Ending a poem with the number "3.1" (the first two digits of pi) just feels *wrong*, like some crucial boundary has been crossed.* *We might say that the poem fails because of it, but isn't that exactly the point? Doesn't that tell us something about love, about our expectations as poetry-readers of what love *should *be? Love *should be* lots of things, but maybe it's more important to every now and then count out precisely what love *is*.
