entry.title: Workin' It
entry.content:
I've been writing here for coming up on three months. There have been some hits, there have been some misses. I'm gonna talk a bit about views and hits in the next few paragraphs. It's not like that's all that matters to me, but as someone working toward becoming an editor and a writer I can't pretend I'm not interested in the question of *what people want*. I'm trying to figure out how to survive on the internet. And I figure some of you are, too, so I want to share some of the things that have worked for me.

The most popular post I've done was actually last week's post about 'Vowels' by Christian Bök. I mean just in terms of numbers, this one has *by far* the most views of any post I've done. What made the difference is that the poet tweeted about it twice. When a publishing house or journal tweets about you, you get a tiny bump at best. When a poet tweets about you, though, the numbers jump dramatically. The same thing happened with my posts about Michael Robbins' 'Country Music' and Diane Seuss's 'Still-Life with Two Dead Peacocks and a Girl (after Rembrandt)'. In all of these cases I tagged the authors when promoting the post on Twitter. I was worried at first that they might be upset by my putting their work online, but all of them have seemed pleased.

The second-most-popular post so far was 'Glass Box' by Sandra Simonds. With this one I didn't even include the whole poem, but I think the graphics I included made the difference. I'm a bit lazy with the graphics sometimes, but there's a decent correlation between having a graphic and getting 30 hits rather than 15. This was also the first post I did that received Facebook traffic. The effectiveness of Facebook has pushed me to add the handy Like/Share buttons at the bottom of each post. There's a similar service for Twitter.

I've also been slowly learning that readers want more of the same. If they started following along because of the poetry, give them more poetry. My mini-essays have not gone over well. Nobody particularly seems to care. I don't regret writing them, but I'll probably be less inclined in the future to indulge in them. (And yes, I recognize the irony of saying all this in a poetry-free post.) This sounds a little disheartening, but really it shouldn't be. It means that you need to refine and own your voice, and always be true to it. If you give people your best, they'll reward you by *wanting* your best. Whenever I sign onto a blog, I'm ready and willing to be impressed. I want to be *captivated*, to find something that's worth coming back to. There can be no *off days*; you have to always write like your reader has never heard of you before. Which is very near always the case with my readers, I'm sure. It's still probably true for even the big literature bloggers like Tony Malone or Scott Esposito.

I look forward to more. As I've commented before, this has been a tough week for writing for some reason. I'm sure the weekend ahead will help me recharge. But really, on the days when writing felt impossible, the thing that helped the most was — writing! I would literally write:
"This is so hard. I don't know how to tell you about this part of the poem. I don't know how to say it. The poet seems to be doing X, Y, and Z."
Then I would go back and erase everything before "The poet seems...." Terribly inefficient but it works.

Until next week. :-)

entry.title: 'Le Zèbre' by Robert Desnos
entry.content:
Robert Desnos. Have you heard of Robert Desnos? I'll summarize from the wiki article. He was a leading member of the Surrealist movement in early 20th century Paris. He was arrested by the Gestapo for his membership in the French Résistance, and he was sent first to Auschwitz and then to Theresienstadt, where he died of typhoid. Here's a story told by Susan Griffin (from her essay, 'Can the Imagination Save Us') about Desnos's last days:
Even in the grimmest of circumstances, a shift in perspective can create startling change. I am thinking of a story I heard a few years ago from my friend Odette, a writer and a survivor of the holocaust. Along with many others who crowd the bed of a large truck, she tells me, the surrealist poet Robert Desnos is being taken away from the barracks of the concentration camp where he has been held prisoner. Leaving the barracks, the mood is somber; everyone knows the truck is headed for the gas chambers. And when the truck arrives no one can speak at all; even the guards fall silent. But this silence is soon interrupted by an energetic man, who jumps into the line and grabs one of the condemned. Improbable as it is, Odette told me, Desnos reads the man's palm. Oh, he says, I see you have a very long lifeline. And you are going to have three children. He is exuberant. And his excitement is contagious. First one man, then another, offers up his hand, and the prediction is for longevity, more children, abundant joy. As Desnos reads more palms, not only does the mood of the prisoners change but that of the guards too. How can one explain it? Perhaps the element of surprise has planted a shadow of doubt in their minds. If hey told themselves these deaths were inevitable, this no longer seems inarguable. They are in any case so disoriented by this sudden change of mood among those they are about to kill that they are unable to go through with the executions. So all the men, along with Desnos, are packed back onto the truck and taken back to the barracks. Desnos has saved his own life and the lives of others by using his imagination.
Here's 'Le Zèbre', by Robert Desnos:
Le zèbre, cheval des ténèbres Lève le pied, ferme les yeux Et fait résonner ses vertèbres En hennisant d'un air joyeux. Au clair soleil de Barbarie, Il sort alors de l'écurie Et va brouter dans la prairie Les herbes de sorcellerie. Mais la prison, sur son pelage, A laissé l'ombre du grillage. --- The zebra, horse of darkness, lifts its foot, closes its eyes and sets its backbone reverberating with its joyful neighing. In the bright Barbary sunlight, he emerges then from the stable and goes grazing in the grasslands on the weeds of sorcery. But the prison, on his coat, has left the shadow of its bars. — Adapted from the prose translation by William Rees, The Penguin Book of French Poetry, 1820 - 1950, William Rees ed., Penguin Books, ©1990, p.760
The French rhymes and has a bouncy rhythm that the English doesn't capture. That bounciness and the sense of freedom and exuberance that come in the first two quatrains are supposed to stand in stark contrast to the sombre final couplet. 'The stable / l'écurie' becomes 'la prison.' It's a jolt. This is and is not an animal poem. It operates along the same lines as Ted Hughes's 'The Thought-Fox': capturing the animal's essence for the sake of illustrating some abstract principle, not for the sake of observing nature. I want to talk about the allegory, but it's so universal that I don't know I can settle on any one context that best fits it. Freedom is tainted by captivity. That's the whole tragic truth of it. Whether it's the freedom of artistic creation, freedom from one's past or one's responsibilities, freedom from political oppression: captivity leaves its mark. Having been captive becomes a part of us, indelible and inextricable. When injustice comes it comes forever; even forgiveness can't erase the past. "Mais la prison, sur son pelage, / A laissé l'ombre du grillage."

entry.title: 'In Memory of my Future' by Norma Cole
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'In Memory of my Future' by Norma Cole, from that Norton Anthology of *Postmodern American Poetry *I've been reading for the last several weeks. Cole, like Christian Bök, was born in Toronto; later in life she moved to San Francisco and became part of Robert Duncan's circle. It's interesting to me how much literary movements live and die by friendships and rivalries in a relatively close geographical and social space. Did I really just write that sentence? What I mean to say is: history is made by groups of like-minded individuals hanging out, getting high, getting mad at each other, being mad together, falling in love with each other, falling out of love with each other, and all the while making art. It happens in cities large and small. Rome. Paris. New York. San Francisco. Concord. Black Mountain. Each body of text is always a gathering of influences, always more than just text or the product of texts. I think this poem is about language's insufficiency, or language's state of exile from the world. I don't want to get of myself. (Well, sure I do. But I shouldn't.) Here's 'In Memory of my Future' by Norma Cole:
Statement is already exaggeration, migration, inclusion, the film itself become the fuse. Confusion in general or at least mutual, no longer or not yet. The thought of dust tightens the cords. A task is perceived as a symbol of inevitability, caesura seeing it through for what it is. It doesn't lend itself to explanation, sealed in the world, letter become life at the limit of memory. — Norma Cole, *Postmodern American Poetry*, Paul Hoover, editor, ©2013, W.W. Norton and Company, Inc, p.386
It's formally interesting, of course. The lines are unbroken, like three elegant brush-strokes. Anything that calls itself a poem but then refuses to use traditional lines and stanzas is trying to say something about form. Which is fitting, since I think even a cursory reading will tell us that the subject of the poem is "statement" as such. The act of stating things, the idea of the act of stating things: this is our poem's subject. So what is "statement"? It's not exact, that's for sure. Statement is slippery. It always misses its mark. It eats itself up; it self-destructs. Anytime you say "X is Y" you're at best very close to the truth, but not quite there. A statement is always too early or too late. "It doesn't lend itself to explanation" — but what else is it for? What is "a task"? A statement disguising itself as action. We say "I will do X" and we think it's inevitable. "Caesura" — the natural pauses that come as we move through a poem or move through life — see this task statement through / see it for what it is. Without jumps and gaps in time we could never get anything done; from the perspective of these jumps and gaps the statement "I will do X" is laughable. As though we could know what we will do! Or as though we could know what we have done, who we are, who we were, who we will be. The statement is "sealed in the world". That's probably the most important little phrase, right there. The world contains the statement, and not the other way around. Even the aggregate of all statements wouldn't contain the world. Statement as such is contained; it's just one of many things the world keeps in its toy chest. Is a poem a statement? I feel overwhelmed by this poem, though I love it, too. It's so small and I don't understand it, but I feel *attached to it *somehow. I think I've talked here before about the beauty of the sensation of the presence of meaning even without the understanding of that meaning. I'm tired. Like really and thoroughly tired. Writing, these last few days, has been very difficult. I'm going through a period of really awful self-doubt. And honestly a lot of that has to do with the fact that I got no sleep on Sunday night. Younger, less mature Tim would have given in to that feeling and done something rash. Made an important change. Freaked out a bit. But I — older and slightly more put together — am able to a degree to detach myself from my affect. I keep pushing, even though I don't want to, because I know I'll kick myself for it later. Or at least I think I will. I can't see that statement through for what it really is. Oy. Tomorrow.

entry.title: 'Dandelions (II)' by Henri Cole
entry.content:
Today I want to read 'Dandelions (II)' by Henri Cole, from the newest issue of *Poetry Magazine*. (You know that by following that link you can read the entire issue for free, right? Worth a look.) Unfortunately I wasn't a huge fan of this latest issue. It's got a big John Ashbery feature and, yeah, I just don't enjoy John Ashbery. Ashbery fans probably sneer at the word 'enjoy' but I don't care. Girolamo Mei created opera because church music left him feeling nothing. Ancient Greek texts told him he *should feel something* when he listened to music, and he believed them. So he and the Florentine Camerata recreated Greek music as they thought it must have been. So you can tell me Ashbery is saying interesting things about Lacan; I'm sure Palestrina was saying interesting things about Christian theology. So I'll learn what I can about Ashbery, and keep an open mind that maybe someday I might enjoy his poetry, but until then I'll follow my intuition toward the poetry that moves me. OK, now for Henri Cole. This is 'Dandelions (II)'. I couldn't find the first 'Dandelions' poem online. Must be in one of Henri Cole's books? In any case, here's the poem. It's a pretty heavy one, so, you know: brace yourself.
He drew these dandelions during one of the days when the only solace was derived from the labor of getting the white stems and blurry seed heads just right. “Nobody there,” the new disease announced, with black-tie gloom, “nobody there,” after he’d succumbed. Sometimes, sleeping soundly is almost unbearable. Please take care of me, he asked, as they put his crayons with his wallet in a box by the stove. In the distance, beyond the tulips, an insect chorus droned: we beat you up; we beat you up.
So there's a structure at work here — seven five-line stanzas — but not a rhythm or a rhyme. It reads like prose that's had line-breaks thrown in randomly. That's an OK tactic. It used to bother me but now I think: yeah, some times in life feel disjointed, arbitrarily broken up into small bits that don't necessarily make any sense. The situation Cole is trying to (not) talk about here seems like one of those moments. In really sad times — the death of a loved one, the departure of a dear friend — it seems like some force is shoving you reluctantly away from the better days of the past. You stumble, you falter, you are miserable, you are bored, but you always keep moving forward. Is it a child who is sick, dying, dead? We might think so at first because of the drawing dandelions, because of the crayons, but "his wallet" suggests someone older. The sufferer takes "solace" in the "labor" of art. Attention to reality's small details becomes — through art — a welcome distraction from reality. There are a couple points here that I find really interesting. The anthropomorphized disease is given words in quotes, but the person suffering from that disease is only quoted indirectly, without quotation marks. Possibly the speaker can't stand to engage with the level of abstraction the quotation marks imply. The quotation marks imply a considered distance; they acknowledge separation. By refusing the quotation marks, the speaker is making the suffering one's words his own. It is an act of empathy. The second point is that set of four lines: "Sometimes, / sleeping soundly / is almost // unbearable." Is the speaker saying this as someone who has to watch another suffer? I think that's what's happening. You feel guilty being well sometimes when someone you love is sick. You feel sick that you're not sick in their place, that you can't take it away from them and into yourself. As an empathetic person, "sleeping soundly / is almost // unbearable." And then finally, what a movement at the end. "In the distance, // beyond the tulips," is this jolting leap away from the intimate, almost breathless space we've been occupying. The drone of the chorus — like the chorus in a Greek tragedy. Insects just *are*. The drone of insects just *is*. And all these things that persist, all these things that unlike the suffering one in this poem *will not go away*, are a painful reminder of impermanence. The lasting things make us hurt for the things that are dying. A good sleep makes us hurt for those who can't get a good sleep. Well that's about as much punch-in-the-gut sadness as I can take for one day. Right? I didn't expect this poem to be quite so sad, but damn. It just aches. I'm gonna go get some dinner with my wife. Some Chinese food; that will cheer me up. Until tomorrow, amigos.

entry.title: 'In Case of Complete Reversal' by Kay Ryan
entry.content:
I took a red-eye from Los Angeles to Boston last night and got about two hours of sleep. I'm a bit of a wreck. I have absolutely no desire to write today which is why I absolutely have to write today no matter what. So here's 'In Case of Complete Reversal' by Kay Ryan, from the new September issue of *Poetry Magazine*.
Born into each seed is a small anti-seed useful in case of some complete reversal: a tiny but powerful kit for adapting it to the unimaginable. If we could crack the fineness of the shell we’d see the bundled minuses stacked as in a safe, ready for use if things don’t go well.
In terms of image, this is a fairly straightforward poem. A seed within a seed, and within that seed "bundled minuses", whatever that might mean. Little floating hyphens. Invisible electrons with their negative charges. But what is the seed, and how is it related to the way "things" "go"? A seed is a beginning, the smallest unit out of which our futures can emerge. So each beginning contains its opposite, so each beginning is not just itself but its own negation. All beginnings are adaptable to their own failure — to our failure. I like the poem's symbolic texture. You know throughout that the seed is only a very tenuous connection to the point the poet is trying to make. These seeds hardly resemble real seeds in any way. They're vessels for an idea. This means the poem plays itself out in a different part of the imagination than poems that more actively engage the senses. It's a poem of intellectual movement. Your mind moves with the poem more than your eye does. The poem is an order of thoughts aided by images rather than an order of images that imply thoughts. It's an interesting distinction to make between and within poems. I have become well-acquainted with failure in the twenty-nine years I've been alive. It's taken me nearly thirty years to learn that failure can be just part of the journey to success and is not always a sign from the universe that you don't belong. Or maybe there are failures that are a sign that you don't belong, but there's a good kind of failure too, a failure that's a challenge that you should accept, a failure that's a dark wood at the beginning of a long journey toward the light. Learning how to accept failures or to put failures behind you is difficult, but it's not impossible, and it's worth learning how to do. Every beginning contains what's needed to get over a reversal of fortune. That's about as much juice as my sleepless brain can squeeze from this lemon. (I like lemon juice; it's a good thing.) Tomorrow I'll be well rested and my thoughts will be more clear. But I'm glad I've written. I'm glad I didn't give up on today. Alright then. Until tomorrow.

entry.title: The Cost of Good Reading
entry.content:
Keeping up on the newest poetry can be expensive. If you're on a budget, you've *really *got to choose where and how you read. Here's a table I put together of how much it would cost to get a year's subscription to each of the top ten 2014 Pushcart Prize-winning journals:
Poetry 11 issues $35.00
The Kenyon Review 4 issues $30.00
American Poetry Review 6 issues $20.00
Ploughshares 3 issues $35.00
The Georgia Review 4 issues $40.00
The Threepenny Review 4 issues $25.00
The New England Review 4 issues $30.00
The Virginia Quarterly Review 4 issues $32.00
The Southern Review 4 issues $40.00
Field 2 issues $16.00
Total (before tax and shipping)      --- $303.00
I would pay for an *American Poetry Review *subscription. It has a great mix of criticism and poetry, and at $20 for 6 issues it's a really good deal. I like *The New England Review* and *Ploughshares* well enough, but not enough of their content is geared toward my tastes and interests that I would commit $65 a year to them. I'd rather get them at the library, even if that means waiting a while after the initial publication date of each issue. (Have you looked at your local library for poetry resources? They might have great stuff there in print, and they might have electronic access to some of the top journals. With a bit of searching I found that I can read the current and even the back issues of most of the top journals for free through* *my local library's website. Do some looking around.) There's also a question of advocacy. Sure I could plunk down the money for a powerhouse publication like *Ploughshares*, but wouldn't my money mean more to a smaller (and, for me personally, more interesting) operation like *Music & Literature*? Putting my money there would give me the feeling of being part of something more intimate; it's a literary *and *a political choice. They aren't all 'just literary journals' any more than *The National Review* and *The Nation* are 'just news magazines'. *In the rush to cheer-lead for poetry as a genre many of us forget that poetry takes many forms and is produced and distributed in more or less fair ways. You can support the best practices with your dollars*. Vote for your favorite poetry with your praise, yes. We need more people doing serious thinking and talking and writing about poetry. But also vote with your dollars. Give praise with your dollars. Let your dollars be thoughtful dollars. For just $25 you can tell *The Threepenny Review* that you love what they're doing, and in return they'll give you more of that good stuff. That's what it costs to read good things. That's what it costs to be a good reader. Tweet

entry.title: 'Vowels' by Christian Bök
entry.content:
If you're like me and you like knowing what books are coming out in the next month or two or you have a hard time keeping up with the books that have already come out in the last several months, then you should take a look through Poetry Daily's Publications Noted and Received list. It's a great way to keep up on the latest poetry news. Most books are linked directly to Amazon, so you can add them to your Amazon Wish List and tell your family and friends, "Buy me these things, if you really love me." Speaking of poetry news, I need to rely less on Twitter for poetry news. Most times when the subject of poetry appears on Twitter, it's just another article about the World War I poets or why we should appreciate Homer. Any time they cover a living poet it's got a very serious-faced black-and-white photo of the poet, very austere looking so that you can reasonably assume the poet is wise and good and heroically thankfully dead. Nobody's talking about living poets, the poets who right now are trying to make something great or have real fun. There are a lot of posers out there, for sure. Maybe that task of wading through the posers discourages people who go looking for *the real thing *in contemporary poetry. But that's how it's always been. You think Homer didn't know a bunch of posers? You think he didn't roll into Megara and sigh that everybody was listening to some poet named Cleomenes and not him? But on the other hand you think he didn't step into some little house party in Thebes and hear an amazing poet and just go "Wow!" and go up to him after the show and say "Hey man, sounds good." And that poet is lost to history now, but that "wow" lives on. There ought to be a tomb for the unknown poet, inscribed with the word "wow". But that "wow" ought to be given to the living, too. We owe a debt of praise to the living poets worthy of that name. Ugh. "Debt of praise"? I'm being too dramatic. Let's get to the poetry. OK, today I want to look at a playful poem called 'Vowels' by the Canadian poet Christian Bök. I found this one in the Norton Anthology of *Postmodern American Poetry* (I've also read a poem by Robert Duncan from this anthology). I'm still trying to *get* what postmodernism is. I could venture some ideas about capitalism, about resisting meta-narratives, about undermining the political assumptions that hold language together and that language holds together, but I'm pretty sure that everything I said would be wrong. So here's 'Vowels':
loveless vessels we vow solo love we see love solve loss else we see love sow woe selves we woo we lose losses we levee we owe we sell loose vows so we love less well so low so level wolves evolve — Christian Bök, *Postmodern American Poetry*, Paul Hoover, editor, ©2013, W.W. Norton and Company, Inc, p.771
You see what Bök has done, yeah? It's an anagrammatic poem. The entire poem is composed with the letters v, o, w, e, l, and s. As a poem about love and love's inversion it has some interesting thing to say, but none of those (at first) seem as interesting as the form itself. We see the arbitrariness of language. We get the sense that, though it might be hard, we can construct any meaning out of any combination of letters. It's the poets intention that drives letters into place, and the reader determines whether those letters in that order (with just the right spaces in between) are *good *or *bad*. But this is beyond just aesthetic judgment. A phrase like "wolves evolve" is *good* English. It has the stamp of approval from the English language. But something like "vlle wvo" doesn't get that stamp of approval. English says, "No, that doesn't belong. There's no historical precedent for it, and nobody now living would recognize it as anything but gibberish." As playful as Bök's poem might seem, it is held tightly in check by societal pressures. So we see, through the game of the anagram, that *all words and phrases are shaped by historical and living communities of language*. Now think about that in terms of love. "we vow / solo love" and "we sell / loose vows". Promises are just made of words, combinations of sounds and letters. We learn the words for promises from other speakers of our language. We learn the words and the letters that make the words, but we don't necessarily have *the substance *to really *make *promises. Without some force outside the letter, outside the word, without some true intention, these words are "loveless vessels". And in short time "wolves evolve". Just one word for this kind of poem: wow. Until tomorrow, all.

entry.title: 'Slow Learner: In the Garden' by Christopher Buckley
entry.content:
Christopher Buckley has the wrong name. He's the author of over twenty books, but you won't find any of them on the first page of Amazon search results because there's a famous novelist also named Christopher Buckley. If you're looking for the poet's new book, *Back Room at the Philosopher's Club*, you'll have to continue onto the second page of search results. Even on the Goodreads page for one of the poet's anthologies, *How Much Earth: The Fresno Poets*, they give the bio for the novelist. Ugh. I hate this sort of thing. When I arrived at Yale, there was already another Timothy Ellison in my department. I'd show up to meetings with professors and they would be expecting the other guy. People would angrily ask me why I hadn't answered their emails and I would have to explain that they probably sent it to the wrong Timothy Ellison. I met the other Tim; he's a really nice guy. But it got old fast. Reminds me (a little) of this cartoon:
What do you do at that point? You let it go, I guess. Or you try to do more with your name than the other guy. But if you're a poet against a famous novelist, you're better off letting it go. So enough small talk. I want to look at this poem 'Slow Learner: In the Garden', one of two poems by Buckley in *Zyzzyva* no. 100. It's a very classical feeling poem. To me it feels like one of Coleridge's conversational poems or Wordsworth's epitaph poems (well, they're *all *epitaph poems, aren't they?). It bears repeated and slow reading. It addresses big themes through small movements in imagery and register, which is how I like poems. I'm not crazy about poems that wave their arms in the air shouting, "Look at me, Ma!" Anyway, here's the first page of the poem. It's a big poem so I don't want to give the whole thing away, and I think this is a really representative sample of the whole:
     I am a slow study, apparently nothing for it ... but I'm happy to be at my lessons,      in the particulars, the thorns or petals, mildew or rust—my doctorate taken in vagary,      in staring off at the ivory bells of yucca in a breeze. I admire clarity, the high, hard edge      of oxygen, and yet the formless beauty, the heady embellishment of orange blossoms—      promises that will not apply in terms of October. The arithmetic of wind—simple plus      or minus, everything blowing away ... our last warnings in the eucalyptus      dry from the air down, the untranslatable borders, sweet peas on the trellis      red and magenta, bruises dividing the sky. I've come up with next to nothing      given the hours spent observing the plumbago braid itself on air, multiply among      the pittosporum and pyracantha. Now and then I have the good sense to listen to      the red sandstone and granite of the Santa Ynez range, of the San Rafaels, a quiet      called for by the insatiable light from here to Istanbul, where I still see Nazim Hikmet      picking an apple in the yard of that rundown house, in the stuttering poverty of his heart. — from 'Slow Learner: In the Garden' by Christopher Buckley, *Zyzzyva*, no. 100, ©2014, p.158
The thing to watch is how your mind moves from sentence to sentence, image to image, line to line. Early on he sets a personal, humorous tone. He declares himself a student of small materialities, and pursues that train of thought through blossoms, wind, trees, peas on their trellises, shades of color in the sky, (and notice it's all air, air, air), and finally ends with those two mouthfuls: "pittosporum and pyracantha." You're being guided through a poetics. He shows you what he's all about as a poet even as he demonstrates it. So why does the stanza break after "pittosporum and pyracantha"? Because his thought has reached its limit. He says he's a student of materials and the images of materials, but as he pursues that thought he comes to a threshold of pure language. The words "pittosporum and pyracantha" are extremely exact *as language*, but they do nothing to convey image. There's a separation between the word and the thing, or the common mind's ability to link the word to the thing. The visual and the verbal are at cross-purposes. So the stanza breaks, and he explores a new angle. "Now and then I have the good sense to listen to" ... To what? It's a good exercise to try and fill in the blank at the end of a line. What do you expect to come next? Birds? The wind? A song? Your guess probably isn't "the red sandstone and granite / of the Santa Ynez range, of the San Rafaels". It's a strangely synaesthetic answer. How do you listen to stone? What is there to hear? He's pushing at the limits of our understanding. The sound of stone and the image of an obscure word like "pittosporum" are each at the edge of sense. And from here we move to Nazim Hikmet. Barring some extreme twists of fate, Buckley simply couldn't have seen Hikmet in Turkey. The poetic eye has drifted from the realest of the real to the imaginary, the solitary figure in a land the poet probably hasn't been to. And who is Nazim Hikmet? A political poet. An exiled poet. A suffering poet. Can you see the way Buckley is testing himself? Straining at the edges of his craft? Doubting the worth and purpose of his poetry even as he writes it? Wordsworth does something so similar in "Lines Composed a Few Miles Above Tintern Abbey":
The day is come when I again repose Here, under this dark sycamore, and view These plots of cottage-ground, these orchard-tufts, Which at this season, with their unripe fruits, Are clad in one green hue, and lose themselves 'Mid groves and copses. Once again I see These hedge-rows, hardly hedge-rows, little lines Of sportive wood run wild: these pastoral farms, Green to the very door; and wreaths of smoke Sent up, in silence, from among the trees! With some uncertain notice, as might seem Of vagrant dwellers in the houseless woods, Or of some Hermit's cave, where by his fire The Hermit sits alone.
Buckley's poem is just right: the didactic but friendly pace, the combination of familiarity and strangeness, the richness of imagery and sound, the respect for the sentence and the line. Just the qualities that, for me, make a poem great. Buy yourself a copy of *Zyzzyva *and read the whole poem*. *Buy yourself a copy of *Back Room at the Philosopher's Club*, which includes this poem*.* Support poets you like with your dollars. Until tomorrow, all.

entry.title: Labor Day
entry.content:
My wife and I just spent most of our day in a rental Volkswagen Jetta, traveling from Quebec to Boston. We made a lot of stops along the way to look at historical sites (and because -- lucky us -- the border patrol selected our car for a random inspection), so it took roughly nine and a half hours to get home. That's a long day. Some days feel so un-poetry that they're poetry, you know? No, maybe that doesn't make any sense. It's just when you stop at the swamps at the foot of Mount Bigelow and you feel the sun pressing on your skin and in your hair and the smell of mud is so damn thick in your nostrils and the only sound you hear is the constant scree of insects and the crush and crish of your own footsteps in the dirt and the splash of a yellow Labrador retriever jumping into the clear water it's hard not to think of it as a poetic experience. It's poetic because it's small, it's private, it's not something you could make a movie about or tie into a popular novel in an especially interesting way. It wouldn't fit very well into a song, and it would be hard to paint, so it's poetic. It's jagged and real but dreamlike and universal, so it's poetic. And all of what I've just written is probably bullshit, but that's also part of what makes it poetic.
And it's an experience I wouldn't give up for anything. That makes it poetry.
And now I'm going to get some sleep before starting a new day. OK, I'm actually going to do some work and then get to sleep, but none of that (Hurray!) will be in a car. That's poetic too. That's all part of it.

entry.title: 'Christ en Croix' by Émile Nelligan
entry.content:
My wife and I are in Montreal today; we got here late last night. It's strange speaking French only about five hours north of home. The only other places I've spoken French are college classes and (of course) France. It's had me wondering about the relationship between French and English here. How does a Quebecois's French impact her or his English, and vice versa?  Anyway, I'll get to the point. I've got work to do tonight; a *lot *of work. So I can't spend as long as I usually do putting this blog post together. So here, in the spirit of Montreal and Quebecois poetry and all things Canadian, is a the poem 'Christ en Croix' by Émile Nelligan, followed by an English translation of the same by (according to wikipedia) Konrad Bongard. My French isn't the best, but even I can tell that it's a *very *loose translation. But enjoy anyway. And really, do yourself a favor and read up on the incomparable Émile Nelligan.Until next week!
Je remarquais toujours ce grand Jésus de plâtre Dressé comme un pardon au seuil du vieux couvent, Échafaud solennel à geste noir, devant Lequel je me courbais, saintement idolâtre. Or, l'autre soir, à l'heure où le cri-cri folâtre, Par les prés assombris, le regard bleu rêvant, Récitant Eloa, les cheveux dans le vent, Comme il sied à l'Éphèbe esthétique et bellâtre, J'aperçus, adjoignant des débris de parois, Un gigantesque amas de lourde vieille croix Et de plâtre écroulé parmi les primevères; Et je restai là, morne, avec les yeux pensifs, Et j'entendais en moi des marteaux convulsifs Renfoncer les clous noirs des intimes Calvaires! ---- The gypsum Jesus always stalled me in my steps Like a curse at the old convent door; Crouching meekly, I bend to exalt an idol Whose forgiveness I do not implore. Not long ago, at the crickets' hour, I roamed dim Meadows in a restful reverie Reciting 'Eloa', with my hair worn by the wind And no audience save for the trees. But now, as I lie with knees bent beneath Christ's scaffold, I see his crumbling mortar cross With its plaster buried in the roses, and am saddened - For if I listen close enough, I can almost hear The sound of coal-black nails being wrung in To his wrists, the savage piercing of Longinus' spear.

entry.title: 'The Jolt' by Anna Semyonovna Prismanova
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'The Jolt' by Russian poet Anna Semyonovna Prismanova (1892–1960), translated by UCLA professor Boris Drayluk for the *New England Review* double issue that came out this spring. It's short and sweet, so I'll get right to it. Here's 'The Jolt':
The jolt must come from far away: the start of bread is in the grain. A stream, although still underground, aspires to reflect the sky. A future Sunday's distant light reaches us early in the week. The jolt must come from far away to trigger earthquakes in the heart. A shoulder alien to me controls the movement of my hand. In order to acquire such strength, the jolt must come from far away. — Anna Semyonovna Prismanova, trans. Boris Drayluk, *New England Review*, Vol. 34, Number 3-4, ©2014,  p.147
With a poem this short, it can feel like there's no room for movement. Nothing is happening by the end that wasn't already happening at the beginning. Take this poem by A.E. Housman, for example:
Stars, I have seen them fall,     But when they drop and die No star is lost at all     From all the star-sown sky. The toil of all that be     Helps not the primal fault; It rains into the sea,     And still the sea is salt.
It's basically three iterations of the same image/idea.You don't learn anything new from the last two lines that you didn't already learn from the first four. But the poem still works because it's not trying to move you anywhere; rather, it works by accumulation. By saying the same thing in different ways it convinces you of a truth: that life is unchanging, nothing is lost, nothing is gained. Anna Semyonovna Prismanova's poem works similarly. It explores her idea of artistic cause and effect from a variety of angles (specifically, lines 2, 3-4, 5-6, 7-8, and 9-10). By demonstrating how many ways there are to express her idea, she convinces us of its truth. There's so much more to say but, alas, I must go. I'll write a little something tomorrow morning from my exotic Canadian hotel room. Until then!

entry.title: Unpoetic Things: On Memory and Creativity
entry.content:
This morning I decided to walk to work instead of taking the train. It takes twice as long, but it's a beautiful walk along Commonwealth Avenue and through the Public Garden and the Common. There was a man playing Bach's 'Ave Maria' on a nylon string guitar on the bridge that crosses the pond in the Public Garden. There was this priest at our church when I was growing up in Clovis. He had a thick beard and a deep voice. He over-pronounced his words and over-projected his voice, which gave his sermons a dramatic effect. He breathed deeply and loudly through his nose. When I was taking karate lessons in the 7th grade there was this master Judo instructor who came to our little dojo and gave a special class on a Saturday morning. He was tall and fat and bald and had this strange yellow patch of skin on one side of his face. His gi fell open at one point and his heavy, jumbo globe of a belly was the dojo's center of gravity. I remember thinking that he was so gross. And I knew another bald man who had a place in the country with his wife and daughters, and they had two or three horses on a couple acres of grassy land, and I remember walking with him and my father and my brothers in their back yard and the bald man was wearing a bucket hat and one of his horses came up to him and he stroked its face and talked to it quietly. All this is to say that I wrote a poem this morning. The poem I wrote was made out of these memories, and several others. How do these unpoetic things become a poem, and why? What pot of chemicals boiled over in my brain and made me write? How did these memories get from one side of the bridge to the other — from my mind to the written word? Why these memories and not some other ones? Why today? Why ever? I'm learning to believe again that it's not really my place to ask any of these questions. The imagination is its own creature. It lives and breathes and dreams with a will of its own. Here are some lines from Wordsworth's *Prelude*:
           ...who shall parcel out His intellect by geometric rules, Split like a province into round and square? Who knows the individual hour in which His habits were first sown, even as a seed? Who that shall point as with a wand and say "This portion of the river of my mind Came from yon fountain?"
This belief is probably why I put so much trust in preference. I like what I like without apology. By going outside myself toward what I enjoy, I draw closer to the world *and *to myself. Another word for it is intuition. I love that word, "intuition." Tuition within, an inner teacher. When I'm writing, I'm just taking dictation. I'm just as much an outsider to my poetry as anybody else. That, to me, feels like the healthiest relationship a poet can have to her or his own work. Here's a line from Devin Johnston's "Nothing Song":
"It's not myself I sing, or love, or anything that has a source. I dreamed these words while riding on my horse."

entry.title: 'Fresno County Library' by Michelle Patton
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Fresno County Library' by Michelle Patton, from issue no. 100 of *Zyzzyva*. I'm from the Central Valley and spent most of my life in Fresno, so this poem was special to me. But I think I would have enjoyed and noticed this poem even without that connection. It's got a sense of humor, it respects the integrity of the sentence, and it balances a lyric voice with an implied narrative. Enough prologue, though. Here's 'Fresno County Library':
It's always the same: the eternal scrape of chairs against linoleum, the Librarians never losing their minds, the children's section with its bright animals and solar systems. You'd like to be like your father, a galaxy of facts flickering behind your forehead, but you've always got late fees and never finish anything, wandering the aisles in your too-big shoes and your too-big sweater, checking the catalog, designing elaborate reading plans, only to give up after the preface, go outside to smoke and stare at the homeless guy who unrolls his sleeping bag under a dusky sky that could make you ache if you stared long enough, if you thought long enough about why he unrolls his bag every evening, then paces between two old trees, you might wonder what the trees know, or where his mother could be. Oh everything passes, even this sky. You'll go back in with the many photographs of authors smiling from dusty book jackets, the old man who reads quietly to the statues, and the woman carefully copying every word from a book about Venice. You'll drink the benevolent water and smile at the janitor who pushes in chairs and wears a long-suffering kindness on his face, as if we were his special wards, we the readers and wanderers, the hungry and the lost. — Michelle Patton, *Zyzzyva*, no. 100, Spring/Summer 2014, pp.39-40
Notice all the layers of night sky in this poem: there's the solar system in the children's section, the galaxy in the speaker's father's forehead, and the dusky sky under which the homeless man is preparing his bed. Each is associated with a different kind of knowledge. The children's section is a nurturing kind of learning that comes through instruction; the father's mind is a storehouse of facts and experiences gathered throughout a life; and the homeless man is something else, perhaps a spiritual knowledge beyond books, perhaps a form of madness. (His pacing between two trees feels like reading to me, the tracing of the eye across a page from left to right, left to right. The pages of a book are often called leaves.) It's a very realistic look at what libraries provide: they're just as much a social sanctuary — a last resort for the desperate — as they are a source of knowledge. Communities of knowledge can serve as clean, well-lighted places to go when we have nowhere else. Readers are "wanderers," "hungry," "lost." Notice the punning hint toward *The Odyssey* in that phrase from the eighth line: "wandering the aisles." And yet I don't think this poem is cheer-leading for libraries and books. It's too complicated and ambivalent for that. It seems to be almost skeptical about reading and knowledge, especially with the image of "the woman carefully copying every word / from a book about Venice." There's a kind of madness to that copying, a bent relationship to words and the world. What a great poem, right? There's more poetry to read in *Zyzzyva *no. 100, plus a lot of great fiction and non-fiction. Besides this by Michelle Patton, I was really only crazy about one other poem in the collection, so I'll read that one tomorrow. Until then!

entry.title: 'Dream Song 1' by John Berryman
entry.content:
I'm going to wrap up my look into the latest issue of *Salmagundi* by looking at Henri Cole's essay on John Berryman's *The Dream Songs*. The first and only time I opened *The Dream Songs* I was very put off. I didn't know what to make of them. I wish I'd known then that that was the point. Here's Cole:
[Berryman] spent thirteen years writing *The Dream Songs* and in them rejects the decorous Anglophilia and formal versification that were fashionable during the decade before. "I set up *The Dream Songs* as hostile to every visible tendency in both American and English poetry," Berryman said. Instead we get a new kind of diction—ridiculous, grotesque, horrible, delicious—that better suits the generally extravagant situations in which the sobbing protagonist Henry finds himself. —Henri Cole, *Salmagundi*, Nos. 182-183, ©2014,  p.56
I don't know that this knowledge would have made a difference to me then. When I was younger I most appreciated a commitment to formal beauty. Shakespeare and Spencer were my jam, the sonnets especially. I liked the sense of mastery, of craft. But I also liked Whitman's *Leaves of Grass* and Thoreau's *Walden*. I liked their abundance, the element of chance that seemed to be at work in their composition. Perhaps if my appreciation for this American voice had been stronger, if I had felt less ashamed of liking it, I would have been more ready for Berryman's *The Dream Songs*. (But we're ready for different pieces of art at different times in our lives. Saying "I wish I understood that artist" or "I wish I could hear what's so great in that musician" is like saying "I wish I could be a grown up *now*." It's a perfectly healthy thing to think and say, but it's perfectly useless, too.)  Enough about me, though. Here's the first of Berryman's *The Dream Songs*:
Huffy Henry hid    the day, unappeasable Henry sulked. I see his point,—a trying to put things over. It was the thought that they thought they could *do* it made Henry wicked & away. But he should have come out and talked. All the world like a woolen lover once did seem on Henry’s side. Then came a departure. Thereafter nothing fell out as it might or ought. I don’t see how Henry, pried open for all the world to see, survived. What he has now to say is a long wonder the world can bear & be. Once in a sycamore I was glad all at the top, and I sang. Hard on the land wears the strong sea and empty grows every bed. —text from poets.org
I won't say "What more is there to say?" because clearly this poem is so complex. I will recommend that if this poem hasn't convinced you to read *The Dream Songs*, then go find and read the rest of Henri Cole's essay in *Salmagundi. *It'll do the trick. (Oh, and Cole lists what he thinks are the best of *The Dream Songs*: nos. 1, 4, 5, 14, 21, 26, 29, 37, 45, 46, 53, 76, and 77. Go find 'em!) Alright, friendlings, I've gotta be gone, like, ten minutes ago. Until tomorrow!

entry.title: Weekly Wrap-Up (August 17-23, 2014)
entry.content:
This has been a fun and very busy week. I'm adjusting to balancing this blog with my job, my duties at Ox and Pigeon and Strangelet, and my new work at Asymptote. It's doable, for sure, but I've got to *learn *to do it. I took a couple days to read 'Blossom' by April Bernard (here and here), read a cool sort of narrative poem by Joan Hutton Landis, enjoyed a little translated poetry by Olga Sedakova, and finished off the week with a prose-poem by Campbell McGrath. The blog will be two months old tomorrow. It's had just over two thousand page hits already, which I think is a great start. But it's not about those numbers, of course. If I'd started a site looking at diet pills or video games, I'd have many times more page hits. What matters to me is that I've been able to think and write about the work of twenty-eight poets whom, until I'd started this blog, I knew little or nothing about. Just for me, it's be a great learning experience. So there are a few things I want to do moving forward.
  • More book reviews. Every couple weeks I would like to do a two- or three-part review of a full book of poetry or poetry criticism. Since I have no budget that's going to mean soliciting publishers for ARCs, which is a whole set of tasks in itself.
  • More special features. I recently applied for a blogging position at a major website, which required me to list a bunch of feature and series ideas. As I brainstormed and generate ideas it got me thinking, "I should be doing this stuff *anyway*, whether or not it's for a major website." Like I said in an earlier post, I want to detail the ridiculous and impractical costs of subscribing to multiple poetry journals. I want to interview poets on how they work. I want to do features on small publishing houses.
  • Writing for other journals and blogs. Just writing for my own site feels unadventurous to me; I want a bigger challenge.
All this will probably mean I'll be going from seven-days-a-week to just weekdays. The stats show that weekend readership is *very low *anyway, so I gather that it won't be much of a loss to all of you. And it will mean fresher, more unique content on the blog, so that's a win for everybody. OK, I've got to get going, but I'll be back with more poetry tomorrow. Until then!

entry.title: 'Georgia O'Keefe' by Campbell McGrath
entry.content:
This morning on the train to work I re-read some poetry and essays from the latest issue of *Salmagundi*. I wish I'd been a regular *Salmagundi* reader for longer. I once raided a big stack of books that Geoffrey Hartman was giving away and pulled out two issues of *Salmagundi*; I should have taken it as a hint that this is one of *the *journals to be reading. But like most people, I need to be beaten over the head with a thing before I'll notice it. So this is me beating you over the head: go buy a copy of *Salmagundi.* Today I'm reading the prose poem 'Georgia O'Keefe' by Campbell McGrath. I've featured a poem of McGrath's before here on the blog. This is the first prose poem I've looked at, so here goes:
Grey is the color of blindness, but also of sight: white rocks and black rocks, the moon and her daughter, equally grey. The door into the dark is the door into the light, neither can exist without its opposite, women and men, the living and the dead, we belong to their long marriage quarrel, everything grey in the cloud-forest of the mind. Grey of milk in a shadowed pitcher, grey of goslings, grey of rivets. Grey being the color of eternity I commend myself to its embrace, grey potato-skins slopped for mud-grey hogs, the dead piglet consumed by its kin, old snow in the coal-ash arroyo, almond and violet gravel, grey as affirmation, grey as union, the doe at twilight, the mesa by moonlight, cloud-drawn dawn like a brindled flank. Color of Third Avenue mornings flush with fresh linen, roman numerals in basalt, the Chrysler building an awl to pierce the sheep’s caul through which an airplane descends with bursts of illumination befitting the immodesty of 20th Century gods. Grey as the void of memory in which I imagine the feel of a brush in hand but can’t recall its purpose, can’t envision the cream of jimson weed, the slashed throat of a dahlia—what else did god intend us to paint beyond the flowers he saw fit to bequeath us, rocks and flowers, say. Bones as a last resort. Color of ghosts, color of clouds and Manhattan, of everything Steiglitz ever touched or photographed, my body unrecognizable as the city’s erotic stone-work—who is that woman with hips like the weathered horns of an antelope skull? Where has it run to, in this desert, the lavish water of her hair?

— Text from the *Salmagundi* website
How do you begin to talk about a prose poem? There are no formal divisions you can use to say "Look at this part" and "Look at that part." Everything comes out in a rush, even if you read it slowly. If there is a movement it is in the type of images. We move from abstraction and nature imagery (common nouns) to specific people and places (proper nouns). It moves from definitions (grey is this; grey is that) to a question ("who is that woman?") the only answer to which can be: Georgia O'Keefe. And how beautiful is that last question: "Where has it run to, in this desert, the lavish water of her hair?" It might as well ask "*Mais où sont les neiges d'antan?*"
I don't usually associate Georgia O'Keefe with the color grey. From experiences of her cityscapes and landscapes, I expect bold colors. Bold colors are a sort of loud renunciation of grey. A boldly colored painting says, "No! Not grey!" Doesn't this mean, though, that the artist is fixated on grey, just as the immaculate saint is fixated on sin? Now that I'm thinking about it, though, I can't help but concentrate on the grey spaces in her work. Look what you've done, McGrath! There's a little passage in there that's a mash-up of two Gerard Manley Hopkins poems. "cloud-drawn dawn like a brindled flank" comes from 'The Windhover"
dapple-dawn-drawn Falcon
and "Pied Beauty"
skies of couple-colour as a brinded cow.
I don't really know what McGrath is doing here with this play on Hopkins. I know it's fun to play with these things, as a poet, but what's he trying to say by playing with Hopkins in a poem about Georgia O'Keefe? I don't really know enough about Hopkins to comment, or O'Keefe for that matter, or whether there was some connection between his poetry and her painting, but it's a mystery I wouldn't mind getting to the bottom of. Alright, I must be going now, to quote the bear. Have a good day all!

entry.title: 'Beads' by Olga Sedakova
entry.content:
Happy Translation Thursday! Today I'm looking at 'Beads' by Olga Sedakova (translated by Stephanie Sandler) in the *New England Review* double issue that came out this spring. If you like Russian literature you really should pick this one up. It features classic writers like Pushkin, Chekhov, and Dostoevsky alongside newer voices like Mikhail Shishkin, Olga Slavnikova, Anzhelina Polonskaya, and Lev Rubinstein.
There's a new book of Olga Sedakova translations coming out this December, and there's another collection of poetry already available as well as a collection of her essays. You can also read many free samples of her work on her website. A quick word about translation. Translations expose you to how much you don't know about the world. This can be a source of great frustration, but it can also be an invitation: an invitation to know more, to experience more, to be more. But yes, *frustration*. Having grown up in the U.S., when I read an American writer, I can quickly get a sense of their politics, their religion, their place. I can imagine them in an historical context; I can see how they play with and to their context. When I read a writer from another country, I have very little context, and what little context I have is probably skewed toward an Americentric point of view. This high level of unfamiliarity makes me tend to embrace poems that are universal (seeming), that don't deal with particulars of place, history, or context. I would love to read a poem that details intimate knowledge of Fresno or Boston or New York or London or Paris because I've spent a lot of time in those cities. But Moscow? Nairobi? Lima? Tokyo? I hardly know anything about them, so when I encounter poems about them *I can choose either to learn or to move on*.  Which would you choose? Alright, enough pondering. Here's 'Beads' by Olga Sedakova:
My grandmother's lapis ring, my great grandfather's books—these I can give up, I think. But somehow these glass beads are more than I can bear to lose. They are bright-colored, simple like a garden of peacocks, and their heart is made of stars and fish scales. Or a lake, and fish in the lake: first a black one dives up, then scarlet, then the tiniest fish, a flash of green— he will never come back now, indeed, why should he? I love not the poor, nor the rich, not this country, nor any other, not the time of day, nor time of year— but I do love what is all seeming: it is a mysterious form of joy. It has no price and makes no sense. — Olga Sedakova, trans. Stephanie Sandler, *New England Review*, Vol. 34, Number 3-4, ©2014,  p.244
Those first three lines are quite a gesture. The writer raises a certain set of expectations, and then sweeps them aside. Nine out of ten poems that begin "My grandmother's lapis ring, / my great grandfather's books" are about to talk *about those things*. Heirlooms seem to have, for all of us, an inherent sense of value. But the speaker says, "No. That's not where value is. Value is in reverie, in beauty free of context, in 'what is all seeming'." Does Sedakova agree? I mean really, does Sedakova actually *believe *what the speaker of the poem is saying? Or is she being ironic, and the poem is actually a critique of aestheticism's ethical impotency? "I love not the poor, nor the rich, / not this country, nor any other, / not the time of day, nor time of year" is a pretty serious thing to say. I think a lot of people would object to that way of looking at the world; many others might praise it. Where do you fall? It's an open question. Our answers might tell us a lot about who we are. This universal (seeming) poetry — the poetry that doesn't dig into the particulars of place and history — can take us into foreign parts of ourselves. There are things we think that we don't know we think until someone else shows us how to voice them. It's a form of travel. It can be fun or it can be frustrating, and in the times of frustration with myself I can choose either to learn or to move on. Which would you choose?

entry.title: A quick note, and then more on April Bernard
entry.content:
I want to continue looking at 'Blossom' by April Bernard, but first I need to say something about yesterday's post. It's a sort of correction, or explanation of a correction. I had originally written the following opening paragraph in yesterday's post:
Today I want to look at a poem by April Bernard from the Spring/Summer 2014 issue of *Salmagundi*. Ms. Bernard is the author of several poetry collections — including *Psalms*, *Swan Electric*, and *Romanticism* — as well as a novel, *Miss Fuller*.
But then my wife, Amy, wrote me a quick email:
Can you edit it so that it doesn't say "Ms. Bernard" in the second sentence? You've never said Mr. so-and-so when referring to a male poet. Why not just say Bernard?
She was absolutely right. In the drafting phase, my first sentence had ended with "April Bernard", so I changed my second sentence opener from "April Bernard" to "Ms. Bernard" just to avoid the repetition. But saying "Ms. Bernard" comes off as condescending. It's like calling her an authoress or a poetess. This is something Amy and I talk about a lot and take very seriously. In academic circles, where people should know better, it's very common to refer to male academics by their last name (citing them as an abstract source of authority) but female academics by their first name (citing them as a friend). What's in a name? A lot. The literary world is heavily gendered. Look at the VIDA count. Read Jennifer Weiner's interview on *Bustle*. Check out this feature on book covers and tell me it isn't 100% true. I do what little I can to help alleviate the problem. One of my standards as a critic is to spend just as much time covering literature by women as I do literature by men. I look forward to the day when I'm making decisions at a major magazine or press and can help on a larger scale. But I slipped up yesterday, and to anyone who may have been offended, I apologize. ---- Returning to 'Blossom' by April Bernard, which appears in the Spring/Summer 2014 issue of *Salmagundi*. Let's look at it stanza by stanza. First we have three beautiful, warm images.
White, smudged like pastel on paper, like the orchard May-blurred on the hillside White like the light in the door as it opens
Then we move to something still white, but differently toned, touched with a note of death:
White as the robes of T’ang mourners in the scroll where the landscape slides into script, vertical calendar of a dead man’s life White as the page these lines sit upon puckering the rice paper with brush-strokes that this side, the side that is life, has drawn
By this point we've established a motion. Three lines at a time, each stanza beginning with "White". There's a rhythm to it that allows us to concentrate. The rhythm draws us into the poem so that this next stanza can gently shake us:
Gone into light he is now everywhere light is I see and reach but my hands are thick with shadow
Look at that first line again, "Gone into light he is now everywhere light is". The grammar breaks in half. It's a sob. Or rather, it's a stifled sob. What would it take to make this line grammatical? "Gone into light, he is now everywhere light is". That comma, now missing, is the pause the speaker can't allow herself. That pause is an absence. Absence is too painful. The poem enacts the fragility of its own utterance. (Did I lose you? Stay with me.)
He left in spring light He threw blessings like stars of shattered blossoms on our sleeves and hair
These three lines convince me that I *have *to read more of April Bernard. The string of realistic images is shattered, but it's so beautiful that I just don't care. And the poet senses that she's crossed a threshold, that she's reached an imaginative peak, so she breaks the three-line stanza pattern:
It is not that I would drag him back —
Self-consciousness. The writer knows that she is writing. The speaker knows that she is speaking. And she wonders, "To whom?" and "To what end?" Could we have known until now that this poem was a prayer, a psalm? (If you haven't studied psalm form, read Walter Brueggemann's amazing book *The Message of the Psalms*.) She seems to be saying "I'm not Orpheus. I'm not so unrealistic that I think my art can bring back the dead." But the heaviness of that pause, "—", makes it feel like she has *to convince herself *that this *really *isn't what she wants. So what does she want?
I ask instead that the scent of light carry forward this moment and the next that the brush meet the paper not as blot but as sign So what was formerly shadow may become a whiteness White in the light of the door as it opens, blossom of light perpetual in all places we yet go
I can't add anything to that. Anything I'd try to add would be inadequate. This poem amazes me with its perfect marriage of intelligence and feeling. Read the poem again without all the scaffolding. Thanks for reading, friends. Keep doing your part to support poetry. Buy April Bernard's books. Buy a copy of *Salmagundi*. Find your favorite poet's address and write her or him a fan letter. But most of all, keep reading and writing and talking about poetry. Until tomorrow, all. Tweet

entry.title: 'Blossom' by April Bernard
entry.content:
Today I want to look at a poem by April Bernard from the Spring/Summer 2014 issue of *Salmagundi*. Bernard is the author of several poetry collections — including *Psalms*, *Swan Electric*, and *Romanticism* — as well as a novel, *Miss Fuller*. There are several reasons I write this blog. It helps me start each day on a positive and thoughtful note. It helps me get some writing exercise in before a long day of dealing with words that aren't mine, some of them exciting, most of the not. But one of the key reasons I write the blog is that *it keeps me open to discovery*. It's so easy to just say, "I've got my Auden and my Yeats and my Olds and my Dickinson. That's all the poetry I need." But by forcing myself to look outward, to look at what's new in the world, I'm constantly at the ready to receive whatever good life has to offer. Don't get me wrong, I'm not one of those "I love *EVERYTHING!*" people. For every poem and poet I feature here there are ten or twenty I've passed by without comment. Some I passionately dislike, some I really don't care either way. But when I do like something, I know it. It's this splash of cold water in the face. It's someone pulling your hair. Sometimes it's a one-off thing: yesterday I read a poem by Joan Hutton Landis but I don't think I'll go out actively seeking the rest of her work. And then other times it's deeper, more of a connection. It's how I've felt about Devin Johnston's poetry, which I discovered while writing on the blog. Two days ago I didn't even know the name April Bernard and now I'll be looking for it on every shelf for the rest of my life. That's discovery. I'll have to talk more about this poem tomorrow (EDIT: Here's the followup post). Here's 'Blossom', by April Bernard:
White, smudged like pastel on paper, like the orchard May-blurred on the hillside White like the light in the door as it opens White as the robes of T’ang mourners in the scroll where the landscape slides into script, vertical calendar of a dead man’s life White as the page these lines sit upon puckering the rice paper with brush-strokes that this side, the side that is life, has drawn Gone into light he is now everywhere light is I see and reach but my hands are thick with shadow He left in spring light He threw blessings like stars of shattered blossoms on our sleeves and hair It is not that I would drag him back — I ask instead that the scent of light carry forward this moment and the next that the brush meet the paper not as blot but as sign So what was formerly shadow may become a whiteness White in the light of the door as it opens, blossom of light perpetual in all places we yet go
You can find this and more poems on the *Salmagundi* website. Do yourself and your literature-loving friends a favor and buy a copy of *Salmagundi* online or at your local bookstore. Get a subscription and save a few bucks. I'm gonna write a post sometime in the next couple months listing the journals and magazines I recommend subscribing to, and *Salmagundi* is definitely going to be on it. Alright, friends. Un abrazo. Until tomorrow. (Read part 2...) Tweet

entry.title: 'Intermission' by Joan Hutton Landis
entry.content: Today I want to look at 'Intermission' by Joan Hutton Landis, from the Spring/Summer 2014 issue of *Salmagundi*. *Salmagundi* is a bit more academic than some of the other journals / magazines I've looked at. There's a really interesting and *thorough *essay by Adam Philips about Freudian psychoanalysis and poetry. There's a fantastic intro to John Berryman's *Dream Songs *by Henri Cole. And there's a special feature on Patrick Leigh Fermor, whose travel writings have been getting a lot of attention lately. I highly recommend you read Ruth Franklin's tribute to the late Stanley Kauffmann. Back to poetry. Joan Hutton Landis is the author of *That Blue Repair*, published by Penstroke Press. She has three poems in this issue of Salmagundi, and I have to confess that I wasn't crazy about the first two. No wait, sorry: there are four poems! That's right. I enjoyed the first poem entitled: 'First Poem'. She takes one of her childhood poems and puts it in a frame of new poetry. So it was the second and third of four poems that I wasn't crazy about. Those two were in a completely different mode than the first poem. They're very learned, very playful with language, but almost to the point of indulgence. She writes "Chests hold glistering coins." Why "glistering"? Who is adding that Middle-English twist when talking about Arabian treasures? Who is it pouring out all this learning throughout the poems? Who is reading *The Golden Bough*, traveling in Beirut, speaking eloquently of Wahabi aesthetics and Glenn Gould? The sense that there wasn't a character, or a least *there wasn't a character I liked*, turned me sour on those two poems. That's probably unfair. I bet people who like Maryanne Moore will really enjoy those two poems. I don't really get Maryanne Moore. And then there's this last poem, 'Intermission'. The speaker has gone alone to a play. He's caught in the crowd of theater-goers as they make their way out of the packed house for some air on 42nd street. The woman in front of him reaches behind her, without looking, and starts tickling his stomach. She turns around and is embarrassed to find that the speaker isn't her husband. She's a newlywed. The speaker plays it cool, says something suave and disarming. But then we're told it was a memory. It all happened fifty years ago, before he married Myra (who was his "best woman friend" all those years ago and didn't go to the play because she had shingles). Myra's great, the speaker insists. "I still / like her" (awesome use of enjambment!). She's got a fun sense of humor — she uses phrases like "frock incarnadine" and "orotund vacuity" and loves to tell jokes that are absolute groaners. But he's been unable to forget that encounter fifty years ago. There was some kind of transfer of energy in that newlywed's touch. He's cursed because he got to feel her animal affection without any of the sobering roundness that comes with actually *knowing *a person. The question for him is, *Has the persistent memory of that moment corrupted my marriage*? *Why haven't I been able to forget that moment, and what does that say about my relationship to my wife*? He concludes that the "sacred and profane" can exist together, though which was sacred and which profane — the encounter or the marriage — is hard to tell. It's an interesting question, an interesting look into a psyche. Each character in this little drama is interesting. And then there's the crucial added layer of complexity that Myra, with her groaner jokes and Shakespearean language, reminds me an awful lot of Joan Hutton Landis in those second and third poems that I'd disliked so much. Is Myra a stand-in for Landis? How is Landis using this poem to explore male sexuality from a woman's perspective? Does she buy the speaker's means of recusing himself? Do we? Go get yourself a copy of *Salmagundi*. You'll be glad you did. Tomorrow I'll be looking at a poem by April Bernard. Until then!**

entry.title: Looking further into Robert Duncan
entry.content:
I can finally share that exciting news! I've accepted a position as an Assistant Managing Editor at Asymptote, a journal of international literature. It's a very exciting opportunity. It may mean I'll be adjusting my schedule here on the blog. I might need to find time during my lunch hour to write (as I'm doing today), or I might even start writing and posting in the evenings. In any case, I'll make it work. Yesterday I read Robert Duncan's 'Often I Am Permitted to Return to a Meadow', which I first encountered in the Norton Anthology of *Postmodern American Poetry*. It's a complex poem. Something I'd like to keep asking as I investigate this and other poems in the Norton Anthology is: What exactly *is* the postmodern, and what makes *this poem *postmodern? Most of this poem strikes me as very Modernist, in the style of T.S. Eliot and Ezra Pound. The allusions in the fourth and fifth stanzas to "the First Beloved", "the Lady" and the "Queen Under the Hill" especially remind me of Eliot's more religious poems like 'Ash Wednesday' and the *Four Quartets*. There's a really great passage from Lisa Jarnot's biography of Robert Duncan that explains the complex anthropological and religious allusions that Duncan is making. Here's Jarnot:
Duncan's interest in Celtic myth came partly from the fact that he knew his biological family, the Duncans, to be of Celtic origin. He used the game in this poem [*the Celtic game of "ring a round of roses"*] to springboard to two other ideas— that of "the lady" and that of "the dead." For the Celts, the Queen Under the Hill was Brigit, for whom fires were burned in worship. As noted in *The Golden Bough*, "like Minerva, Brigit was a goddess of poetry and wisdom...Brigit was the patroness of bards, physicians, and smiths."  Secondarily, Duncan saw this Lady as Persephone of Greek myth, the Queen of the Dead. At this point in the poem, he created a composite "Lady" of at least three myths– the Celtic Brigit, the Greek Persephone, and the Christian Mary, (with further manifestation as Eve and Sarah), and as Duncan pointed out in a lecture in 1959, she was also Morgan Le Fay of Arthurian legend.
Jarnot makes a very convincing case for Duncan's erudition. But it strikes me that the poem isn't nearly as academic feeling as most of Eliot's poems. One of my favorite Eliot poems is 'Marina' (it's there, just scroll down) because he manages to temper his erudition with musicality and imagery. It's one of the few Eliot poems that doesn't feel anxious or overly professorial. I feel like Duncan does the same thing here. But even if you explain the allusions, there's still the question of the syntax breaks. You have to stretch your imagination to assemble sentences out of Duncan's phrases. What exactly is happening there? How does that broken or jolting quality relate to the enclosed garden imagery? And about that enclosed garden, the *hortus conclusus*. Very often the *hortus conclusus *is a symbol of the Virgin Mary, but it is also a symbol of the contemplative life, of peaceful (and therefore threatened) beginnings, and of Eden. Jarnot explains that it is also very likely Machpelah. In Genesis 2:8-9, Abraham is looking for a place to bury his wife Sarah. He approaches the Hittites  —
listen to me and intercede with Ephron son of Zohar on my behalf so he will sell me the cave of Machpelah, which belongs to him and is at the end of his field.
Duncan seems to be activating all of these meanings at once. Permission is granted to return to a place of origin which is also a place of burial. Who gives permission? And what is the form of this returning? Are we talking about memory? About poetry? This is one of those poems that rewards reflection and investigation. It seems bottomless. I might return to it again, but probably not for a couple of days. I need to expand my sense of the postmodern. Maybe there's another way into this poem that somebody else's poem can show me. Until tomorrow, then. Ciao for now!

entry.title: 'Often I Am Permitted to Return to a Meadow' by Robert Duncan
entry.content:
I've just started reading through the nearly 1000 pages long Norton Anthology of *Postmodern American Poetry*. 1000 pages seems like a lot, but I can already tell that many of these poets will leave me cold and so won't occupy too much of my time. The first poet featured is Charles Olson, and for the life of me I can't figure out the appeal of Charles Olson. A friend recommended Ben Lerner, who is the last poet featured in the book, and I don't really get Ben Lerner either. I'm hoping this upcoming course on Modern & Contemporary American Poetry will help open my mind to these different styles of writing.  But Robert Duncan. I *get* Robert Duncan. I read one of his poems and, even before I understand it, I know that I love it. Not all of the poems, but you don't have to love all of a poet's work. Even the poets I most enjoy I enjoy only half the time, at best. "Poet Robert Duncan" by [1]. Licensed under Fair use via Wikipedia. So here's a poem from the anthology, entitled "Often I Am Permitted to Return to a Meadow". I'm going to repeat the title because I think that matters in this case.
Often I Am Permitted to Return to a Meadow as if it were a scene made-up by the mind, that is not mine, but is a made place, that is mine, it is so near to the heart, an eternal pasture folded in all thought so that there is a hall therein that is a made place, created by light wherefrom the shadows that are forms fall. Wherefrom fall all architectures I am I say are likenesses of the First Beloved whose flowers are flames lit to the Lady. She it is Queen Under The Hill whose hosts are a disturbance of words within words that is a field folded. It is only a dream of the grass blowing east against the source of the sun in an hour before the sun’s going down whose secret we see in a children’s game of ring a round of roses told. Often I am permitted to return to a meadow as if it were a given property of the mind that certain bounds hold against chaos, that is a place of first permission, everlasting omen of what is. — Robert Duncan, *Postmodern American Poetry*, Paul Hoover, editor, ©2013, W.W. Norton and Company, Inc, p.30
Unfortunately, I don't have time to really get into the poem this morning; I'll look more closely at it tomorrow. [EDIT: here are my remarks the following day.] I do have some exciting news to share, too, though I'll have to wait until tomorrow to share it. Until tomorrow, then, friends. Un abrazo.
