entry.title: Untitled poem by Michael Ondaatje
entry.content:
Michael Ondaatje is the author of 13 books of poetry — though he is probably best known as the author of *The English Patient*. This untitled poem originally appeared in the Summer 2014 issue of The Threepenny Review.
That poet you scorned
for retiring when he was forty,

then beginning thirty years later
with the same voice and style
The crack in his life invisible

What he said in youth
and approaching death
having the same breath
that precise pitch
unaffected by time

What a wonder I think now
after all those wars and eras
of love he must have passed through

not one gesture altered
as he wrote, as if he always slept
this way beside her

What could we learn
by leaving the color blue
for another?

— Michael Ondaatje, The Threepenny Review, Summer 2014
It's a short poem with a restrained vocabulary, but Ondaatje manages to fit in a dramatic sense of time passing and a whole cast of characters (the "you" who scorned "that poet", a woman "that poet" slept beside, and the poetic speaker himself).

Some of us do love to scorn poets and fiction writers for not changing over their careers. We want to see change because we understand change. We understand it so thoroughly that we've convinced ourselves that we like and value change unequivocally. Constancy of subject or style betrays a frightening and enviable depth of experience, a rooted-ness that most of us don't know or understand.

Who is the "her" in that second-to-last stanza? Is she an allegory for Poetry? Is she the Muse? Or is there some literal woman who inspires him? His wife? A new lover? It could be all of these at the same time, really, but I like the allegorical reading best. Writing poetry is a kind of dreaming while asleep in the arms of one's beloved.

That last stanza really sticks out; I'm not really sure I like it. I think the poem would end more gracefully without it; Ondaatje probably knows that but doesn't want the poem to end gracefully. He wants the final question to hit you on the nose. What does it mean to leave a color for someone else? Or does it mean, "leaving the color blue / for another" color, setting blue aside for red or green or yellow? That second interpretation makes more sense to me. It's about constancy. You can keep creating new work through the years by remaining true to one thing. It reminds me of this stanza by Coventry Patmore:
I vow'd unvarying faith; and she,
  To whom in full I pay that vow,
Rewards me with variety
  Which men who change can never know.
Until tomorrow, all.

entry.title: 'A Psalm of Life' by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
entry.content:
I've written a few thousand words this morning in an attempt to deal with some recent rejections, but I'm having to face the fact that they won't do any good. They're bitter words; they won't make me feel any better. All this submission and waiting and rejection gets really frustrating. It's a good way to live — knowing you're working hard toward something you care about. It's much better than the alternative. But the rejection still sucks. It's not contemporary poetry, but here are the last three stanzas of 'A Psalm of Life', by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. I've found them comforting in the past. They came to mind now.
Lives of great men all remind us    We can make our lives sublime, And, departing, leave behind us    Footprints on the sands of time; Footprints, that perhaps another,    Sailing o’er life’s solemn main, A forlorn and shipwrecked brother,    Seeing, shall take heart again. Let us, then, be up and doing,    With a heart for any fate; Still achieving, still pursuing,    Learn to labor and to wait.

entry.title: Comic Con and Paul Muldoon
entry.content: Yesterday my wife and I went to the Boston Comic Con. I want to share a bit of that experience, but first I want to point out how it ties in to poetry. I've been thinking a lot about this little nugget by Paul Muldoon. It's pretty short, but the TL;DR is that poetry draws more people in for a more fulfilling experience than pop culture does or can. It's pretty delusional. So delusional, in fact, that it must be an attempt at some kind of ultra-cool ironic gesture. No thanks, Paul. So Comic Con: It was the first time I've ever been to any kind of Con. I've spent most of my life being very judgmental of conventions and the sort of people who go to them. But it was a really fun time. A *really *fun time. It was like a cross between a county fair and a Halloween party. Everyone there was really pleasant, obviously just happy to be there. There was this palpable good mood throughout the place. There were a lot of families with small kids, a lot of teenagers in groups, a lot of older guys with antisocial beards and ironic tees, fathers and sons, mothers and daughters, and all of them were having a good time. We spoke with some artists and vendors; I got a really fun Star Wars poster by Aaron Wood. Aaron does these awesome nerd-culture posters in the style of World War II era propaganda posters; you should check them out. The biggest thing was that we got to meet James Marsters from *Buffy *(who it turns out is also from Central California!) and Sean Astin. Yes, that's right: Sean Astin. Said hi to Samwise. Shook hands with Rudy. I was a bit star struck. I felt like I handled meeting James Marsters pretty well. I spoke to James Franco a couple times when I was at Yale and felt like I was fairly calm-ish around him. But meeting Sean Astin — I just couldn't find any words. I guess what I'm trying to get at is that there doesn't have to be this opposition between poetry and pop culture as Paul Muldoon suggests. We can all just like what we like. If the two meet, like when Robert Pinsky read his Promposal poem on the Colbert Report, then that's awesome. But we'll all be the stronger if we don't create these false oppositions. I'm not saying that as a poetry fan you have to go to Comic Con now; but there are lessons to learn there. Lessons about *community, inclusion, expression, and fun*. When's the last time you went to a poetry reading that was fun, Paul Muldoon? Maybe the reason poetry sales are so bad (do the math, Paul) is because so much poetry is *just no fun*.

entry.title: More thoughts on Pessoa
entry.content:
Writing a daily blog has its advantages and disadvantages:

ADVANTAGESDISADVANTAGES
Habitual writing means
I won't slack off.		Mandatory writing means
I can't take a break.
It's great training in writing.My training is embarrassingly
public.
I'm always moving forward.I'm always moving forward.

I'm thinking about that last row especially. I'm always moving on to the next thing, never taking time to come back and reflect. Last night I picked up James Wood's *How Fiction Works* and started reading it through a second time. I had enjoyed it the first time but this time — wow! — I'm *really* enjoying it. I don't know what's changed since I read it a year ago, but I'm so much more ready for what Wood has to say now. Something similar happened when I read *The Catcher in the Rye* this year. I *hated *the book when I was sixteen but absolutely loved it now that I'm almost thirty. These experiences have got me thinking that I need to make more efforts to revisit works of literature. *Being a reader should be about more than just looking for the next big thing. *Being a reader should include knowing how to live with the next big thing once it's arrived.

So I want to go back and look more closely at yesterday's poem. Yesterday I read a poem by Fernando Pessoa and finished my post by saying, "What more can you add to that, really?" After thinking about it over the course of the last 24 hours, it turns out there's *a lot *more you can say. Here's the poem again:
To be great, be whole: don't exaggerate     Or leave out any part of you. Be complete in each thing. Put all you are     Into the least of your acts. So too in each lake, with its lofty life,     The whole moon shines. —*A Little Larger than the Entire Universe*, Fernando Pessoa, translated by Richard Zenith, Penguin Books, ©2006, p.134
What I neglected to connect was that this message ("Be yourself!") is complicated by the fact that Pessoa is writing under a pseudonym. A man who doesn't even exist is telling us that we shouldn't be afraid to exist! A man hiding behind a persona is telling us not to hide ourselves! Is Pessoa ignorant of this self-contradiction, or is it part of his message?

Let's assume that it is part of his message — what then? We could say that it ironically undercuts the poem's stated meaning. Nobody can really "be whole" or "be complete". You can't put "all you are" into your acts because you are irreparably fragmented. It means that Ricardo Reis believes his advice, but Fernando Pessoa doesn't. We should sneer at the advice along with Pessoa; we should kick ourselves a little for finding it so appealing.

That's one way of looking at it. But another way of reading it is that this poem, and the entire Ricardo Reis persona, is one of Pessoa's ways of being whole. Ricardo Reis has to be invented so that Pessoa doesn't "leave out any part of [himself]." The poet, Pessoa, is the moon, and the poem is the lake in which he shines. There are two things about this that appeal to me. 1) It speaks to my growing notion of poetic *pluralism*, the idea that one poem just isn't enough. A poet writes more poems like a bird sings new songs: not because she's striving to create the best poem or the poem to end all poems, but because that's just what she does. So a poem in which the poet is whole doesn't have to be this all-inclusive, autobiographical thing, because there will always be more poems in which the poet can reflect more pieces of herself. 2) It appeals to me because it helped me think these words: *a fiction is a lie that carries truth*. Without the lie of Ricardo Reis, Pessoa couldn't have told this truth. Pessoa needed to break himself apart in order to see what was inside, and in the fragment called Ricardo Reis he found this poem, and in the poem he found himself, and in himself he found.... You see?

There's a lot more I want to say. About drama. About music. I look forward to saying those things in future posts. I look forward, despite the disadvantages, to moving forward. Until tomorrow, then.

entry.title: A Poem by Fernando Pessoa
entry.content:
For today's Translation Thursday read, I had to do a bit of thinking about the title. Nothing about this post's title was easy. First of all, the poem itself has no title, so I chose the ambiguous "A Poem". But more importantly, the author is and is not Fernando Pessoa. Pessoa wrote under several pseudonyms: when this one was published in 1933, readers would have thought it was the creation of Ricardo Reis. Pessoa gave Reis a backstory:
Ricardo Reis, according to his creator, was born in 1887 in Oporto, which became the focal point of the surviving monarchist forces after the founding of the Portuguese Republic, in 1910. In 1919 the monarchists took control of Oporto but were soon defeated, at which point Reis, a royalist sympathizer (his last name means "kings"), fled to Brazil, where he presumably lived out the rest of his days.... —from Richard Zenith's introduction to *A Little Larger than the Entire Universe*, Fernando Pessoa, Penguin Books, ©2006, p.xxii
If you haven't read him, Pessoa is amazing. Zenith's translation is the one to get; it's published by Penguin Books as *A Little Larger than the Entire Universe*. Here's the poem from February 14, 1933, by Ricardo Reis:
To be great, be whole: don't exaggerate     Or leave out any part of you. Be complete in each thing. Put all you are     Into the least of your acts. So too in each lake, with its lofty life,     The whole moon shines. —*A Little Larger than the Entire Universe*, Fernando Pessoa, Penguin Books, ©2006, p.134
What more can you add to that, really? Have a good day, all.

entry.title: 'One Evening' by William Stafford
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'One Evening' by William Stafford (1914-1993), from a new collection called *Ask Me: 100 Essential Poems*. It's not my favorite book, though I can see why others might really enjoy Stafford's poetry. Hell, I can see how I, if I were in a different mood, might really enjoy Stafford's poetry. His most famous poem, the much-anthologized "Traveling Through the Dark", really is amazing.

But I thought William Logan (despite his obsession with poetry as a zero-sum game and his over-writing for comedic effect) nailed it when he said "Stafford possessed a sentimental streak broader than a barn door, and it spoiled a lot of poems" (from Logan's review in the July/August 2014 issue of *Poetry Magazine*). Several of Stafford's nature poems, in my opinion, are marred by the intrusion of an interpreting voice. The poet tries to find meaning in his own observations, rather than letting the reader find the meaning for her- or himself. (This forbearance is one of the things I most admire about Devin Johnston.) 'One Evening' is, I think, one of the better nature poems, though there are several more that I really enjoyed as well. Here's 'One Evening':
On a frozen pond a mile north of Liberal almost sixty years ago I skated wild circles while a strange pale sun went down. A scattering of dry brown reeds cluttered the ice at one end of the pond, and a fitful breeze ghosted little surface eddies of snow. No house was in sight, no tree, only the arched wide surface of the earth holding the pond and me under the sky. I would go home, confront all my years, the tangled events to come, and never know more than I did that evening waving my arms in the lemon-colored light.   —*Ask Me: 100 Essential Poems*, William Stafford, Graywolf Press, © 2014, p. 66
If you're a Wordsworth nut like me, you're probably thinking of the ice-skating passage in *The Prelude*. I really enjoy these kinds of poems that recollect a seemingly insignificant moment and try to relate them to the rest of one's life. I especially like it when they buck our expectations; like a good Shakespearean sonnet, the last lines can twist like a knife. There's the ambiguous twist at the end of Robert Frost's 'The Road Not Taken': "And that has made all the difference." Optimists that we are, we always assume that the difference is a good one, though I think there are signs ("I shall be telling this with a sigh") that it's not so simple.

Stafford does something similar here: I expect him to say in the last stanza that he takes solace from this remembered evening, that he remembers it as a moment of peace before "all my years, the tangled / events to come." But instead he makes an unexpected connection: the poet says "I would... never know more than I did / that evening...." Does this mean that this evening was the height of his knowing, or does it mean that he's always been equally unknowing his entire life? And what kind of knowing are we talking about? What did he know, or not know? And do any of those questions matter compared to the cold, quiet beauty of those first three stanzas? Is there any meaning, anything to know, outside of those images?

entry.title: 'The Vacation' by Wendell Berry
entry.content:
I mentioned Wendell Berry in my post earlier today, so here's a 2012 poem of his that's made available for free on the Poetry Foundation website. (If you haven't explored it yet, poetryfoundation.org is an amazing resource.) Here's 'The Vacation':
Once there was a man who filmed his vacation. He went flying down the river in his boat with his video camera to his eye, making a moving picture of the moving river upon which his sleek boat moved swiftly toward the end of his vacation. He showed his vacation to his camera, which pictured it, preserving it forever: the river, the trees, the sky, the light, the bow of his rushing boat behind which he stood with his camera preserving his vacation even as he was having it so that after he had had it he would still have it. It would be there. With a flick of a switch, there it would be. But he would not be in it. He would never be in it. 
I'm ambivalent about this idea that a person can be in a place but *not really *be there. We all slip into different modes of being at different times — daydreaming, sleep, mindless repetition of a menial task, the full wakefulness of physical exertion. Is any one of those modes *more authentic *than the others? Berry would probably say yes; I would say no. Most of the time, I don't really believe in authenticity. It's worth paying attention, though, to the fact that technology takes us into a different mode of being. I'm not judging whether it's good or bad, but it's definitely different. A piece of technology — whether it's a phone, a camera, a train, or a telescope — conditions our experiences of places and events. For me, it's a pragmatic decision. What do you *want* out of an experience? Taking photos of a rushing river is a distinct pleasure from paddling down the same river in a kayak. Pick your pleasure, and know it. Or (because this is a pleasure, too) don't.

entry.title: Cosmopolitanism, Local Tradition, and Provincialism
entry.content:
Reader BryghtTyger recently left a comment on my post about Cameron Dezen Hammon's 'Math Rock Drummer' regarding the passage highlighted below:
My approach to literature had its roots in my own conservative upbringing in California's Central Valley. I was raised in an electrically self-conflicted combination of liberal Catholicism and small-town provincialism. As long as I wasn't addressing *that*, that beautiful *tension*, I wasn't going to have a healthy relationship with literature or (more importantly) with other people.
BryghtTyger  points out:
There's no need for this conflict. Have you ever read any of the poet Wendell Berry's essays on localism? I also recommend _Slow Food_ by Carlo Petrini (ISBN: 0231128444). He's far to the Left but still makes a case for local traditions.
First of all, BryghtTyger has seen right through me. I *love* Wendell Berry. The Art of the Commonplace is one of my favorite books, as is The Poetry of William Carlos Williams of Rutherford. And while I haven't read Carlo Petrini, I am a fan of Michael Pollan, Eric Schlosser, and Jonathan Safran Foer's writings on food, something of a slow-foodie, and a recently recommitted vegetarian. That's not quite the issue, though. BryghtTyger wants me to know that liberalism and local traditionalism can go hand in hand. They don't need to be in conflict. To that I say: absolutely right, but local traditionalism and provincialism aren't the same thing.

I have no doubt that Carlo Petrini can be "far to the Left but still [make] a case for local traditions". Of course that combination is possible. There's no reason people in rural, traditional societies can't be every bit as liberal as people in urban, multicultural societies (though, I would argue, it is often much harder to do). Conversely, people in urban, multicultural societies can be every bit as conservative as people in rural, traditional societies. What matters is having an open mind and respecting other ways of life, being able to define oneself and one's culture without shooting down all the others. Cosmopolitanism and respect for local traditions are two sides of the same coin. But only an outsider — someone who experiences life from the perspective of exile — could think about defending local traditions in the plural. A provincial (whether from the country or the town or the city) isn't interested in preserving local traditions generally; he's interested in preserving his own local tradition. To the provincial, everything but his own way seems silly, stupid, maybe even evil. I've met people like this in the country; I've met people like this in small and large towns across the US; I've met people like this in New York and London and Paris; I've found it in myself. So while it's true that this conflict between a universalizing liberal perspective and a narrow local commitment doesn't *need *to happen, the fact is that it does happen. It happens all the time, *hic et ubique*.

That's why we need to constantly be re-freshening our perspectives with art and literature and music and (most importantly) good conversation. Notice that I called it a beautiful tension, an electrical combination. I don't think this conflict is a bad thing; it's the only way out of provincialism. For me, acknowledging the tension and engaging with it and being willing to talk about it was a huge step toward becoming more myself and more respectful of other ways of living.

entry.title: 'Country Music' by Michael Robbins
entry.content:
This morning I'm reading 'Country Music' by Michael Robbins, from the July 7 issue of *The New Yorker* (scroll all the way to the bottom; the poems are the only items not given an eye-catching graphic). I usually have mixed feelings about the poetry in *The New Yorker*, but I really enjoyed this one by Robbins. Here's 'Country Music':
God bless the midnight bus depot, the busted guitar case. God bless diazepam, its dilatory grace. God keep Carl Perkins warm and Jesus Christ erase my name from all the files in the county’s database. The dog that bit my leg the night I left the state, Lord won’t you let his vaccines be up to date. West Point to the south of me, Memphis to the north. In between is planted with pinwheels for the Fourth. Smokestack Lightning, Jesus Christ— whatever your name is— bless my fingers on these strings, I’ll make us both famous. How about that, the new moon, same as it ever was. You must’ve been high as a kite when you created us. So hurry, hurry, step right up, there’s something you should see. The sun shines on the bus depot like a coat of Creole pink. God keep the world this clean and bright and easy to believe in and let me catch my bus all right, and then we’ll call it even.   — from The New Yorker website
This poem reminds me a little bit of Howl and of the duke and the king from *The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn*. And there's a bit of a Coen brothers sensibility in there: *Raising Arizona*, *O Brother, Where Art Thou?*, *Inside Llewyn Davis*. Somebody posted on Reddit recently that there doesn't seem to be any funny or whimsical poetry anymore, but of course they were basing this on what can be found in r/ocpoetry. You really do need to go to the professionals for a good comical poem. Michael Robbins can do it, Kanye can do it, Ogden Nash knew how to do it. And since they're pros, they can use their humor to make serious points. Who hasn't made the bargain: "God keep the world this clean and bright / and easy to believe in / and let me catch my bus all right, / and then we’ll call it even"? It's fun to look down on this Chaplinesque tramp character, and it's revealing too. But mostly it's fun. Michael Robbins is on Tumblr and Twitter. He is the author of Alien vs. Predator (Poets, Penguin) and the soon-to-be-released The Second Sex.

entry.title: 'Homage' by Noelle Kocot
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Homage' by Noelle Kocot, from her 2011 book, The Bigger World. This is one I picked at random off the library shelves, and I'm glad I did. All of the poems in this book are written in a sort of fairy-tale style. They are short, somewhat surreal narratives each of which leaves you with *the sense* that some lesson in human nature has been imparted. Here's 'Homage':
Rick was a polyamorous shaman, Who moonlighted as a detective. He had quite a lot of women All over the country. Rick Liked to hunt wild mushrooms In the starlight. Once he saw Two giraffes with necks intertwined, And he thought, "How nice would It be if there were three, or even Five!" Rick traversed many lands, And he also traversed the red Acres of language in the form Of many books. He liked to read Cookbooks, mainly, because he Enjoyed looking at the pictures, Especially cookbooks with a lot Of mushrooms. Once when one of Rick's women started blubbering, He blew pipe smoke on a tiny bug. "Ha! This rigid pantomime has Got to end. The solitary tear Of a good drama is one thing, But this is quite another!" And So the woman stopped, and she Snuggled up to Rick. Their lungs Filled with air, as they listened to The song of the blue blue warmth.    — *The Bigger World*, Noelle Kocot, Wave Books, © 2013 by Noelle Kocot, pp. 11-12
Poems like this make me wish I knew more about narratology. I love the way it jumps from general characterizing statements ("was a polyamorous shaman", "had quite a lot of women") to very specific single-instance stories ("Once he saw", "Once when one of / Rick's women started blubbering"). There are, I have no doubt, specific terms for these sorts of differences. I love the way inconsequential details take on significance just by their being included: the giraffes, his side-career as a detective, the tiny bug. Rick wants more of everything *except tears*. One giraffe isn't enough, one book isn't enough, one career isn't enough, one woman isn't enough, but one tear is plenty. It bothers me that I don't know where to go from here in my reading, but maybe that's a quality I really like in poems. Sure, I love it when a beautiful poem means something that I recognize as true, but I also love when a beautiful poem is just on the edge of meaning something, when I can only just make out the shape of something at the bottom of it but can never quite tell what. That, too, feels like a kind of truth.

entry.title: 'Painting Exhibition' by Xi Murong
entry.content:
2013TIBE Day5 Hall1 Xi Murong" by 玄史生 - Own work. Licensed under CC0 via Wikimedia Commons.
During my commute into downtown Boston this morning, I reread my favorites from the most recent issue of Poetry East. I can't recommend this issue of Poetry East highly enough. There's some great poetry from Shu Ting, Wislawa Szymborska, and Xi Murong, among others. For today's Translation Thursday post, I want to share one of my favorites by Xi Murong, translated by Angela Ball and Jianqing Zheng. Here's the poem, 'Painting Exhibition':
I know All that is beautiful Will never Stay for Anyone So I hang My love and grief On the wall For show and For sale
Read that first stanza by itself and think about all the things she could have said afterward. "Beautiful things don't last so: 1) I'll immortalize them with my art; 2) I'll just give up; 3) I'll write about the ugly things that *do *last; 4) Carpe diem!" The list, I'm sure, could go on. But she chooses to talk about money. Is it that she's given up on beauty? She seems to be saying that beauty isn't real, or isn't lasting, so you might as well make a buck with whatever you're able to assemble from your life. Maybe she's contrasting beauty with 'love and grief', as though they didn't belong in the category of  the beautiful. This puts a lot of weight on "My", a level of particularity in subtly contrast with the abstract "All that is beautiful". The implied metaphor — that parts of her life are hanging on the walls — makes this self-sacrifice (or self-betrayal) all the more poignant.  This interpretation feels true to me, but I have no doubt there are others. It's amazing that so small a poem can reward continued reflection. Unfortunately, it's hard to find poems by Xi Murong or Shu Ting in English, whereas there are translations available by their male contemporaries like Gu Cheng, Duo Duo, and Bei Dao. Angela Ball and Jianqing Zheng have done great work with this poem; I hope they do more, and I hope others follow their lead.

entry.title: My Bright Abyss by Christian Wiman (Part 2)
entry.content:
I want to share a paragraph from Christian Wiman's *My Bright Abyss: Meditation of a Modern Believer* and talk a bit about what it has to say about poetry. At this point in the book (the last chapter) Wiman has been reading through Robert Browning's 'Childe Roland to the Dark Tower Came'. Roland has just come to the Dark Tower, where he is surrounded by "all the other knights, who have made their way to this place—the price of entry to which, [Roland] realizes all too clearly, is death" (p. 173). It is of course relevant to Wiman's own story. Wiman is dying of inoperable cancer. Roland's last act before death is to raise his "slug-horn" to his lips and blow one last note. Here's how Wiman interprets Browning's poem:
   Triumph or defeat? Redemption or oblivion? The knight knows he's going to die, but he is "dauntless." He is at the edge where all human action fails, and he is acting. Auden once described poetry as "the clear expression of mixed feelings": this is the clear expression of an ambivalent action. Or no, not ambivalent. The very opposite of that, in fact. The knight's last action is inscrutable, unknowable, but it is also mysteriously decisive. It is, like a poem, so sealed in by and replete with meaning that there is nothing outside of the act to translate it: it is only—*it is utterly*—itself. To fling yourself into failure; to soar into the sadness by which you've lived; to die with neither defiance nor submission, but in some higher fusion of the two; to walk lost at the last into the arms of emptiness, crying the miracles of God.      — *My Bright Abyss: Meditation of a Modern Believer*, Christian Wiman, Farrar, Straus and Giroux, © 2013, p. 174
A poem is an action, a cry. How much meaning can a cry contain? "Not much," you might think. "A cry is pure voice. There's no reason in it. Babies can do it; how meaningful could it be?" But its universality is precisely why it is meaningful. The cry is pure form, a raw assertion of humanness. Just as every word spoken or written in English is an assertion of Englishness and every word spoken or written in Chinese is an assertion of Chineseness, every cry is an assertion of humanness. The cry, no matter what is being cried, says, "I am." The blast of Roland's "slug-horn" is the transformation of his breath into music. His breath, his life, becomes music to assert that *he lives, he is*. Every poem does the same. And why assert our existence, and to whom? "God," Wiman would say. Fine with me. I would probably say "the Universe" or "Existence" or "Humanity", but I think Wiman and I mean very nearly the same thing. As Wiman says, the cry is "neither defiance nor submission, but ... some higher fusion of the two". What a beautiful definition of poetry, though I might tweak it a little: *a higher fusion of defiance and praise*. Ah, there's always too much to say. A criticism of Wiman: he leaves practically no room open for light or incidental verse. But whatever; that's just not his style. As much as I wrestled with Wiman's Christian vision of the world, I would read it again. It said a lot of things I've been thinking about; it just said them in ways that I didn't want to hear. I need to get over that prejudice. Tomorrow I'm going to read something fun, that's for damn sure. Until then, everybody.

entry.title: My Bright Abyss by Christian Wiman (Part 1)
entry.content:
It's tough to review Christian Wiman's *My Bright Abyss: Meditation of a Modern Believer*. I think I need to recuse myself. First things first, though: this is a really interesting book to read as a poet. That's why I picked it up in the first place; I got it at the library the same I day I got Richard Blanco's For All of Us, One Today. Poetic biography — in which a poet's work is placed within her or his life narrative — is one of my favorite genres. (I highly recommend Dante's Vita Nuova and Richard Ellmann's Yeats: The Man and the Masks.) Wiman has some very interesting analyses of his own poems, locating his religious and poetic impulses in the same complicated source. Which is not at all to say that his poems are hymns. Here's a much darker toned poem that I was blown away by.  It's titled "Commute (I)":
O the screech and heat and hate we have for each day's commute, the long wait at the last stop before we go screaming underground, while the pigeons court and shit and rut insolently on the tracks because this train is always late, always aimed at only us, who when it comes with its blunt snout, its thousand mouths, cram and curse and contort into one creature, all claws and eyes, tunneling, tunneling, tunneling toward money.    — *My Bright Abyss: Meditation of a Modern Believer*, Christian Wiman, Farrar, Straus and Giroux, © 2013, p. 88
Second, Wiman's engagement with his own mortality is striking. Wiman is dying of untreatable cancer. It's noble, really, the dignity and clarity of feeling with which he approaches his own death. Not to say that he's Stoic — by no means. He's fully engaged with his own suffering, which he occasionally describes in stomach-churning detail, and the suffering that his death will bring to his wife and children. It's tempting to think Wiman is returning to the Christian faith of his childhood for comfort in the face of death, the easy relief of belief. That's not the case, but even if it were *could you blame him*? So here's where I have to recuse myself: I find Wiman's Christianity aggravating to the point of distraction. He comes from West Texas, I come from California's Central Valley — similar worlds with similar languages. "The world" exists opposite "God". "Human love" isn't real compared to or only draws its reality from "God's love". All those atheists are just so sad and angry and lost without faith in God (though, of course, you've never met a single atheist, or if you have she's lived in a town surrounded by people who think she's going to Hell so how exactly could she not be sad and angry and lost?). And here's one that we desert dwellers love: the liberal "Moderns" in the big cities have forgotten the hard truths learned in the land and the Bible. I wouldn't say I no longer believe in God, but I certainly don't believe in this way of talking about God anymore. There are people who speak this language who are profoundly good people, but *even if it gives them certain strengths then it also gives them certain weaknesses*. It's provincial and inhumane, and I know it from experience to be the foundation for a lot of authoritarian, patriarchal, stultifying nonsense. But here's the thing: I know that Wiman is more subtle and self-conscious about Christianity than anybody I knew back at home. For every statement I just listed as typically Christian, I could find a passage in *My Bright Abyss* that counters it. Wiman always resists easy answers; he even resists the hard answers so that you never feel (as he never feels) on solid ground. My revulsion at his Christian vocabulary is visceral and irrational. So I'm not being an impartial judge. I resent Wiman for using the language of Christianity because it touches a raw nerve, a deep embarrassment that I used to think that way, or perhaps an even deeper fear that I *still* think that way. I'll have to continue this review tomorrow. But here's something that interests me, something that's really at the heart of my writing: dispelling the myth of the impartial judge. As a blogger or reviewer or critic or whatever it is I'm doing here, can I ever really hope to escape from my origins? Can I become cosmopolitan without first becoming more honestly who I am, which is to say, the accumulation of all the things I have been? And if I can escape my origins and become cosmopolitan, is that even a good thing? I think Wiman has a lot to say about that, even if I don't exactly want to hear it the way he wants to say it. More on that tomorrow.

entry.title: 'Hurricane Birds' by Dawn Lonsinger -- a Guest Post by Darrell Dela Cruz
entry.content:
Today I'm featuring a guest post by Darrell Dela Cruz, who runs the poetry analysis blog A Retail Life After the MFA. Darrell says he is open to people telling him that he’s wrong in his analysis – even the poets who wrote the piece.  He’s also a contributor to the Bill Knott Criticism blog, where he analyzes the life’s work of Bill Knott, who died earlier this year. Darrell will be featuring one of my poem analyses on his blog this week (EDIT: here's the link!). But until then, here's Darrell's look at 'Hurricane Birds' by Dawn Lonsinger:
Click to Expand
This poem is a mixture of image and narrative, and by the style of the poem – a very upfront, visually focused poem, the end of the poem comes as a surprise.
So the poem starts in medias res from the perspective of the speaker, “In the eye of the storm we came / up out of basements and found sea birds in our yards—" The key with the first two lines is the communal nature of the speaker.  The “we” and “our” brings a bigger, yet personal setting with the image of “backyards.”  Why?  They are survivors of an event which the communal speaker emphasizes.
And as to parallel, there’s also a community of birds which mimic reconstruction, “gulls and terns stockpiling debris, and frigate birds gliding / flawless over the interstate.”  I think the key words in these lines is “flawless” – yes, the action happening seems like recovery and everything fits in the right place, but “flawless” doesn’t.  The idea of “without flaw” happening in these lines seems a bit cynical on one hand, but a bit ironic on the other.  It’s here where the authorial intrusion comes in as perspective rather than observer.
“A white ibis crawled out of / the gutter and loosed its looped limbs into the air.”  Note how precise and focused the image is to the singular and also the alliteration as well – the further the poem goes the more surreal the images become, but also the more barbed the descriptions become as well.  Then this statement “Petrels and doves swarmed wet parking lots” seems a bit more curt in tone.  The more expansive the scene gets, the more it is inescapable due to the amount of “hurricane birds” serving as a reminder of the hurricane.
“What glistened overwhelmed us, swallows rising / like a sheet over the injured.”  So the ending is a surprise because the simile seems so obvious but was sort of lost due to the constant images of birds.  But it makes sense, right?  The poem starts out from this communal speaker and ends with the community “overwhelmed” and when the swallows rise then the image – the insight – of the situation becomes actualized by “sheet over the injured” – does this mean dead? Not necessarily.  The part that people don’t want to see, but know exists – note that the damage of place wasn’t described or the emotional damage of “survivors” – just the description of birds reconstructing as though nothing was ever amiss.  --- Make sure to check out A Retail Life After the MFA and follow along on Twitter @RetailMFA!

entry.title: 'Still-Life with Two Dead Peacocks and a Girl (after Rembrandt)' by Diane Seuss
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Still-Life with Two Dead Peacocks and a Girl (after Rembrandt)' by Diane Seuss, from The Missouri Review's new summer issue. This is the second poem by Diane Seuss that I've read here on the blog, and I've quickly become a fan of her work. This poem is based on a painting by Rembrandt. As Seuss explains on The Missouri Review website, she wrote the poem with some rules in mind. "I placed some strict limitations upon myself: 14 lines, 17 syllables per line (what Allen Ginsberg called “American Sentences”), and no “I.”" Anyway, without too much more ado, here's 'Still-Life with Two Dead Peacocks and a Girl (after Rembrandt)':
She comes out of the dark seeking pie, but instead finds two dead peacocks. One is strung up by its feet. The other lies on its side in a pool of its own blood. The girl is burdened with curly bangs. A too-small cap. She wanted pie, not these beautiful birds. Not a small, dusky apple from a basket of dusky apples. Reach in. Choose a dusky apple. She sleepwalked to this window, her body led by its hunger for pie. Instead this dead beauty, gratuitous. Scalloped green feathers. Gold breast. Iridescent-eyed plumage, supine on the table. Two gaudy crowns. She rests her elbows on the stone windowsill. Why not pluck a feather? Why lean against the gold house of the rich and stare at the bird’s dead eye? The girl must pull the heavy bird into the night and run off with it. Build a fire on the riverbank. Tear away the beautiful feathers. Suck scorched tough dark meat off of hollow bones. Look at her, ready to reach. She’d hoped for pie. Meringue beaded gold. Art, useless as tits on a boar.
Before I even begin to interpret the poem I love it. I love the playfulness of the language, the sense of discord between the girl's sweet tooth and the artist's baroque subject. But the poem does have some interesting things to say (or it invites the reader to say some interesting things) about art. What is art for? Why do we come to it? So many times when I travel to a foreign city (London, Paris, wherever) I'll check out the museums. Why? What is it we expect to find there? One answer is "entertainment". Perhaps this is analogous to the pie that the girl wants. But even if there's something more to be found other than entertainment, will someone who comes seeking entertainment really even be able to find it? Put less (or more) awkwardly — if we come looking for food but instead find beauty, will we appreciate the beauty, or will we simply try to eat it?

Thus end my musings. They feel even more useless than usual today. Though it is later than I usually write and I'm a little hungry, so maybe that's just bringing my mood down a bit. Maybe there's some pie in the kitchen....

entry.title: 'Storm and Sturgeon' by Devin Johnston
entry.content:
I went to a poetry reading last night in Cambridge, MA. It was... I don't really know what to say about it. A few of the poets who read were interesting or compelling in their presentation, but I couldn't tell exactly what they were getting at other than *so much anxiety*. The others weren't really interesting in presentation or subject matter. I'm lucky that I've attended some very good poetry readings. I heard Joyce Carol Oates read a poem of hers that made the audience crack up with laughter. I heard some amateur poets in Fresno, CA who really just nailed it. Biggest of all for me, I saw Turner read from *Here, Bullet *when I was a student at Fresno State and he was just starting to teach there. He was amazing. And then of course I've seen amateur and professional productions of Shakespeare that were incredibly funny and moving. Poetry *can *keep you on the edge of your seat. Poetry can *communicate*. That's why even though last night's reading was a bit of a disappointment, I'll keep going back to readings on the off chance that someone might have something to say. Because I would very much like to hear it. So, for today's poem. I've been reading Devin Johnston's 2011 book *Traveler* (a beautiful little book published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux). I have some negative criticisms, but I feel like all of them are unfair. Sometimes I'll read a poem that's very specific to Johnston's experiences in the Midwest or his travels in Scotland and the unfamiliar place names and vocabulary will turn me off. But I've found that, when I bother to look up the unfamiliar words and references, Johnston is being very considerate in his choices. Knowledge always adds to the experience of his poems. I've been thinking that poetry should be, as Poetry East editor Richard Jones puts it, "immediate, accessible, and universal". But Johnston makes me think a real craftsman can ask you to go further, to participate and work more as a reader. Here's one of the poems I loved immediately, though it certainly has its own mysteries to explore. It's called 'Storm and Sturgeon':
When a thunderstorm    trundles down the Wabash, revealing the form    of flow in every flash, northerlies lash    the walls that keep us warm, rummaging grass,    scattering flock and swarm. Beneath an icy    column thick as phlegm, this cold coyote    of our river system peers through a scrim    of silt and leaf debris as lighting skims    the shoals of Harmonie. As each percussion    shakes the sturgeon's bladder— a loose vibration    felt in fleshy matter— her switch-tail stirs    beds of hibernation, bottom dwellers    lost in cloud formations.
I want to unpack this a little. There's the first level of understanding the references. I've lived my entire life in California and New England. Even though I've had the good fortune to go on three long drives across the country, references to the Wabash and Harmonie are lost on me. But when I do look them up I understand that this poem is located in a very specific place — New Harmony, Indiana. New Harmony was founded by German immigrants, which is why Johnston uses the German "Harmonie". But of course "German immigrants" is being much too simplistic. They were religious refugees, the Harmony Society. The same group founded the town of Harmony, Pennsylvania. They were fond of music. All of a sudden word choices like "percussion" make sense in a different way. There are so many ways to interpret this poem, even with the little we've dug up so far. Is the thunderstorm supposed to be God? His thundering voice shakes through the flesh of the mortals below, mortals like the Harmony Society? Or is it more about history in the way that I think Johnston's poem 'Telephone', the strange contingency and interconnectedness of history? Are all of us are just "bottom dwellers / lost in cloud formations", unable to make any real sense of the forces moving at higher levels than ourselves? I highly recommend Devin Johnston's *Traveler*. He has several more books available, and FSG is bringing out a new collection in March of 2015. Have a great Friday, everyone.

entry.title: 'An Impression' by Gu Cheng
entry.content:
Yesterday I went to the Boston Public Library and pulled out a couple books of poetry I've had my eye on — Devin Johnston's Traveler and Tracy K. Smith's Life on Mars. I'm excited to read both of those. I grabbed a couple of other books that looked interesting (I'm a sucker for a book cover and a good title), one of which I read last night and found almost impossible to read. I try to always be open to surprises when I read, but this book just had absolutely nothing I could grab onto. I couldn't tell you what a single poem was about. I could get super negative about that, but instead (Pollyanna that I am) I let it remind me how *good* good poetry really is. If things can go *this wrong*, it's amazing when things go right. Too much positivity? Yeah, it's a bit saccharine. But that's part of the process, that back and forth between saccharine and cynical. Everything I know about writing I learned from what little I've misunderstood about tacking. That's an exaggeration of course, but that's all part of it. Today's my first Translation Thursday poem! Though it's not the first translated poem that I've covered (see here and here), it is the first that I've done on a Thursday, and it's the first to which I'll affix #translationthurs when I post on Twitter. I'm looking at 'An Impression' by Gu Cheng, translated from the Chinese by Ginny MacKenzie and Wei Guo. It appears in the absolutely amazing Spring 2014 issue of Poetry East. Here's the poem:
The sky is gray The road is gray The building is gray The rain is gray Through this dead gray Come two children One in bright red One in tender green
Isn't the way those colors pop in the end just amazing? The poet lulls you into this aural and visual rhythm (gray...gray...gray...gray...gray) and then breaks it open in a burst of color right at the end. Kudos to the translators Ginny MacKenzie and Wei Guo for really nailing this. Its simplicity reminds me so much of Ezra Pound's In a Station of the Metro. But it's not really that simple is it? We move from the sky, to the road, to the building, to the rain. Why that order? Why wouldn't rain be after sky? Maybe it's so that the eye moves in a particular direction, from the horizon of sky along the road to the building immediately in front of us to the rain that falls on us. The rain isn't rain in the abstract, as it would be if it came after sky. It's the rain that's soaking our clothes and our hair or tapping nervously on our umbrella. All these gray things are all around us, falling on us, until the two children enter. Gu Cheng died in 1993. He was only 37 years old. He was one of the Misty Poets, a group that includes Shu Ting, whose poems are also featured in this issue of Poetry East. (Really, buy a copy, or save $5 and subscribe.) If you'd like to read more Gu Cheng, there's a poetry collection available called Nameless Flowers. Have a great day, all.

entry.title: Poetry Doesn't Matter
entry.content:
*The New York Times *wants very badly to convince you that poetry matters. Seven poets and critics, including Pulitzer winners Tracy K. Smith and Paul Muldoon, took time out of their busy poetry schedules to convince us that poetry matters. Even William Logan came out of his troll cave to make the case that poetry matters.

But of course *poetry doesn't matter*. It doesn't matter in the ways that AIDS research matters, it doesn't matter in the way that fixing the education system matters, it doesn't matter in the way that making sure your kids are fed a healthy breakfast each morning matters.

But just because it doesn't matter doesn't mean we should stop doing it. Not everything we do has to matter in some profound way. It's OK to do things *just because you like them*. For me these "poetry matters" arguments are evidence of a deep shame in the face of pleasure (possibly because so many poets depend upon the oh-so-serious academic institutions?). Can we please stop being ashamed of the pleasure that reading and writing bring? Can we please be a bit more hedonistic about poetry?

And a little bit less religious? David Biespiel tweeted about his contribution to *The New York Times' *poetry panel and received this reply among others:

@DavidBiespiel @kenyonreview Excellent piece! Very well said. But how to get non-poets to read poetry? Your essay in the NYT might help.

— Cortney Davis (@nurseprolife) July 21, 2014
Why should we care whether "non-poets" read poetry? Is that what all this is about? Converting people? William Logan writes: "When it is once more taken seriously in the schools, poetry will be loved again...." What is this golden age of poetry appreciation that we're trying to get back to, and why must poets and poetry lovers be so desperate for its second coming? How will I recognize the poetry messiah when he comes?

If poetry matters *to you*, good *for you*. Enjoy it. Buy books by the poets you like. Talk about the poems you like, or don't. But please appreciate that there are people who really like jai alai, love to play jai alai with their jai alai-loving friends, don't really care for poetry but are just nuts about jai alai, and note that they don't bother writing en masse into *The New York Times* to tell everyone — in some weird preemptive act of self-defense — why it matters. Because it doesn't matter in some profound sense, and neither does poetry, and that's ok.

entry.title: 'Still Life' by George Bogin
entry.content:
I'm having one of those days where I question what I'm doing, how I'm doing it, why I'm doing it. (Warning: I'm about to emote, so you can just scroll down to the poem if you're just here for the poem.) Maybe it's just because I didn't get much sleep? So much of a negative affect is simply a manifestation of physical strains like hunger or fatigue. But I feel like this blog is getting away from me a little, like I'm just going through the motions. But maybe that's the point. It's a discipline. It's a discipline of discovery. I've wanted to learn more about contemporary poetry and this blog is my way of doing it. I recognize this malaise, though. I've experienced it before with other of my projects that have collapsed. The important thing right now is not to give in to doubts. My brain's going to give me a thousand reasons why none of what I'm doing is important and it's going to tell me that I should stop. It's going to say: "This should be easy! This should be fun! Why are you doing it if it isn't easy and fun all the time?" But it is a discipline, it is hard. The important thing is to find a way to enjoy the difficulty. I think a word for that is pride. And I am proud of what I'm doing here, strangely enough. Embarrassed sometimes, yes, but always proud. And the embarrassment is less and less every day, and the sense of pride grows. And sometimes you just have to keep your head down and march forward and trust that you made the right decision when you started the thing.

Wow, I'm being so tiresome, huh? Let's get to some poetry.

Even before the series of events that led to me being very tired and a bit cranky and annoyingly introspective I had decided to read 'Still Life' by George Bogin for today's blog post. It appears in the Spring 2014 issue of *Poetry East*, which I can't recommend highly enough. Other journals I've discussed here on the blog so far have been a mixed bag, you know? Each has had a lot of poems that I chose not to cover because they didn't really speak to me. With *Poetry East* it's an opposite case. There are *so many* poems of *such high quality* that I don't want to spoil them for you. Seriously, there's hardly a single poem in this issue that I don't enjoy. Buy a copy.

But to get to the point. Here's 'Still Life' by George Bogin.

A song
is being sung here
of my room
and the objects
in the room.
The room lies
in the arms
of the house
and the house
floats
in the afternoon.
The windows
give on trees
and the
grave late sun
enters.
On the desk
wait
an apple,
a napkin,
a pair of glasses,
a lamp
and a book.
A chair
stands by.
Time brushes
these objects
and shadows
fall from them.
All things
sing the song,
the song
of the sadness
of objects.

I started learning to play the piano when I was about ten years old, and a couple years later I started learning to play guitar. (Yeah, it's my blog, so I'm gonna talk about myself again.) From the beginning, I just wanted to play the music of Nobuo Uematsu on the piano, though like most other kids I got stuck playing from Bastien books. I would sit at the piano and poke around at the keys until I could recreate a melody from Final Fantasy III or Chrono Trigger. When I started playing the guitar (in 1997, the same year George Bogin died) I was more interested in writing my own music. The process of composing music is halfway between invention and discovery. You search for the right note, the note that you hear in your head, the notes that you've heard but never *really* heard. For me, I don't really *write* a song so much as I draw it fully formed from somewhere between silence and noise. That sounds pretentious because it sounds mysterious. But *it is mysterious*. In my very quiet childhood there was a song vibrating in every stifling room and I felt the need to bring it out as melody. The same thing happens with poetic lines. They just sort of appear in my head, fully formed. Who knows how long they've been sitting there, quietly taking shape, before they appear as words. Then I set them down on paper and over the course of several drafts other words crystallize around them with an irrefutable logic, or at least a logic that is irrefutable for me. *The song is always already there.*

Tomorrow I'll read one last poem from *Poetry East* as part of my first Translation Thursday post. (EDIT: Just realized it's only Tuesday, making the previous sentence fairly ridiculous. FML.) I'm gonna get more sleep so that I can be a bit less emotive. Until then.

entry.title: 'Say More, Speak Like Rain' by Arne Ruste
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Say More, Speak Like Rain' by Arne Ruste, a Norwegian poet, novelist, essayist, etc. who as yet has never had a single one of his books translated into English. Olav Grinde translated Ruste's poem for the Spring 2014 issue of *Poetry East*. My wife bought me my copy of *Poetry East *as an anniversary present and it's become one of my favorites in my growing collection of poetry journals.

This is the first of my Motivation Monday posts, and I take as my first point of motivation that *there are so many amazing poems waiting to be found*. There are great poets (some famous, some obscure) writing here in the U.S. and in other countries and languages all across the globe. There's no end of surprise. Keep looking and you'll keep finding. And (amazing to me) there are translators like Olav Grinde who are willing to take on the onerous task of spreading the word, often with no compensation but pride and the knowledge of a job well done.

Lucky for us, Poetry East makes the poem available for free on their website, so I'm going to post it here along with my strong encouragement that you buy a copy of Poetry East online or at your local bookstore. So here's "Say More, Speak Like Rain':

Am I perhaps
the only believer now?
I believe in words

I believe in the carrying capacity
of words in the power of their
relativity

I believe in
the parable, the paradox, the poem
and in the stories

of old men
told over fences, and I
believe in the soft

things of this world, in wood and
clay, that they will outlive
steel and concrete

human things are what I
believe in, the penetrating
power of gentleness

and I believe in things
that take a long time to make,
like trees and books

but I no longer believe
in the good deeds
of this world

I no longer believe in
heroism, I believe
in good-naturedness

and in words spoken by simple people,
simple words woven together
like baskets for carrying

I put my stock
in stamp collectors
and the owners

of small shops and
country inns, carpenters
and flower-women

There are no big
words in this world, only
loudmouths and demagogues

The collapse of words is a conceited fiction
Words hold everything together
Words connect everything.

I believe
in café talk and
in coffee-break talk

I believe in prayers, narrow
strips of words, weightless and golden
burnable, spread to the winds

I believe in
confessions whispered in darkness
and in letters

I believe in ballads and in
curses of a sincere heart
I want words

like deep axe cuts and clinging
mallets. I want
words

like shiny stones in my pocket,
words like thrown arrows
I want words

like the years in a worn down
table. Maybe I am the last
believer now:

I believe in blind man's
never faltering fumbling over a writing
of flaming points


For a long time now I've been looking for ways to express what it is I want out of poetry and art and music and, well, Life. Arne Ruste's poem shows me so much of what I've been looking for. I feel deeply the lines: "I no longer believe / in heroism; I believe / in good-naturedness". A kind word is an act of tremendous power. So is a beautiful phrase, or a true phrase, or a silly phrase.

I love what Ruste is saying about multiplicity, or perhaps *pluralism *is a better word. The title is relevant, of course, but I notice a phrase from the second-to-last line: "never faltering fumbling". This could be easily labeled oxymoronic, but I think it's a beautiful sentiment that *absolves our words from judgment*. Words are things, like a basket, like a stone, like rain. There are no inherently good words or bad words. The more words there are, the richer the world is. Art, literature, music — let there be more of them, more and more and more of them.

I should add, however, that I'm wary of the politics this poem might imply for some people. I don't believe in "simple people", as Ruste puts it. No people are simple. Believing there are such things as "simple people" is a step toward becoming one of the "loudmouths and demagogues" that the poet vilifies. But I won't cast the poem off just because of this. I know that this poem isn't perfect. I know that no poem is perfect. I know that the perfect poem will never be written, and that makes me glad. Because the perfect poem would be the last poem, and there can be no last poem. No arrangement of words is sufficient; we always need more words.

I could just go on and on about this poem. I'll look at a few more poems from the Spring 2014 *Poetry East *this week. Get yourself a copy. Until tomorrow, friends.

link.title: 'Say More, Speak Like Rain' by Arne Ruste

entry.title: 'Falling in Love with a Fiji Mermaid' by Grant Clauser
entry.content: Today I'm reading 'Falling in Love with a Fiji Mermaid' by Grant Clauser, which is one of three poems by Clauser in the latest issue of The American Poetry Review. Clauser provides a helpful explanatory note at the top of the poem: "Fiji mermaids were common gaffs at carnival sideshows. They were usually made by combining the head and torso of a monkey with the tail of a fish." The fictional creature has an interesting history. To the right is one of the least horrifying images of a Fiji mermaid that you can find online. A Fiji mermaid was featured on an episode of *The X-Files *back in 1995, at which point I would have been ten years old, and I've successfully repressed that memory until today when I foolishly plugged "Fiji Mermaid" into Google Images. Anyway, back to the poem. The poem draws on that carnival sideshow tradition that asks you to believe things that simply can't be true and applies it, with powerful effect, to a failing relationship. Love, or the desire to be in love, can make you believe your imagination over your senses. "It's easy to confuse lies / for love, / believe that the palm reader / wasn't out to pick your pocket." Our desires lead us into fantasies. "It's cheap to dream / of such things, / coral meadows where / bull sharks menace / mermaids to their caves. / Where Fiji women toss / their stillborn babies to the sea / and they come back / remade by waves." And this would go on but that "in the end / the carney calls you / back to the midway light. / No time left for fantasy." I've talked before about how much I dislike poem titles, but I think this is a really good one. It could easily have been called "Love Is a Fiji Mermaid" or "Love Is Like a Fiji Mermaid", but that wouldn't have given the same shade of meaning. Saying "Falling in Love with a Fiji Mermaid" shows that falling in love (I want to say "when it's not *really *love" but maybe that's too easy) has little to do with the other person in the relationship. You're falling in love with the dream of love, with the cheap threads of affection for affection that hold you to the other person. And somebody's done the work sewing that mermaid together, and they're looking to make a buck off of you. That's a pretty dark message for a Sunday afternoon, huh? But it's a dark message well stated. And who says there isn't something cheering in the enlightenment that comes from of a hard truth? I was walking to work the other day and saw a very anxious man standing at an intersection, stepping into and out of the busy street to see whether he could make it across to the other side. Can I go now? Can I go now? All he needed to do was wait until the walk sign told him it was safe to cross, but instead he decided to worry and fret and increase his own anxiety. Right then a line of poetry came to me: "Rejoice in the Law." There is some joy in the hard truths, the red hand that signals "Don't": they can free you. So maybe Clauser's poem isn't the worst thing for a Sunday afternoon. There's more from Grant Clauser and many others in the July/August issue of The American Poetry Review. Check it out. Until tomorrow, friends.

entry.title: 'Under the Tree of Idleness' by W.S. Merwin
entry.content:
Today I'm reading another poem by W.S. Merwin from the July/August issue of The American Poetry Review. Yesterday I was talking about how I've learned (a little bit) how to appreciate Merwin's punctuation-less poems. The poem I looked at yesterday, 'Drinking Tea in the Small Hours', was very meditative, very concentrated on a single moment's images and sounds and tastes, but today's poem has a bit of a fairy tale plot to it. So here's 'Under the Tree of Idleness':

This is where I was going the whole time
when they thought I was lost and were looking
for me everywhere I was right here
but as long as they were looking for me
they walked past and never laid eyes on me
it was only when one stumbled on me
by accident that I seemed to have been
found for a moment before I was gone
again following shadows on the leaves
of the oldest limb where they might never
have been noticed but I watched them as though
I was remembering after a long
time without seeing them although that had been
no time in the life of the tree where I
had heard far away a voice calling to
someone and asking what are you doing
until I answered to call it nothing

This poem has so much going on, so many knots that need to be untied. Who are "they"? His parents? (That would make it *so* much like the story of Jesus in the temple as a child.) His friends? Everybody? And how is it that they can never find him until they stop looking for him? That's such a fairy tale detail, like Alice in the sheep's shop in Through the Looking Glass: "The shop seemed to be full of all manner of curious things -- but the oddest part of it all was, that whenever she looked hard at any shelf, to make out exactly what it had on it, that particular shelf was always quite empty: though the others round it were crowded as full as they could hold." It's a dream detail, like how you can't read in a dream.

(Which makes me think: "Why do I assume that the poetic I is a person at all?" Maybe the "I" is the meaning of the poem, or the Meaning of Poems in general, or Meaning in general. You never find it if you look for it; you only ever stumble upon it "by accident" after you've given up the search. And when you do find it it's not found forever: "I seemed to have been / found for a moment before I was gone / again".)

And the really abstract part is in those last few lines. "I / had heard far away a voice calling to / someone and asking what you doing / until I answered to call it nothing". Why does the "I" think that it's being addressed at all? It sounds like someone is calling to someone else, and the "I" interrupts, calling "it"—the thing that "someone" is doing—"nothing". We saw this same strategy of crossed communication in Devin Johnston's 'Telephone'. What is it doing here?

Personally, I'm surprised that I find this poem satisfying. It's still mysterious to me, but it's a pleasant mystery. I like trying different interpretations out, seeing how each one fits or doesn't fit, playing with what each interpretation might imply if it were true. That's part of the joy of poetry.

That's the last of Merwin's poems I'm going to be reading in a little while. Please do consider purchasing a copy of The American Poetry Review online or in your local bookstore. Read poetry, yes, but also be sure to share poetry and talk about poetry and buy poetry. You vote every day with your voice and your dollars. Vote for poetry.

entry.title: 'Drinking Tea in the Small Hours' by W.S. Merwin
entry.content:
Image from poets.org. Photo credit: Matt Valentine
For the longest time I haven't really understood W.S. Merwin. His translation of Neruda's *Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair *has always been one of my favorites, but his own poems—eschewing punctuation, often falling into anticlimax—have left me unsatisfied. And I've found that lack of connection aggravating, because in his interview in the Paris Review he says so much that I agree with. He seems like a kindred spirit, but I just don't *get* him. But there are nine new poems in the July/August issue of The American Poetry Review, and with some of these I finally feel a connection. And I'm sure it has nothing to do with the previous poems not being good enough or not my style. It just took an encounter with Merwin at a new time in my life, in a new place, for me to see a little more than I had before. Here's one of the nine poems, this one entitled 'Drinking Tea in the Small Hours':
An unlabeled green from Korea second pick from the foothills of summer taste of distance and slight rustling of leaves on old trees with names hard to remember as I listen after heavy rain in the night the taste is a hush from far away at the very moment when I sip it trying to make it last in the knowledge that I will forget it in the next breath that it will be lost when I hear the cock crow any time now across the dark valley
The trick for me is to *read slowly and read aloud*. Merwin's omission of punctuation puts the task on the reader to find the pauses that work for her or him. From the context, I feel like you have to put a longish pause after the word "remember", and another after "from far away". But who knows, I could be wrong. Not having punctuation used to bother me, but now I really enjoy that Merwin's given me that freedom as a reader. There's so much to love in this poem. The simple romance of 'unlabeled green', the synesthetic quality of lines like 'the taste is a hush from far away', and the cock crowing in the dark (which reminds me both of Peter's denial of Jesus and Devin Johnston's 'Orpingtons'). It's a very sensual poem built of simple language with no frills or fuss. I highly recommend you buy yourself a copy of The American Poetry Review online or at your local bookstore. The latest issue includes eight more poems by Merwin, the poem 'Pardon My Heart' by Marcus Jackson which I talked about in a previous post, and a lot of other great stuff that I'll be looking at in the next couple days. Have a great day, all. Take some time to read a poem or two. Until tomorrow, friends.

entry.title: For All of Us, One Today: An Inaugural Poet's Journey (part 2)
entry.content:
Yesterday I started looking at Richard Blanco's *For All of Us, One Today: An Inaugural Poet's Journey*, which tells the story of how Blanco came to write the poem for President Obama's second inauguration ceremony. I vented a lot of my negative criticisms about the book, some of them fair and some of them not. But today I want to talk about a few passages in the book that I really thought were excellent.

I griped yesterday that Blanco says *so many* thank yous throughout the book. But it's a good lesson: we should be grateful and we should show it. Our family, our teachers (including, in Blanco's case, the amazing Campbell McGrath), our friends, our coworkers, our fellow citizens. Everybody deserves a good thank you.

One think I love about the book is that, despite the success Blanco had already found as a poet, he still honestly struggles with form. The book includes the two poems he didn't use—"What We Know of Country" and "Mother Country". Blanco explains step by step how he wrote them, where they came from (historically, psychologically, etc.), and *why he couldn't use them*. I really admire that kind of attention to voice and craft, that acceptance that a poem can perform a function, and that some poems are more fit for certain functions than others. By accepting the challenge to write the inaugural poem, Blanco set out on a path of self-discovery:

I realized that for years I had subconsciously believed my work had been well received mostly because of my subject matter as a child of exiles, focused on issues of cultural identity, displacement, and a proverbial search for home.

   But I discovered that it wasn't *what* I wrote about but *how* I wrote about it that made my poems *my* poems, namely, the density of imagery and lushness of language that are signatures of my work. Once that clicked, I knew the task at hand was to revise "One Today" along those lines, not by virtue of altering the subject matter but by infusing it with those same qualities and breathing my voice into it. And—as Sandra Cisneros advised—it was important that I approach the poem with the same loving tone as if I *were* speaking about (or to) my mother.
—*For All of Us, One Today: An Inaugural Poet's Journey*, Richard Blanco, Beacon Press, 2013, pp. 56-7
There are a lot of really good reasons to take on challenges, including creating a better future for yourself. But challenges can also help you see things about your past that you might otherwise have missed. Blanco learned about the impulse that drove his *old* poetry by trying to write a *new* kind of poetry. It's a mark of really admirable emotional and artistic maturity.

And about voice. It's really interesting to watch the poems develop from these more personal reflections in "What We Know of Country" and "Mother Country" to the kind of sweeping, inclusive, prophetic voice of "One Today". Here's a relevant passage:

Finally I grasped the underlying tension I had been searching for in the poem: namely, the wishing for, the striving for the ideal of being or becoming one, not just for a day, but every day. I came to understand the poem as a kind of prayer, an invocation, with an appeal to our higher selves at its emotional center.
—*For All of Us, One Today: An Inaugural Poet's Journey*, Richard Blanco, Beacon Press, 2013, p. 64
It's good to know there are people who still believe that poetry can bring people together. Nobody doubts that oratory can or that song lyrics can, but poetry is sometimes pushed to the side. Blanco gives poetry a place in the world of politics, not politics as a struggle for power but politics as a form of communication and peacemaking. Blanco uses poetry *to enact and embody peace*. It's a powerful example.

Alright friends, I've rambled on just about enough. I'd love to discuss Blanco's book with you if you feel like commenting. I think I'll condense all of this down into a review for Amazon and Goodreads. I don't get many commenters here but I know from experience that Amazonians *love* to hate on each other. Fun stuff. But I'll be back looking at more poems tomorrow. Until then!

entry.title: For All of Us, One Today: An Inaugural Poet's Journey (part 1)
entry.content:
This will be my first book review here on *Tim Reads Poetry*. I want to keep it quick and conversational like my other posts, so I'm going to break my review into two parts over two days. Richard Blanco, if you aren't familiar, is the poet who read at President Obama's second inauguration. I enjoyed the inaugural poem, which is entitled "One Today". *For All of Us, One Today: An Inaugural Poet's Journey* is Blanco's story of how he came to write the poem. It starts with his Cuban ancestry, passes through his poetic training and the tense weeks leading up to the inauguration, and culminates in the reading of the poem itself. One of the best parts about the book is that includes the text of "One Today" and three other excellent poems. Today I want to spill out a lot of my cynicism about *For All of Us, One Today: An Inaugural Poet's Journey*. I'm going to get it all out of my system, because this book does have valuable things to say but they're hard to find amidst all the fluff. Tomorrow I'll focus more on the positive aspects of the book. Blanco seems a bit starstruck -- by himself. A lot of the book reads like an Oscar acceptance speech, a *long* list of thank yous. (Which is very sweet, but, ummm, *why should I care?*) There's a quote from Billy Collins on the back cover: "The high drama here is the backstage look into the pressure and process of writing the poem itself and the thrill of reading it to the world." Not quite, Billy. The book is shaped as follows:
  • Blanco was an engineer and started writing poetry. He was afraid his engineering buddies wouldn't like his poems, but they did!
  • Blanco enrolled in an MFA program focusing on poetry. He was afraid his classmates wouldn't like his poems, but they did!
  • Blanco was asked to write the poem for the second inaugural. He was afraid Americans wouldn't like his poem, but they did!
So Blanco passes test after test. "Do regular people like me?" Yes! "Do celebrities like me?" Yes! The real "high drama" comes from this one question, which hovers over the entire book: "*Does President Obama like me?*" Aaaaand of course he does. "... in May [*after the inauguration*] I'll meet President Obama in the Oval Office and we will speak about his and the First Lady's ongoing commitment to poetry. I will present the president with Sergio's beautiful broadside of 'One Today,' which he'll hang in his back office where he'll say he keeps those things closest to him." But you know what? I need to give the guy a break. Blanco has attained just about the ultimate in bragging rights as far as poets are concerned, so let him brag. He's now up there with names like Robert Frost and Maya Angelou. He's part of American history. He's got this moment to stand up and talk about what he wants to talk about, so let him have it. If he wants to point out how happy he is with himself and say a few heartfelt thank yous along the way, even if that's boring reading, then let him. And it is boring reading, no mistake, and sometimes embarrassingly sentimental, especially the twentieth time he refers to himself as the "inaugural poet". I'm reading *My Bright Abyss* right now and the contrast of Blanco's ecstatic enthusiasm and Christian Wiman's dark night of the soul is almost laughable. But maybe that's my real problem with this book: Blanco doesn't have an ounce of melancholy. He's pure cheer. I just don't understand that personality. I don't understand *how* a person can *be* like that. My distaste for it says more about me than it does about Blanco, perhaps. A sunnier disposition might read Blanco and feel right at home. I need to put myself in that person's shoes for a minute or two and see what there is to see. So that's what I'm gonna do, starting tomorrow. (UPDATE: Part 2 has now been published.)
