entry.title: 'Horse Fantasies' by Alice Derry
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Horse Fantasies' by Alice Derry, from the Spring issue of *Ploughshares*. This will be the last item I read from the most recent *Ploughshares*. Maybe I'll write something tomorrow about how I choose which poems I read and why I choose so few poems from each journal. There are so many poems I skip over: at one point I would have thought that this means I don't love poetry *enough*, but now I think it's a sign of how *seriously* I take poetry. Not seriously in a straight-faced way. That's not what I mean. What I mean is that *our preferences reveal us to ourselves*. Aesthetic preference is a form of self-knowledge. We learn more about who we are in a given moment by what we like and dislike in that moment. And self-knowledge is a serious thing, an important thing, an important step toward happiness. Oy vey. Let's get to some poetry.

'Horse Fantasies' is (in my opinion) about envy and projection and the formation of the imagination. The speaker is a woman looking back on her childhood as an indoorsy girl living in Montana. She does well at school and probably has a boringly happy home life. The object of her attention is 'Terry Jo, the last child / and only daughter of a rancher / whose spread lay deep / in the sheepland steppe, forty miles / south of our little town.' There's something romantic about Terry Jo's parents. Her father is a hard man. His hardness has driven his sons away. He's a man of the land and yet is 'one of the royalty of our town'. I certainly knew these kind of people growing up in California's Central Valley. During the winter Terry Jo lives with her mother in town. I'm guessing that for a suburban kid in the Midwest in say the 60's or 70's, a wife who lives apart from her husband for a portion of the year has got to seem like a pretty unusual thing. It unsettles (for the better, in my humble O) so much of what a child thinks they know about family.

But I'm not even talking about the most important part yet. Terry Jo rides horses. Her father 'taught her horseflesh, the saddle merely / an extension of four-legged motion.' This is what sticks out to the speaker about Terry Jo. The poem's first line: 'for all the horses I didn't get to ride'. Terry Jo is what the speaker didn't get to be. Is there anybody who doesn't carry with them a memory of that one kid in school who got to do all the cool things we wanted to do but couldn't? (Unless of course *you were that kid*, in which case you can get lost, you jerk.) Either we weren't allowed to or our parents didn't have the money to or we just never knew how to follow our dreams. And they were a kid's dreams. "Riding horses? So what? I should be over this by now." But that memory persists, that envy persists, and we pore out a lifetime of frustrated desires into that memory, so that we never forget our Terry Jo, the girl who was everything we weren't.

And so we deify her. She becomes a touchstone for our childhood, for the place where we grew up. She becomes unreal. The last lines: 'I spoke the language of those ragged plains / as well as she who learned to sweep along them, / wind's love and not its resistance.' The place itself loved Terry Jo as it only could in a child's imagination. This poem reminds me so much of Wordsworth's *Prelude*; for me that's just about the highest praise you can offer.

Such an interesting poem. I could go on and on about it, but I've gotta rein it in. (Horse metaphors!) If you're interested in this poem by Alice Derry be sure to get a copy of the Spring issue of *Ploughshares*. Keep reading poets. Keep talking about poets. Keep supporting poets. Until tomorrow, y'all.

entry.title: 'Aurora Perpetua' by Campbell McGrath
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Aurora Perpetua' by Campbell McGrath, from the Spring 2014 issue of Ploughshares.

This poem is too gorgeous not to share. If I'm asked to take it down, I will, but here's the full poem in all its twelve-line glory. I'll encourage you up front to go and buy Ploughshares online or in stores to help support poets and journals of such high quality. OK, here's 'Aurora Perpetua':

   O tulip, tulip, you bloom all day and later sway
   a deep-waisted limbo above the dinner table,
   waiting for a coin to drop into your well,
   for the stars to pin your stem to their lapel.

   Soon, on ocean winds, dawn cries its devotion,
   our world entranced once more into being.
   Let go your sumptuous rage, darling.
   All this awed awakening is a form of adoration.

   What's born in that fountain of salt and spume,
   of spackled sea monsters and gardenia perfume,
   is everything blossoming ever amounts to:
   an hour of earthly nectar, a single drop of dew.

      -- Campbell McGrath, *Ploughshares*, Vol. 40, no. 1, Spring 2014, p.152, © 2014 by Emerson College

Part of me is skeptical of such a perfectly musical poem. 'Is the *prettiness* of it covering up nonsense? Is there really any *thought* in this poem?' But I think *there is* thought. The individual tulip, representative of the fleeting moment of beauty, the small triumph, is being shown its source in the great 'fountain of salt and spume'. The tulip wants to be exalted; the momentary wants to become eternal. But it needs to be reminded that the eternal is its source; it is a drop of the eternal, made of the same stuff as the eternal, consubstantial with it. No need then, tulip, to wait 'for the stars to pin your stem to their lapel.' In other words, *you don't need to be taken up to perfection, because you are the scion of perfection*.

'Let go your sumptuous rage, darling.' How many of us are waiting for something to take us up and make us great? How many of us secretly despise, from time to time, the smallness of our lives? 'Let go your sumptuous rage, darling.' How many of us erase little poems we've written, throw first attempts at writing a novel in the trash because we're unhappy with them? How many of us don't bother to be patient or kind or gentle because, you know, what difference does that make in the big scheme of things? 'Let go your sumptuous rage, darling.' Don't pity yourself and indulge your sumptuous rage and wait until morning for another opportunity; the morning is always already arriving.

entry.title: 'To One Waiting to be Born' by Malachi Black
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'To One Waiting to be Born' by Malachi Black, from the Spring issue of *Ploughshares*. The poem is in three sections or movements, each about fifteen lines long, in blank verse. The poem is directly addressed to one waiting to be born, a sort of song of consolation and instruction and benediction.

The first few lines of a poem are so important. They set the rhythm and the key, if I can borrow a musical phrase without seeming pretentious. (You're thinking, 'No, you can't.') I love Black's first lines in this poem: 'Know your origin: you are a token / of the afterwards of love.' That's a beautiful thing to say to a child, but isn't it also a great thing to remember as an adult? But it plunges from romance to an apology for how cruel the world will be.

      Good luck; you won't be born as much
   as you'll be given up. And as you tumble
   from your orbit toward this crib of sticks
   and dust, be adamant. Be tough. All earth
   is but a roughness underfoot.

Everything falls apart, including the body. 'You will spoil like a plum.' The solution? 'Be wild: be stranger / and more formless than a boy.' And in the last lines: 'drift as a bright curl in the bluish light / of sky: impervious, indifferent, unhuman.'

Doesn't that take such a strange turn by the end? (I think that final benediction reads a lot like 'Mansion' by A.R. Ammons, for whatever that's worth.) The speaker is basically saying: 'you would be better off if you hadn't been born, or at least not born human.' Who hasn't felt that in moments of trial and hardship? Who hasn't felt, consciously or not, a certain jealousy of the wind and the mountains and the seas which get to be part of this world without all the burdens of life and death? It's ultimately very life-affirming, I think, as it grounds us in our humanity, but it gets there through such a strange and sobering road. Really great companion pieces for comparison would be Yeats' 'A Prayer for my Son' and 'A Prayer for my Daughter'.

Be sure to pick up a copy of *Ploughshares* in stores or online. Read poetry, talk about poetry, support poetry, eat too much poetry and choke on poetry, get in a big fight with poetry and then kiss and make up with poetry. It'll be worth it. Have a happy Friday!

entry.title: 'Serial Seeing' by Elaine Equi
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Serial Seeing' by Elaine Equi, from the *Columbia Poetry Review* no. 27. I've looked at several other poems by Equi already (here, here, here, and here). Here's 'Serial Seeing':

   A totality
   claims to be,
   but really--

   how could it
   contain everything?

   Gaps
   let the work
   breathe,

   let the reader
   in among.

   When art is
   too complete,

   you're locked outside

   (a cold business)

   with nothing left
   to do but admire.

      -- Elaine Equi, Columbia Poetry Review no. 27, p.176, © 2014 Columbia College Chicago

I love the phrase, "Gaps / let the work / breathe, / let the reader / in among." The grammatical emptiness after the preposition "among" enacts the very principle the poet is talking about. Our minds want to fill in the object of the preposition; the poem draws us in, draws out our inner voice to fill the gap. Lucretius in the *De Rerum Natura* puts forward his theory that the only way motion is possible is if there exists a void, a gap between atoms. If there weren't a gap, nothing would be able to move. In more modern scientific terms, no movement means no heat, absolute zero, "a cold business" indeed. And then you come to that perfect last couplet: "nothing left / to do but admire". Have you ever thought of admiration as an ethical problem? Admiration can be a distance you allow between yourself and the things you supposedly love. You can call it respect or admiration or appreciation, but it can be a way of protecting yourself from wild, warmblooded life and turning it into "a cold business". For me at least, it's important to let literature be a part of your life and let your life be a part of literature. I think that's at least partly what Equi is getting at in this poem.

This is the last of the poems from the *Columbia Poetry Review* that I'll be looking at. It's an annual, so I guess I'll have to wait until next year for more. Tomorrow I'll turn to some of the poems in the most recent issue of *Ploughshares*. Until then!

entry.title: 'Glass Box' by Sandra Simonds
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Glass Box' by Sandra Simonds, from the *Columbia Poetry Review* no. 27.

I'm gonna geek out about poetic form for a sec, so feel free to skip ahead. The poem (I think) is in 10 pseudo-Spenserian stanzas. They have the same shape as a Spenserian, but they are unrhymed, and sometimes a stanza will have have too many or too few lines, and the lines will be indented to imply a sort of rhythm, and even though the stanzas are numbered the contents sometimes spill over from one to the next. Maybe she wasn't going for the Spenserian shape at all, but there's certainly an implied ideal shape which is sometimes adhered to and sometimes cast aside. Which is of course part of the poem's theme. The poet chafes against the form as the individual chafes against society.

Here's a small excerpt, from stanza 9:

   We--the workers and also my lover and my husband
as well as the man who rejected me, pulled back
   the curtain to find a wall. Then I wasn't so sure I was being
rejected. My lover texted me "we need to talk,"
   I ran ten miles, cooked a vegetarian lasagna for my husband,
bought a pirate costume for my son.
   "The Indian Ocean is in Chicago," my son said.
If I don't correct him, I am a bad mom, bad sister,
   bad daughter, bad philosopher-king.

The web of relations and roles is so complex, all of it -- for 'an ordinary woman or "mom" living at the beginning of the 21st / century' -- defined by sex and knowledge and power (if those are three different things). The speaker, like 21st century society, is distracted; we go from her sex life to encounters with a troll on Twitter to motherhood to scholarly references to Dante and the Très Riches Heures. In the very last stanza the poet identifies with a figure from the Très Riches Heures' page for February.

Here are the lines from the poem:

And on the page representing February, the farm workers
   are warming themselves inside the cottage and the sheep
huddle together outside, but the thing the viewer most
identifies with is the girl with steamy breath on the far right,
   stumbling back through the snow
and the frozen village in the far distance.

I find the girl's isolation, her place outside of domestic warmth and village life, quite moving. I've seen this image before and never before noticed what Simonds is pointing out here. Isn't that such an important part of what a poet does? *Poets make us see things we've never seen before*. There's so much of this poem that I'm not discussing, so much that makes it great, but we like what we like and we do what we can. Until tomorrow, poetry-lovers.

entry.title: The Poetry Magazine Podcast
entry.content:
So I just listened to the *Poetry Magazine* podcast for the first time this morning on the way to work. It featured Rosanna Warren and Thomas Sayers Ellis reading their poems and Dorothea Lasky discussing her essay from the latest issue of *Poetry*. Looking through the iTunes store, I see that many have tried poetry podcasts but few have succeeded. A podcast is a really cool idea for poetry, I think, though it exposes how weird most spoken poetry can be. Rosanna Warren and Thomas Sayers Ellis both had this kind of 'preacherly' tone, and I think that's sort of what a lot of us want American poetry to be, a sort of sermon. I'm not crazy about it. To me, a lot of American poetry is visual rather than aural. For spoken poetry I like something a little less stentorian, something you can say in a calm voice without looking like you spent the last couple months working on it. I like long sensuous lines that ease their way through your mind rather than clippy little riddles, and if a poem is going to contain clippy riddles, I like it to be short like a zen koan, not a long chain of riddle after riddle after riddle. I'm so opinionated this afternoon; it's hot out. In any case, I look forward to listening to more. If I listen to an episode and really like the way somebody reads their stuff, I'll write something about it here on the blog.

Alright, gotta scoot. Until tomorrow!

entry.title: 'Pardon My Heart' by Marcus Jackson
entry.content:
This morning I'm looking at 'Pardon My Heart' by Marcus Jackson, which appears on the back cover of the most recent issue of The American Poetry Review. This one's available on the web for free, so I'm going to put the full text up. But do check out the APR's site and consider buying a copy of the magazine. At $4.50 for the issue it's a steal.

So here's 'Pardon My Heart' by Marcus Jackson:

   

Pardon my heart if it ruins your party.
It’s a large, American heart and has had

a good deal to drink. It’s a pretty bad
dancer—too much feeling, too little technique.

It may sing some godless hymns, about ousting
armies of loneliness, about marching

victorious to wives and towns beneath
a heart-colored dusk. Pardon my heart

if it closes its eyes for hours,
whispering *rapture* over and over.

Pardon my heart if it laughs too loudly,
or if it tells many of its stories

too ardently. Pardon my heart if it rests
an arm across you or your friends’ shoulders—

touch allows my heart to trust that it’s not
imagining your company’s loveliness.

Pardon my heart if you have to kick it out.
After you’ve muzzled the music and brightened

the lights to tidy, my heart will ignore
and keep doing its little two-step, aglow

in the middle of the room, never
happier to have nowhere else to go.

     -- from The American Poetry Review, Vol. 43 No. 4

On the one hand, this poem makes me feel embarrassed for the speaker. The phrase 'pardon my heart' is so angsty, something a teenager would scrawl in a notebook. I imagine someone dramatically throwing a cape across his face, yelling "Look away!" It's a self-contradictory message. But on the other hand I think it's so honest about poetry, all art but especially poetry, about the loneliness of it, the weird compromise of sociability and withdrawal that it requires. I love the image: 'my heart will ignore / and keep doing its little two-step / in the middle of the room'. When you're caught up in the rhythm of a poem you're writing or reading and really *getting* it's such a small thing, just a little shuffle back and forth, but it's yours and that makes it everything. For that little while you're *in it* and nothing else matters. And you know before you go in that it's going to be embarrassing when you come out, but you've got to do it anyway. Why is it this way? I don't know, but it is. So you just have to tell the world: 'pardon my heart'.

Good stuff. It never ceases to amaze me how many talented artists are out there. Check out The American Poetry Review's website to see about purchasing this issue, to see more great poems from the latest issue, or to set yourself up with a subscription.

Alright, that'll do it for today. Have a good day, everybody!

entry.title: Why I'm Blogging
entry.content:
So every now and then I get into these moods where I examine all my daily routines and ask, "Why am I doing this?" It's a good thing to do, though maybe not quite so often as I do it.

Anyway, the time has come. (Yeah, I've been blogging just over one week and already I'm taking stock.) So here are what I consider the main reasons I'm keeping this blog going.

  • I want to learn about contemporary American poetry. There are so many journals out there publishing so much poetry; I want to find the stuff that I like.
  • I want to share what I like. I know that I've definitely typed things like 'best contemporary American poets' into Google and read through the first couple pages of results. That's something I hope to provide here, a link to what I consider the best.
  • I want to write and really get my writing abilities back in shape. I know the quality of this first couple weeks' worth of posts hasn't been that great. I know I would never submit anything I've published here to a serious forum. But I also know that it's already made me feel more comfortable with writing after the couple years' hiatus I've gone through after leaving grad school. It's a bit of rehabilitation. It's good for me. It's fun.

Anyway, even if I haven't convinced you, I've convinced myself. So the blogging will continue. :-)

entry.title: 'Elegy for the Road' by Tatiana Oroño (translated by Jesse Lee Kercheval)
entry.content:
I picked up a few new journals / magazines to read yesterday. The July/August issue of the *American Poetry Review*, the summer issue of *The Threepenny Review*, and the Spring issue of *Ploughshares*. I look forward to reading through them in the coming weeks. Today's poem is 'Elegy for the Road' by Tatiana Oroño (translated by Jesse Lee Kercheval), from the Spring issue of *Ploughshares*.

The poem is written in two short prose paragraphs. In the first paragraph, the speaker says "I ask where the things go that did not arrive at their destination" and then rephrases each of this sentence's elements repeatedly. Who is is asking whom? Why isn't this broken into lines as we expect in a poem? Then, in the second paragraph, an answer comes: "Poetry is the place where the things go that have no solution. To look for it."

Something this poem got me thinking about that I hadn't before is a certain scene in Orlando Furioso when the knight Astolfo flies to the moon to recover Orlando's wits. The moon is his destination because that's where all lost things go. The connection Oroño's poem made for me is that the moon itself, in its *fantastic unreachableness*, is a symbol of poetry, of imagination, of invention. The moon is a place of elegy, a place where lost things live on in name alone. All lost things go to the moon because, for those of us who miss them, *we need them to be somewhere*.

The poem also got me thinking about what it means for a piece of text to be a poem. How can prose be poetry? Is anything we put in the poetry section poetry? As an analysis of poetry itself, Oroño's poem perhaps shows a relationship between prose thought and poetic invention. Philosophical speculation and poetry are separate activities; philosophy pokes holes in the universe and poetry tries to fill them. Poetry is somewhat philosophical, at least, because it shows where the holes are by filling them. But they aren't the same activity.

I'm not too sure I see how the poem's title relates to its content. I've never really cared about titles, except for when it comes to minimizing the anxiety I feel about the titles of my own poems. But usually I like to sense *some* connection between the title and the body. Oh well. So much for the lost title. I should write a poem about it, or see if it's on the moon.

link.title: 'Elegy for the Road' by Tatiana Oroño (translated by Jesse Lee Kercheval)

entry.title: 'Long, Long Ago I Used to Smoke in Bed' by Diane Seuss
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Long, Long Ago I Used to Smoke in Bed' by Diane Seuss, from the Columbia Poetry Review no. 27. (This journal *still* isn't available online anywhere, so you'll have to either explore your local bookstores or contact CPR directly to get a copy)

I love the way this poem unfolds. The speaker lives in the basement of an old Victorian house. She describes her space: she owns nothing, nothing but a red velour chair with a matching ottoman and 'a cardboard box / full of tangled costume jewelry'. She dresses up and hennas her hair for nobody in particular. So far so weird. Then we learn that to make money she transcribes the recorded confessions of a murderer for a local author, and that she has a love/hate with Arthur Rimbaud. And that local girls come by with their boyfriends to visit her, the girls attracted by her strange way of life, the boys upset by losing their girlfriends' attention for even a second. (If this feels really vague then I think that's the point. She talks about it so generally but it seems like there's something very specific behind it. How many of these girls and boys could there really have been?) And then we learn that the upper floors of the Victorian house are haunted by a woman waiting for her fiancé.

I'm a big fan of Edmund Spencer's *The Faerie Queene*, which is full of contrasting masculine-feminine pairs. No sooner does Spencer create one romantic couple than he feels compelled to create another one to contrast with it, and then another, and another, until his fantasy world is buzzing with varying wavelengths of love and lust. Maybe that informs why I try to read this poem the way I do. The contrasting pairs are:
   The poet 'long ago'|  Arthur Rimbaud
   Michigan girls who love her  |  Michigan boys who hate her
   The ghost upstairs|  The ghost's lost fiancé
   The poet now|  ??

What are they pointing to? What traumatic event ties these all together? Or is that not it at all? Is this a symbolic portrait of a psyche? I don't know, but I love it, love to think about it. Yesterday I looked at a poem that I read very personally, but good poetry can also be *an invitation to think about the unfamiliar*.

link.title: 'Long, Long Ago I Used to Smoke in Bed' by Diane Seuss

entry.title: 'Math Rock Drummer' by Cameron Dezen Hammon
entry.content:
I picked up the *Columbia Poetry Review* no. 27 at Barnes & Noble pretty much at random about a week and a half ago. Most of it wasn't quite my taste, but it had a few poems that I really enjoyed. Elaine Equi's poems were the highlight for me (I've discussed one of them already), but I also really enjoyed 'Long, Long Ago I Used to Smoke in Bed' by Diane Seuss, 'Glass Box' by Sandra Simonds, and (the subject of this post) 'Math Rock Drummer' by Cameron Dezen Hammon.

'Math Rock Drummer' is a very direct, colloquial poem about (on the surface) a failed relationship. A twenty-four year old 'math rock drummer' courts a nineteen year old girl using his poetry, but when he meets her she proves a disappointment 'in flesh'. But it's just as well from her perspective: he's not nearly as romantic as his poetic persona or musical ability would make you expect. 'In real life he talked like a Baltimore / fisherman, not like Eliot.' And then she sums it up in what are no doubt the best ending lines of this entire issue of *CPR*: 'I knew it would never work // No man could love both me and Pound.'

I'm about to take this in a personal direction because this poem really spoke to me about my own story, but before I do I'll say something more generally about the poem. I love how quickly the poem moves. Hammon's short phrases and conversational tone let her include real humor, the kind of self-confident everyday humor you won't find in many other poems. Which is great because it's also a poem about positioning oneself artistically, about stating one's artistic alliances and what it means to live those alliances, the sort of *ars poetica* poem that doesn't usually include humor.

So now for the personal bit. When I was in highschool, playing in a really bad garage band, *who you listened to* was a way of telling the world *who you were*. This would still probably be the case if I hung out with musicians. When I got to grad school, it was all about *who you read*. Some pretty boring personalities could hide themselves in whatever romantic glow surrounded Sebald or Post-war Cinema or the digital humanities. I did the very same thing with Classics and Renaissance Studies. I waved them over my head like a flag. 'This is me! This is me!' When I told people that I was writing something about the Faerie Queene or Catullus, I was saying '*I'm* the sort of guy who venerates old things but also wants to re-invigorate them through bold, new ways of reading.' The problem was that I didn't really want that and I wasn't really that sort of guy. It was just a stance. Worse, I found the company of people who *genuinely* wanted that to be insufferable. There was a disconnect between my literary 'interests' and who I really was. My approach to literature had its roots in my own conservative upbringing in California's Central Valley. I was raised in an electrically self-conflicted combination of liberal Catholicism and small-town provincialism. As long as I wasn't addressing *that*, that beautiful *tension*, I wasn't going to have a healthy relationship with literature or (more importantly) with other people. I needed to admit that I was more 'Baltimore fisherman' than urbane scholar before I could correct my angle of approach toward literature and people.

I guess what I'm trying to get at is that *we can use our literary and artistic interests to hide from ourselves and from others*. It's something we all have to be careful of. It's something I failed to be aware of for an embarrassingly long time.

Speaking of embarrassment, I've been talking about myself for a while now. But that's something really good poems can get you to do, right? They show you to yourself and make you reconsider who you are. That's what Cameron Dezen Hammon's 'Math Rock Drummer' did for me.

link.title: 'Math Rock Drummer' by Cameron Dezen Hammon

entry.title: 'Hymn to Life' by Timothy Donnelly
entry.content:
The last poem I'll look at from the July/August 2014 issue of *Poetry Magazine* is Timothy Donnelly's 'Hymn to Life'.

The poem is arranged in sixty six-line stanzas. The lines are of fairly equal length across the page (would you call that typographical length?) but with no stable metrical guidelines that I can see. If you're reading the poem online, you won't see that the sixty stanzas are arranged five to a page for twelve pages. It seems to me that the poem's theme is the *overwhelming abundance* of life, so the way his poem appears on the page -- nearly filling up the physical page, taking all the space it can -- is relevant to its theme. His use of enjambment is relevant too: there's hardly a phrase or an idea that isn't so full that it must spill over the edge of the line or the stanza. Also significant is his range of register: we move from biology to geology to pop music to the Bible to the writer's home as he's writing the poem. It's all about abundance.

Which is why it's so funny that the first line begins: 'There were no American lions.' Odd for a poem about life to begin with *extinction*, but it continues to do so, piling up names of the deceased and a few anecdotes of the last time certain species were ever seen. In the insistent march of 'Life' (a sort of Whitmanian 'procreant urge') so much is left behind. 'Life', if it is a god that deserves a hymn, is a bit terrifying. 'Life' isn't Mother Nature so much as an imperious queen who's liable to forget her loyal subjects while she makes new plans.

Eighteen stanzas into the poem we get these lines, which explain the theme of the poem about as well as anything could:

   ... All these gains and losses, so mysterious
   from a distance, held together it has felt by nothing stronger
   than momentum, like a series of bicycle accidents or a pattern
   in the pomegranate, come to hint at a logic in time, but whether
   it’s more fitting to say that they promise to reveal it or else

   threaten to is debatable.

There aren't many long poems that I'm crazy about, but Donnelly's 'Hymn to Life' works on the same wavelength, for me, as the long poems written by two of my favorites: Whitman and Ginsberg. I highly recommend it.

That finishes up my reading of the latest *Poetry Magazine*. Maybe I should write a little something about why I didn't choose the other poems? Maybe I'll do something like that later. Right now I'm too excited about finding things I like. I'll just say this though: I love poetry more maturely now than I did when I was younger. When I was younger and I didn't like a poem, I passionately disliked it. I berated it. I knew how *good* poetry could be, and it bothered and offended me that *all* poems weren't that good. I was awful. The worst. Now I believe in *pluralism* in literature. If I don't like a poem, there's probably somebody else who does, and that's ok. That poem simply wasn't made for me. Maybe later I'll be the sort of person that poem was made for, and then I'll be grateful it's there. So in lieu of spilling critical poison in your ear regarding all the things I don't like and why, I'll leave you with a quotation attributed to Kurt Vonnegut: "Any reviewer who expresses rage and loathing for a novel is preposterous. He or she is like a person who has put on full armor and attacked a hot fudge sundae."

entry.title: 'It Says What We All Think' by Elaine Equi
entry.content:
'It Says What We All Think' is the last of the Elaine Equi poems I'll be looking at from the July/August 2014 issue of *Poetry Magazine*.

The photo that accompanies 'It Says What We All Think' is of a red-painted wall with the words 'LOVE ME' rolled on in white. It's above street level, though it isn't clear how high. The poem hints that it can be found 'Getting off the subway at Canal St.' Mere Bostonian that I am, I leave it to the New Yorkers to determine what this location might add to the context. If this were an ancient poem (my background is in Classics) we would interpret it as a liminal space between Lower Manhattan and Midtown and explore the social valences of the location, where it positions the poet socially, how it reveals the Sitz im Leben of the poem.

Those are all good questions to ask, but I think they stay too far away from the poem. The poem is just a marginal note, just a tag. The point of Equi's poem is to bring up an important question about this 'LOVE ME': who is the author? This is the marginal note she adds to this little piece of New York. Imagine New York were divided into a billion photos of New York on Instagram or Facebook, each with its own comment board. Wouldn't Equi's question -- who wrote this? -- be a fitting comment? Her simple and unpretentious diction would fit in perfectly to this context. This is why I interpret these poems as *marginalia*. They fit alongside life, alongside the world as it is experienced outside of literature. They don't try to transform the world into art; they just use art to make comment or mark an occasion.

Speaking of marginalia, here's a marginal note of my own. Something that bothers me in my own writing is the relationship between the title and the poem's body. Equi's first line in the poem is "even if we won't admit it." The line of thought continues from the title, as thought the title were just another line that happened to be bold and in four-points larger font. Wallace Stevens does this with his titles, and it bothers me to no end. In my own writing I think of the title as something incidental. I would rather just have numbers or dates to reference them. But usually I buckle to some sense of pressure and tag each poem with a title that I don't really believe in.

Alright, I had better sign off for the day. This is my eighth day of blogging about poetry. It's been fun and it's been difficult, too. I genuinely enjoy the poems I write about, and I genuinely enjoy writing about them. But I don't know if anyone's really reading. The few views Google says I have could just be bots. I know I would read a blog like this, so I have to force myself to believe that other people would too. Gotta just stay true to the work and give it time and patience and let it become what it becomes.

link.title: 'It Says What We All Think' by Elaine Equi

entry.title: 'Something's Coming' by Elaine Equi
entry.content:
OK, I'm itching to get at another Elaine Equi poem, so I'm going to do write this second post today. This post is about 'Something's Coming' from the *Columbia Poetry Review *no. 27.

Unfortunately *CPR* hasn't updated its website or put the journal for sale online anywhere, so I can't advise on how you can get a copy of this poem unless you've got a really good local bookstore. And alas, because of my respect for copyright law I'm afraid I won't put the poem up here for you. So here's what I'll do: I'll try to describe the poem in such a way that you'll want to do everything in your power to go out and get a copy for yourself.

This is, like, the ultimate Boho hipster holiday love poem. It starts with a couple exchanging gifts on their first 'Xmas' together. The speaker receives 'Einstein's theory of relativity, / soap on a rope, *West Side Story*' and gives "a bottle of Stolichnaya'. The next day a neighbor is helping them dig their car out of the snow and remarks that 'he'd never seen / two people so happy / to go to Burger King.'

It comes in three short stanzas. The movement is quick and decisive: you gave --> I gave --> the neighbor said. Done. End of poem. It's got that living unornamented quality to it that the best of William Carlos Williams has. The sentence structures and diction are contemporary, colloquial. The speaker says "Xmas" instead of "Christmas" in the first line, and that letter X carries so much, doesn't it? Two lines meeting, a symbol of union, the Chi of Christ, the ex of a lonely life left behind. (Am I being too imaginative in my reading? I don't care.) And the Burger King kills me. It comes across without a trace of the bathetic. It just feels real and sweet.

I sometimes think that poem's chief value can be in how imitable it is. I first thought this when reading Jonathan Swift's birthday poems to Stella. I think now that, if I were to sit down and write a love poem to my wife, I might do it like Elaine Equi has done here. Short and sweet and honest and funny. Perfect.

entry.title: 'Wolves of the Sacred Heart' by Elaine Equi
entry.content:
Today I'm looking at 'Wolves of the Sacred Heart' by Elaine Equi, part of her photo and poetry collection 'Local Colors' in the July/August 2014 issue of *Poetry Magazine*. And in case you're wondering, I really do enjoy poems that *don't* include animals and I'll look at one tomorrow, I promise.

In the photo the camera is drawn up close to two pictures in elegant gold-finished antique frames. Just in front of the pictures in their frames are some fake flowers, described in the accompanying poem as "color-coded floral candelabras". I'm guessing they are some kind of cheap plastic or glass, something thin so that when they are turned on the light can shine through their pink and white petals. The real stars of the show, however, are the pictures themselves. The picture on the left is of three wolves in a snowy landscape. The two wolves on the left and right are standing with their bodies at profile, their faces turned toward the viewer as though they were posing for their portrait. The third wolf between them is sort of slinking or stalking toward us, its head angled down just slightly toward the snow. This wolf's body is not in profile, and the difficulties of foreshortening seem to have overwhelmed the artist. The picture on the right is of Jesus dressed in a lush crimson tunic under a blue cape -- like Superman in reverse. In the exact center of his chest is visible the Sacred Heart, bleeding, bound in thorns, radiating some kind of holy light. You can't see his face, but he's doing that classic Jesus-thing with his left hand where he's making a ninety degree angle between his extended thumb and index finger while drawing his middle, ring, and pinky fingers in toward his stigmata-marked palm.

Equi's poem reads:

   Leave it to the street vendors
   of NYC to improvise a shrine
   from whatever they find,

   setting a place at their table
   for animal and divine nature
   symbolically joined with
   color-coded floral candelabras.

One principle of composition that I love is *juxtaposition*. Just put things next to each other and let the reader or viewer infer connections. Here the connections are established on a vendor's table. It's commerce that brings these things together -- religion and nature and fake nature. But "commerce" is a crass way of putting it. The engine of commerce is desire, and desire is the impulse to draw things into oneself. What puts these three items on the table, what unites "animal and divine nature", is the desire to be both animal and divine, incorporate them, embody them. You couldn't choose a more perfect symbol than the Sacred Heart, the ultimate symbol of the union of God and human flesh. (I've read that the beating of the heart is the first source of all music and poetry. Is that relevant? Do I care?) You also couldn't choose a more perfect symbol than those fake flowers, those painted wolves. We love things that live. We love to love things that live. That's how they all get onto the same table.

I'll read one more Equi poem from *Poetry Magazine* tomorrow, then I'm going to look at some of her stuff in the latest *Columbia Poetry Review*. Until next time!

link.title: 'Wolves of the Sacred Heart' by Elaine Equi

entry.title: 'Cats, Now and Forever' by Elaine Equi
entry.content:
Today I'm looking at 'Cats, Now and Forever' from Elaine Equi's collection of photographs and poems called 'Local Colors', printed in the July/August 2014 issue of *Poetry Magazine*. In the photo there are two ceramic figurines, I'm guessing six inches tall at most, on a dark wicker shelf, probably in a store full of old knick-knacks. They are anthropomorphic cats in Victorian or conservative early 20th century dress, glossy and colorful. One of the cats is reading a book entitled *Lady Catterly's Lover*. She is shocked at what she reads: the one hand that is not holding the book is raised to her mouth, as though she is gasping. The other cat is also reading, though from the angle of the photograph we can't tell what. *A Tale of Two Kitties*? Below the photograph, Equi appends these two prosey lines of verse:

   An arty feline couple parodies bourgeois gender roles
   and literary values before the days of YouTube.

The one cat's shocked reaction to D.H. Lawrence dates it as an expression of a certain attitude toward books and sex. But no that's not it at all: it dates it as a parody of that Victorian attitude. It doesn't show a world shocked at sex; it shows a world amused that there had been a world (a childish, kittyish world) that was shocked at sex. It's a little remarkable that someone chose to express that sense of amusement at the preceding generation's naiveté into (of all things) a couple of cat figurines. Yet I can't help but think that whoever buys these figurines will buy them not for the quality as social commentary but because they think the kitties are cute.

The poem, for me, brings out two things. First, it reminds me that one form of poetry is *marginalia*. Poetry can be the clever comment or memorandum written off to the side of life. Equi's verses give us her take on this little piece of New York that who knows how many thousands have passed by in silence. There is nothing so kitsch or banal or abstract that it can't be made the subject of a poem. This sort of attitude is eye-opening, not just for poets but for people moving about their everyday world.

Second, I'm interested in the way we use animals to talk about ourselves. As in my look at Devin Johnston's 'Scavenger', I feel tempted when I read an animal poem to anthropomorphize, allegorize, moralize. It's very hard to see another living thing and not invest it with one's own mode of consciousness. Why? Is this a hangover from reading too much Aesop? Watching too many Disney cartoons? These cat figurines, like the YouTube videos Equi mentions, buy wholly into the representative quality of animals. Animals are 'cute', 'adorable'.

I feel like I'm missing the point. There's a point here and I don't see it yet; at least I know that I'm not seeing it. Maybe it will come to me as I look more closely at the other photographs in the series. That will have to wait for tomorrow, unfortunately. Elaine Equi also has some poems in the *Columbia Poetry Review* so I'll look at those afterward, too. Until tomorrow, then!

link.title: 'Cats, Now and Forever' by Elaine Equi

entry.title: 'Orpingtons' by Devin Johnston
entry.content:
Today I'm reading 'Orpingtons' by Devin Johnston, from the July/August 2014 issue of *Poetry Magazine*. Here's a lovely picture of an Orpington very like the ones Johnston describes in the poem:

The two Orpingtons in the poem are dark colored: one is black, the other a deep blue. It is late, nearly the full dark of night. I don't think it says in the poem, but the night must be warm, perhaps cooled slightly by a last evening breeze. The poem ends quietly as it began, three of the most beautiful lines I've read in some time: "the days grow long enough / to kindle in each a yolk, / the smallest flame of spring."

All poems don't really need commentary, do they? Can't it be enough to just say, "Read this"? Perhaps. But in my experience it's precisely the poems that *least* conspicuously employ symbol and gesture that require the *most* clarification.

Or rather let's say this: *it is right to talk about the things we love*. Yes, that feels true to me.

"They settle down to roost, / two rests upon a stave." This is the critical pair of lines for me, the only time the poem draws slightly away from the closely observed subject toward something, I don't know, aesthetic. The two Orpingtons are compared to musical notation, but not the sound of two notes but the sound of rest. They are pauses, they are living quietnesses. And this quietness, through the last three lines -- "the days grow long enough / to kindle in each a yolk, / the smallest flame of spring" --, is tied to regeneration, creation, slow and organic growth of new life.

That's the last of Devin Johnston's poems I'm going to talk about in a while. Tomorrow I'll look at Elaine Equi's photographs from the same issue of *Poetry Magazine*, then hopefully I can talk about some poets from the new *Columbia Poetry Review* before returning to *Poetry* to talk about Timothy Donnelly's 'Hymn to Life'. Until next time!

entry.title: 'Scavenger' by Devin Johnston
entry.content:
Today I'm looking at 'Scavenger' by Devin Johnston, from the July/August 2014 issue of Poetry Magazine. This one is a straightforward nature poem, I think. The poet observes a buff-banded rail picking at the scraps around the feet of some picnickers.

The buff-banded rail is a scavenger native to Australia and the South Pacific. Here's a pic:

Johnston's choice of vocabulary makes me want to anthropomorphize the rail so that I can draw a moral from it. The rail 'queries' its food, its manners are 'so refined / as to be indeterminate', its 'herringbone' is 'immaculate', it is 'aloof though underfoot', it shows 'no trace / of table-scrap solicitude / for any human hand or face'. It strikes me as descriptive of a certain kind of person whose refined manners hardly mask his greed. This turns the rail into an emblem rather than a bird, a rail and not a rail.

That phrase in the second-to-last line, 'table-scrap solicitude', reminds me of the story of the rich man and Lazarus in the Gospel of Luke. In light of that reference, the picnickers are a sort of council of the gods, and the rail is the rich man who eats their scraps but doesn't acknowledge it with gratitude or any sense of responsibility to share his blessings.

But I can see already that that's over-reading. There's nothing wrong with over-reading as long as we acknowledge it as such. Over-reading can be a good thing. We readers discover ourselves in what we add to the poem. Contemplating a poem is very like dreaming. It helps coax the subconscious mind to come out and play. For me, I've always got this God and Mammon question churning somewhere in my mind, so I shouldn't be surprised that it came up while I tried to read a poem.

But after this kind of over-reading you always have to come back to the buff-banded rail. It is, after all, just a bird. As a picnicker, would I try to shoo it away? Wouldn't that make me the rich man and him Lazarus? Why shouldn't I share with it? What other way do I have to commune with it except by sharing food? Why should I judge it because it *appears* entitled? There is a kind of pitiable spiritual poverty in those who wish to appear dignified without containing the substance of dignity, isn't there? And if that poverty is pitiable, will I express my pity? Will I live it?

I'm over-reaching again. Always back to the rail, back to the rail, back to the rail. It's so hard to look at something not like a mirror. Nobody said this would be easy.

entry.title: 'Telephone' by Devin Johnston
entry.content:
'Telephone,' by Devin Johnston, is an amazing poem in the July/August issue of *Poetry Magazine*. This was the first time I'd read Johnston's work, but now I'm going to make a point of reading all of it.

Formally it's a very simple poem. It's built of six-and-a-half six-line stanzas, each line about two to seven syllables long. There's no punctuation but the stops come naturally at the ends of lines and stanzas. No pretension, no experimentation, dignified in its simplicity.

The poem opens with a mockingbird perched on a long-abandoned payphone. The phone is ringing in the overgrown hedges -- who's calling whom? from where? -- and the mockingbird mimics the sound. The sound of the ringing spreads first among birds and then among humans, "from Kiowa / to Comanche to Clark". I'm assuming Clark here is William Clark, the American explorer who along with Meriwether Lewis brought so many Native American words into American English. Then someone picks up -- who? when? -- and "a voice / on the other end" says the name of the Kaw people who gave the territory and then state of Kansas its name. "Kansas" has been interpreted (possibly *mis*interpreted) as meaning "people of the wind," which explains something of the last half-stanza: "*Kaw* / which is only the sound / of a word for wind / then only the sound of wind".

It's a striking movement of images and thought. The poem *feels* like a nature poem at first, but it becomes historical and then even political by the end. The death of the last mother-tongue Kansa speaker in the 1980s is relevant. That last half-stanza leaves you just sitting there, listening to the silence of what should be three more lines. You should sit in silence for three lines. It's the sound of wind, the sound after the end of all speech.

The sadness of it, the unshakable sense of apocalypse that follows the image of the Kaw people, makes us reevaluate the poem from the beginning. The payphone, too, is an outmoded form of speech. If this were Wordsworth the mockingbird would be sitting on a stone ruin or a tree with someone's name carved into it; instead it's sitting on a method of communication whose time is up. Like the Kansa language to William Clark or the French trappers, the ringing of the payphone is just insignificant sound to the mockingbird. But an old system of signification, in its extinction, becomes a signifier in a new system of signification. The sound of a payphone ringing and of the Kansa language are given a new life, such as it is, in songs and place-names.

Is the person who picks up the phone the person the message was intended for? I think the answer to this question must be yes because, really, *the message is intended for whoever will listen*. The "voice / on the other end" who picks up must be the sort of person who goes out into the hedges, into the abandoned places, and is willing to engage with whatever is willing to speak. And the speaker speaks, regardless of the listener's contingency. And who is the speaker whose calling? I think we could say it's history, though that word "history" is so vague here. It's the voice of *what-has-been* ringing out like a bell. *Maybe *that gets a little closer to it? It's a trace or remnant of what was, always speaking itself if we are willing to listen.

So endeth my interpretation. My thoughts are half-formed. But this is a blog, after all. I know that I don't have adequate answers to certain questions like, What role does the poet play in all this? I know that five years from now my interpretation may be completely different. But just by exploring, attempting, braving questions, and braving answers I feel closer to the poem, closer to the poet, closer to myself as a poet, closer to poetry, centered, more myself, more at home in language, more at home in the universe. That may not be what poetry is for, but it's what poetry does for me.

Jesus, I'm so damned dramatic and sentimental sometimes. I'm always embarrassed by it, but maybe some people like it. Whatevs. Still a couple more Johnston poems in this issue of *Poetry Magazine *to look at. I'll do those tomorrow and Monday.

entry.title: Highlights from this month's Poetry Magazine
entry.content:
The July/August issue of *Poetry Magazine* is a good one. The highlights for me (all of which I'll explore more in upcoming posts) are Devin Johnston's three poems, Timothy Donnelly's 'Hymn to Life,' a set of beautiful art prints by Tony Fitzpatrick, and a photo series by Elaine Equi.

The big beast of a poem in this issue is Timothy Donnelly's 'Hymn to Life.' It's like Walt Whitman meets John McPhee, this wild foray into American geology and biology and history but with this interesting six-line stanza structure and (thank you!) a respect for the sentence.

(Ah, the sentence. So many poems use sentence fragments to get a vatic or gnomic tone that's just so *embarrassing*. If free verse is like playing tennis without the net, writing in sentence fragments is like playing without the ball. That said, I definitely write in fragments too, and when fragment poems are good they're damn good.)

*Poetry* does a great job with prints. The colors from Tony Fitzpatrick's drawings/collages and Elaine Equi's photos really pop. Maybe it's the beautiful heavy paper they print on? Anyway, the production quality is wonderful. Tony Fitzpatrick is an amazing Chicago artist that I hadn't heard of before, but now I want to see everything he's done. And Elaine Equi I had only just recently discovered (I am, as always, several years behind everyone else) through the *Columbia Poetry Review* no. 27, so it was awesome to see more of her work in *Poetry*.

And then there are Devin Johnston's three poems. I want to call them bird poems because birds are the key image in all three, but that would be a little reductive. I love their quiet tone, slow and observant and thoughtful. They have an equal dignity on the page and read aloud. Lovely.

entry.title: The AIRC Index
entry.content:
Last week my wife and I stopped at the Barnes & Noble just around the corner from our apartment here in Boston. Since it's near a university it has a good selection of literary journals, more than your average big-box bookstore. I picked up a copy of *Poetry Magazine*, the July/August issue, along with the annual *Columbia Poetry Review*. I've read them both now and, thinking about my reading experience, I notice that I had one of four reactions to each poem:
  • Attraction - I enjoyed the poem, for whatever reason, and I finished it wanting to read more by its author.
  • Indifference - I understood the poem, but it just didn't click with me on any level. I was left feeling open to the possibility that its author might, under different circumstances, have written something that I would like.
  • Repulsion - I understood the poem but found its message, form, or some other aspect objectionable. I was put off reading anything else by its author.
  • Confusion - I simply didn't understand the poem. I couldn't see a message or a form in it. Water under the bridge.
It was always more or less one of these four reactions, which gave me an idea. As I read more journals, I'll give each issue a grade based on the percentage of poems that really attracted me divided by the total number of poems. I'm calling it the AIRC index. Do you love it or hate it? Whatever, I love it so it's staying. The AIRC index for the July/August Poetry Magazine, for example, would be about 30%. Compare that to 11% for the *Columbia Poetry Review*.* *These numbers are extremely subjective, of course, but over time it will give me a solid idea of which journals have editors whose taste is similar to my own. This is a valuable exercise as a reader *and *as a writer. I've been unsuccessfully submitting poems to journals for about a year now, and one of my big mistakes is that I haven't been reading any of the journals I'm submitting to. If I had blindly submitted material to the *Columbia Poetry Review*, for example, I would never have known that their aesthetic is *very *different from my own. They're a little more Charles Bernstein, I'm a little more Devin Johnston: alas, this union was not meant to be.  Anyway, I'll try out this thing out for a little while. If it's a total bust I'll abandon it, but I've got high hopes.

entry.title: Making a Change
entry.content:
This blog is a continuation of what I'm doing over on Tumblr. Same content, different url.

It’s halfway through the year and I’m halfway through my goal of reading 100 books in 2014. Something I’ve reconnected with through this experience is my love of poetry.

I love to read poetry. I’ll read through hundreds of pages of bad poems just to find one that I like, and I love that search. And I love that once I’ve found that one poem, I can revisit it again and again, learn it by heart, give it a place in my brain. Novels and short fiction, by comparison, almost always feel like a bit of a slog.

I also genuinely enjoy writing poetry. It’s fun. Writing fiction and reviews, I grate my teeth with frustration. But writing poetry, even my failures feel like victories, because I enjoy the process so much. The rules make sense to me, and I have (who knows how!) a guiding intuition.

So I’m going to switch things up a bit. I’m going to commit to poetry. From now on, it’s all poetry all the time. timreadsbooks is now <cue fanfare> timreadspoetry.

I’m struggling to come up with a snappy ending for this post, so I’m just gonna stop.
